boot.blacklistedKernelModules.description:
List of names of kernel modules that should not be loaded
automatically by the hardware probing code.

boot.cleanTmpDir.description: Whether to delete all files in <filename>/tmp</filename> during boot.

boot.consoleLogLevel.description:
The kernel console log level.  Log messages with a priority
numerically less than this will not appear on the console.

boot.crashDump.enable.description:
If enabled, NixOS will set up a kernel that will
boot on crash, and leave the user in systemd rescue
to be able to save the crashed kernel dump at
/proc/vmcore.
It also activates the NMI watchdog.

boot.crashDump.kernelParams.description: Parameters that will be passed to the kernel kexec-ed on crash.

boot.crashDump.reservedMemory.description:
The amount of memory reserved for the crashdump kernel.
If you choose a too high value, dmesg will mention
"crashkernel reservation failed".

boot.devShmSize.description:
Size limit for the /dev/shm tmpfs. Look at mount(8), tmpfs size option,
for the accepted syntax.

boot.devSize.description:
Size limit for the /dev tmpfs. Look at mount(8), tmpfs size option,
for the accepted syntax.

boot.earlyVconsoleSetup.description: Enable setting font as early as possible (in initrd).

boot.enableContainers.description: Whether to enable support for nixos containers.

boot.extraModprobeConfig.description:
Any additional configuration to be appended to the generated
<filename>modprobe.conf</filename>.  This is typically used to
specify module options.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>modprobe.conf</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry> for details.

boot.extraModulePackages.description: A list of additional packages supplying kernel modules.

boot.extraTTYs.description:
Tty (virtual console) devices, in addition to the consoles on
which mingetty and syslogd run, that must be initialised.
Only useful if you have some program that you want to run on
some fixed console.  For example, the NixOS installation CD
opens the manual in a web browser on console 7, so it sets
<option>boot.extraTTYs</option> to <literal>["tty7"]</literal>.

boot.hardwareScan.description:
Whether to try to load kernel modules for all detected hardware.
Usually this does a good job of providing you with the modules
you need, but sometimes it can crash the system or cause other
nasty effects.

boot.initrd.availableKernelModules.description:
The set of kernel modules in the initial ramdisk used during the
boot process.  This set must include all modules necessary for
mounting the root device.  That is, it should include modules
for the physical device (e.g., SCSI drivers) and for the file
system (e.g., ext3).  The set specified here is automatically
closed under the module dependency relation, i.e., all
dependencies of the modules list here are included
automatically.  The modules listed here are available in the
initrd, but are only loaded on demand (e.g., the ext3 module is
loaded automatically when an ext3 filesystem is mounted, and
modules for PCI devices are loaded when they match the PCI ID
of a device in your system).  To force a module to be loaded,
include it in <option>boot.initrd.kernelModules</option>.

boot.initrd.checkJournalingFS.description: Whether to run <command>fsck</command> on journaling filesystems such as ext3.

boot.initrd.kernelModules.description: List of modules that are always loaded by the initrd.

boot.initrd.luks.cryptoModules.description:
A list of cryptographic kernel modules needed to decrypt the root device(s).
The default includes all common modules.

boot.initrd.luks.devices.description:
The encrypted disk that should be opened before the root
filesystem is mounted. Both LVM-over-LUKS and LUKS-over-LVM
setups are supported. The unencrypted devices can be accessed as
<filename>/dev/mapper/<replaceable>name</replaceable></filename>.
boot.initrd.luks.devices.type: list or attribute set of submodules

boot.initrd.luks.devices.<name?>.allowDi.description:
Whether to allow TRIM requests to the underlying device. This option
has security implications; please read the LUKS documentation before
activating it.

boot.initrd.luks.devices.<name?>.device.description: Path of the underlying encrypted block device.

boot.initrd.luks.devices.<name?>.header.description:
The name of the file or block device that
should be used as header for the encrypted device.

boot.initrd.luks.devices.<name?>.keyFile.description:
The name of the file (can be a raw device or a partition) that
should be used as the decryption key for the encrypted device. If
not specified, you will be prompted for a passphrase instead.

The size of the key file. Use this if only the beginning of the
key file should be used as a key (often the case if a raw device
or partition is used as key file). If not specified, the whole
<literal>keyFile</literal> will be used decryption, instead of just
the first <literal>keyFileSize</literal> bytes.

boot.initrd.luks.devices.<name?>.preLVM.description: Whether the luksOpen will be attempted before LVM scan or after it.

boot.initrd.luks.devices.<name?>.yubikey.description:
The options to use for this LUKS device in Yubikey-PBA.
If null (the default), Yubikey-PBA will be disabled for this device.
Time in seconds to wait before attempting to find the Yubikey.
How much the iteration count for PBKDF2 is increased at each successful authentication.
Length of the LUKS slot key derived with PBKDF2 in byte.
Path where the ramfs used to update the LUKS key will be mounted during early boot.
Length of the new salt in byte (64 is the effective maximum).
Which slot on the Yubikey to challenge.

An unencrypted device that will temporarily be mounted in stage-1.
Must contain the current salt to create the challenge for this LUKS device.
The filesystem of the unencrypted device.
Path where the unencrypted device will be mounted during early boot.

Absolute path of the salt on the unencrypted device with
that device's root directory as "/".
Whether to use a passphrase and a Yubikey (true), or only a Yubikey (false).

boot.initrd.luks.mitigateDMAAttacks.description:
Unless enabled, encryption keys can be easily recovered by an attacker with physical
access to any machine with PCMCIA, ExpressCard, ThunderBolt or FireWire port.
More information is available at <link xlink:href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DMA_attack"/>.

This option blacklists FireWire drivers, but doesn't remove them. You can manually
load the drivers if you need to use a FireWire device, but don't forget to unload them!

boot.initrd.luks.yubikeySupport.description:
Enables support for authenticating with a Yubikey on LUKS devices.
See the NixOS wiki for information on how to properly setup a LUKS device
and a Yubikey to work with this feature.

boot.initrd.network.enable.description:
Add network connectivity support to initrd. The network may be
configured using the <literal>ip</literal> kernel parameter,
as described in <link
xlink:href="https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/filesystems/nfs/nfsroot.txt">the
kernel documentation</link>.  Otherwise, if
<option>networking.useDHCP</option> is enabled, an IP address
is acquired using DHCP.

boot.initrd.network.postCommands.description:
Shell commands to be executed after stage 1 of the
boot has initialised the network.

boot.initrd.network.ssh.authorizedKeys.description: Authorized keys for the root user on initrd.

boot.initrd.network.ssh.enable.description:
Start SSH service during initrd boot. It can be used to debug failing
boot on a remote server, enter pasphrase for an encrypted partition etc.
Service is killed when stage-1 boot is finished.

boot.initrd.network.ssh.hostDSSKey.description:
DSS SSH private key file in the Dropbear format.

WARNING: Unless your bootloader supports initrd secrets, this key is
contained insecurely in the global Nix store. Do NOT use your regular
SSH host private keys for this purpose or you'll expose them to
regular users!

boot.initrd.network.ssh.hostECDSAKey.description:
ECDSA SSH private key file in the Dropbear format.

WARNING: Unless your bootloader supports initrd secrets, this key is
contained insecurely in the global Nix store. Do NOT use your regular
SSH host private keys for this purpose or you'll expose them to
regular users!

boot.initrd.network.ssh.hostRSAKey.description:
RSA SSH private key file in the Dropbear format.

WARNING: Unless your bootloader supports initrd secrets, this key is
contained insecurely in the global Nix store. Do NOT use your regular
SSH host private keys for this purpose or you'll expose them to
regular users!

boot.initrd.network.ssh.port.description: Port on which SSH initrd service should listen.

boot.initrd.network.ssh.shell.description: Login shell of the remote user. Can be used to limit actions user can do.

boot.initrd.postDeviceCommands.description:
Shell commands to be executed immediately after stage 1 of the
boot has loaded kernel modules and created device nodes in
<filename>/dev</filename>.

boot.initrd.postMountCommands.description:
Shell commands to be executed immediately after the stage 1
filesystems have been mounted.

boot.initrd.preDeviceCommands.description:
Shell commands to be executed before udev is started to create
device nodes.

boot.initrd.preFailCommands.description: Shell commands to be executed before the failure prompt is shown.

boot.initrd.preLVMCommands.description: Shell commands to be executed immediately before LVM discovery.

boot.initrd.prepend.description: Other initrd files to prepend to the final initrd we are building.

boot.initrd.supportedFilesystems.description: Names of supported filesystem types in the initial ramdisk.

boot.isContainer.description:
Whether this NixOS machine is a lightweight container running
in another NixOS system.

boot.kernel.sysctl.description:
Runtime parameters of the Linux kernel, as set by
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>sysctl</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry>.  Note that sysctl
parameters names must be enclosed in quotes
(e.g. <literal>"vm.swappiness"</literal> instead of
<literal>vm.swappiness</literal>).  The value of each
parameter may be a string, integer, boolean, or null
(signifying the option will not appear at all).
boot.kernel.sysctl.type: attribute set of sysctl option values

boot.kernelModules.description:
The set of kernel modules to be loaded in the second stage of
the boot process.  Note that modules that are needed to
mount the root file system should be added to
<option>boot.initrd.availableKernelModules</option> or
<option>boot.initrd.kernelModules</option>.

boot.kernelPackages.description:
This option allows you to override the Linux kernel used by
NixOS.  Since things like external kernel module packages are
tied to the kernel you're using, it also overrides those.
This option is a function that takes Nixpkgs as an argument
(as a convenience), and returns an attribute set containing at
the very least an attribute <varname>kernel</varname>.
Additional attributes may be needed depending on your
configuration.  For instance, if you use the NVIDIA X driver,
then it also needs to contain an attribute
<varname>nvidia_x11</varname>.

boot.kernelParams.description: Parameters added to the kernel command line.

boot.kernelPatches.description: A list of additional patches to apply to the kernel.

boot.loader.efi.canTouchEfiVariables.description: Whether the installation process is allowed to modify EFI boot variables.

boot.loader.efi.efiSysMountPoint.description: Where the EFI System Partition is mounted.

boot.loader.generationsDir.copyKernels.description:
Whether copy the necessary boot files into /boot, so
/nix/store is not needed by the boot loader.

boot.loader.generationsDir.enable.description:
Whether to create symlinks to the system generations under
<literal>/boot</literal>.  When enabled,
<literal>/boot/default/kernel</literal>,
<literal>/boot/default/initrd</literal>, etc., are updated to
point to the current generation's kernel image, initial RAM
disk, and other bootstrap files.

This optional is not necessary with boot loaders such as GNU GRUB
for which the menu is updated to point to the latest bootstrap
files.  However, it is needed for U-Boot on platforms where the
boot command line is stored in flash memory rather than in a
menu file.

boot.loader.generic-extlinux-compatible..description: Maximum number of configurations in the boot menu.

Whether to generate an extlinux-compatible configuration file
under <literal>/boot/extlinux.conf</literal>.  For instance,
U-Boot's generic distro boot support uses this file format.

See <link xlink:href="http://git.denx.de/?p=u-boot.git;a=blob;f=doc/README.distro;hb=refs/heads/master">U-boot's documentation</link>
for more information.

boot.loader.grub.configurationLimit.description:
Maximum of configurations in boot menu. GRUB has problems when
there are too many entries.

boot.loader.grub.configurationName.description: GRUB entry name instead of default.

boot.loader.grub.copyKernels.description:
Whether the GRUB menu builder should copy kernels and initial
ramdisks to /boot.  This is done automatically if /boot is
on a different partition than /.

boot.loader.grub.default.description: Index of the default menu item to be booted.

boot.loader.grub.device.description:
The device on which the GRUB boot loader will be installed.
The special value <literal>nodev</literal> means that a GRUB
boot menu will be generated, but GRUB itself will not
actually be installed.  To install GRUB on multiple devices,
use <literal>boot.loader.grub.devices</literal>.

boot.loader.grub.devices.description:
The devices on which the boot loader, GRUB, will be
installed. Can be used instead of <literal>device</literal> to
install GRUB onto multiple devices.

boot.loader.grub.efiInstallAsRemovable.description:
Whether to invoke <literal>grub-install</literal> with
<literal>--removable</literal>.</para>

<para>Unless you turn this on, GRUB will install itself somewhere in
<literal>boot.loader.efi.efiSysMountPoint</literal> (exactly where
depends on other config variables). If you've set
<literal>boot.loader.efi.canTouchEfiVariables</literal> *AND* you
are currently booted in UEFI mode, then GRUB will use
<literal>efibootmgr</literal> to modify the boot order in the
EFI variables of your firmware to include this location. If you are
*not* booted in UEFI mode at the time GRUB is being installed, the
NVRAM will not be modified, and your system will not find GRUB at
boot time. However, GRUB will still return success so you may miss
the warning that gets printed ("<literal>efibootmgr: EFI variables
are not supported on this system.</literal>").</para>

<para>If you turn this feature on, GRUB will install itself in a
special location within <literal>efiSysMountPoint</literal> (namely
<literal>EFI/boot/boot$arch.efi</literal>) which the firmwares
are hardcoded to try first, regardless of NVRAM EFI variables.</para>

<para>To summarize, turn this on if:
<itemizedlist>
  <listitem><para>You are installing NixOS and want it to boot in UEFI mode,
  but you are currently booted in legacy mode</para></listitem>
  <listitem><para>You want to make a drive that will boot regardless of
  the NVRAM state of the computer (like a USB "removable" drive)</para></listitem>
  <listitem><para>You simply dislike the idea of depending on NVRAM
  state to make your drive bootable</para></listitem>
</itemizedlist>

boot.loader.grub.efiSupport.description:
Whether GRUB should be built with EFI support.
EFI support is only available for GRUB v2.
This option is ignored for GRUB v1.

boot.loader.grub.enable.description: Whether to enable the GNU GRUB boot loader.

boot.loader.grub.enableCryptodisk.description:
Enable support for encrypted partitions. GRUB should automatically
unlock the correct encrypted partition and look for filesystems.

boot.loader.grub.extraConfig.description:
Additional GRUB commands inserted in the configuration file
just before the menu entries.

boot.loader.grub.extraEntries.description: Any additional entries you want added to the GRUB boot menu.

boot.loader.grub.extraEntriesBeforeNixOS.description: Whether extraEntries are included before the default option.

boot.loader.grub.extraFiles.description:
A set of files to be copied to <filename>/boot</filename>.
Each attribute name denotes the destination file name in
<filename>/boot</filename>, while the corresponding
attribute value specifies the source file.

boot.loader.grub.extraInitrd.description:
The path to a second initramfs to be supplied to the kernel.
This ramfs will not be copied to the store, so that it can
contain secrets such as LUKS keyfiles or ssh keys.
This implies that rolling back to a previous configuration
won't rollback the state of this file.

boot.loader.grub.extraPerEntryConfig.description:
Additional GRUB commands inserted in the configuration file
at the start of each NixOS menu entry.

boot.loader.grub.extraPrepareConfig.description:
Additional bash commands to be run at the script that
prepares the GRUB menu entries.

boot.loader.grub.font.description: Path to a TrueType, OpenType, or pf2 font to be used by Grub.

boot.loader.grub.fontSize.description:
Font size for the grub menu. Ignored unless <literal>font</literal>
is set to a ttf or otf font.

boot.loader.grub.forceInstall.description:
Whether to try and forcibly install GRUB even if problems are
detected. It is not recommended to enable this unless you know what
you are doing.

boot.loader.grub.fsIdentifier.description:
Determines how GRUB will identify devices when generating the
configuration file. A value of uuid / label signifies that grub
will always resolve the uuid or label of the device before using
it in the configuration. A value of provided means that GRUB will
use the device name as show in <command>df</command> or
<command>mount</command>. Note, zfs zpools / datasets are ignored
and will always be mounted using their labels.

boot.loader.grub.gfxmodeBios.description: The gfxmode to pass to GRUB when loading a graphical boot interface under BIOS.

boot.loader.grub.gfxmodeEfi.description: The gfxmode to pass to GRUB when loading a graphical boot interface under EFI.

boot.loader.grub.ipxe.description:
Set of iPXE scripts available for
booting from the GRUB boot menu.
boot.loader.grub.ipxe.type: attribute set of path or strings

boot.loader.grub.memtest86.enable.description:
Make Memtest86+, a memory testing program, available from the
GRUB boot menu.

boot.loader.grub.memtest86.params.description:
Parameters added to the Memtest86+ command line. As of memtest86+ 5.01
the following list of (apparently undocumented) parameters are
accepted:

<itemizedlist>

<listitem>
  <para><literal>console=...</literal>, set up a serial console.
  Examples:
  <literal>console=ttyS0</literal>,
  <literal>console=ttyS0,9600</literal> or
  <literal>console=ttyS0,115200n8</literal>.</para>
</listitem>

<listitem>
  <para><literal>btrace</literal>, enable boot trace.</para>
</listitem>

<listitem>
  <para><literal>maxcpus=N</literal>, limit number of CPUs.</para>
</listitem>

<listitem>
  <para><literal>onepass</literal>, run one pass and exit if there
  are no errors.</para>
</listitem>

<listitem>
  <para><literal>tstlist=...</literal>, list of tests to run.
  Example: <literal>0,1,2</literal>.</para>
</listitem>

<listitem>
  <para><literal>cpumask=...</literal>, set a CPU mask, to select CPUs
  to use for testing.</para>
</listitem>

</itemizedlist>

This list of command line options was obtained by reading the
Memtest86+ source code.

boot.loader.grub.mirroredBoots.description:
Mirror the boot configuration to multiple partitions and install grub
to the respective devices corresponding to those partitions.

boot.loader.grub.mirroredBoots.*.devices.description:
The path to the devices which will have the GRUB MBR written.
Note these are typically device paths and not paths to partitions.

boot.loader.grub.mirroredBoots.*.efiBoot.description:
The id of the bootloader to store in efi nvram.
The default is to name it NixOS and append the path or efiSysMountPoint.
This is only used if <literal>boot.loader.efi.canTouchEfiVariables</literal> is true.

boot.loader.grub.mirroredBoots.*.efiSysM.description:
The path to the efi system mount point. Usually this is the same
partition as the above path and can be left as null.

boot.loader.grub.mirroredBoots.*.path.description:
The path to the boot directory where GRUB will be written. Generally
this boot path should double as an EFI path.

boot.loader.grub.splashImage.description:
Background image used for GRUB.  It must be a 640x480,
14-colour image in XPM format, optionally compressed with
<command>gzip</command> or <command>bzip2</command>.  Set to
<literal>null</literal> to run GRUB in text mode.

boot.loader.grub.storePath.description:
Path to the Nix store when looking for kernels at boot.
Only makes sense when copyKernels is false.

boot.loader.grub.trustedBoot.enable.description:
Enable trusted boot. GRUB will measure all critical components during
the boot process to offer TCG (TPM) support.

boot.loader.grub.trustedBoot.isHPLaptop.description:
Use a special version of TrustedGRUB that is needed by some HP laptops
and works only for the HP laptops.

boot.loader.grub.trustedBoot.systemHasTP.description:
Assertion that the target system has an activated TPM. It is a safety
check before allowing the activation of 'trustedBoot.enable'. TrustedBoot
WILL FAIL TO BOOT YOUR SYSTEM if no TPM is available.

boot.loader.grub.useOSProber.description: If set to true, append entries for other OSs detected by os-prober.

boot.loader.grub.version.description:
The version of GRUB to use: <literal>1</literal> for GRUB
Legacy (versions 0.9x), or <literal>2</literal> (the
default) for GRUB 2.

boot.loader.grub.zfsSupport.description:
Whether GRUB should be built against libzfs.
ZFS support is only available for GRUB v2.
This option is ignored for GRUB v1.

boot.loader.initScript.enable.description:
Some systems require a /sbin/init script which is started.
Or having it makes starting NixOS easier.
This applies to some kind of hosting services and user mode linux.

Additionally this script will create
/boot/init-other-configurations-contents.txt containing
contents of remaining configurations. You can copy paste them into
/sbin/init manually running a rescue system or such.

boot.loader.raspberryPi.enable.description:
Whether to create files with the system generations in
<literal>/boot</literal>.
<literal>/boot/old</literal> will hold files from old generations.

boot.loader.systemd-boot.editor.description:
Whether to allow editing the kernel command-line before
boot. It is recommended to set this to false, as it allows
gaining root access by passing init=/bin/sh as a kernel
parameter. However, it is enabled by default for backwards
compatibility.

boot.loader.systemd-boot.enable.description: Whether to enable the systemd-boot (formerly gummiboot) EFI boot manager

boot.loader.timeout.description: Timeout (in seconds) until loader boots the default menu item. Use null if the loader menu should be displayed indefinitely.

boot.plymouth.enable.description: Whether to enable Plymouth boot splash screen.

boot.plymouth.logo.description: Logo which is displayed on the splash screen.

boot.postBootCommands.description: Shell commands to be executed just before systemd is started.

boot.resumeDevice.description:
Device for manual resume attempt during boot. This should be used primarily
if you want to resume from file. If left empty, the swap partitions are used.
Specify here the device where the file resides.
You should also use <varname>boot.kernelParams</varname> to specify
<literal><replaceable>resume_offset</replaceable></literal>.

boot.runSize.description:
Size limit for the /run tmpfs. Look at mount(8), tmpfs size option,
for the accepted syntax.

boot.specialFileSystems.<name?>.mountPoi.description: Location of the mounted the file system.

boot.specialFileSystems.<name?>.options.description: Options used to mount the file system.

boot.tmpOnTmpfs.description: Whether to mount a tmpfs on <filename>/tmp</filename> during boot.

boot.vesa.description: Whether to activate VESA video mode on boot.

boot.zfs.devNodes.description:
Name of directory from which to import ZFS devices.

This should be a path under /dev containing stable names for all devices needed, as
import may fail if device nodes are renamed concurrently with a device failing.

boot.zfs.enableUnstable.description:
Use the unstable zfs package. This might be an option, if the latest
kernel is not yet supported by a published release of ZFS. Enabling
this option will install a development version of ZFS on Linux. The
version will have already passed an extensive test suite, but it is
more likely to hit an undiscovered bug compared to running a released
version of ZFS on Linux.

boot.zfs.extraPools.description:
Name or GUID of extra ZFS pools that you wish to import during boot.

Usually this is not necessary. Instead, you should set the mountpoint property
of ZFS filesystems to <literal>legacy</literal> and add the ZFS filesystems to
NixOS's <option>fileSystems</option> option, which makes NixOS automatically
import the associated pool.

However, in some cases (e.g. if you have many filesystems) it may be preferable
to exclusively use ZFS commands to manage filesystems. If so, since NixOS/systemd
will not be managing those filesystems, you will need to specify the ZFS pool here
so that NixOS automatically imports it on every boot.

boot.zfs.forceImportAll.description:
Forcibly import all ZFS pool(s).

This is enabled by default for backwards compatibility purposes, but it is highly
recommended to disable this option, as it bypasses some of the safeguards ZFS uses
to protect your ZFS pools.

If you set this option to <literal>false</literal> and NixOS subsequently fails to
import your non-root ZFS pool(s), you should manually import each pool with
"zpool import -f <pool-name>", and then reboot. You should only need to do
this once.

boot.zfs.forceImportRoot.description:
Forcibly import the ZFS root pool(s) during early boot.

This is enabled by default for backwards compatibility purposes, but it is highly
recommended to disable this option, as it bypasses some of the safeguards ZFS uses
to protect your ZFS pools.

If you set this option to <literal>false</literal> and NixOS subsequently fails to
boot because it cannot import the root pool, you should boot with the
<literal>zfs_force=1</literal> option as a kernel parameter (e.g. by manually
editing the kernel params in grub during boot). You should only need to do this
once.

boot.zfs.requestEncryptionCredentials.description:
Request encryption keys or passwords for all encrypted datasets on import.

Dataset encryption is only supported in zfsUnstable at the moment.

containers.description:
A set of NixOS system configurations to be run as lightweight
containers.  Each container appears as a service
<literal>container-<replaceable>name</replaceable></literal>
on the host system, allowing it to be started and stopped via
<command>systemctl</command>.

containers.<name>.additionalCapabilities.description:
Grant additional capabilities to the container.  See the
capabilities(7) and systemd-nspawn(1) man pages for more
information.

containers.<name>.allowedDevices.description: A list of device nodes to which the containers has access to.

containers.<name>.allowedDevices.*.modif.description:
Device node access modifier. Takes a combination
<literal>r</literal> (read), <literal>w</literal> (write), and
<literal>m</literal> (mknod). See the
<literal>systemd.resource-control(5)</literal> man page for more
information.

containers.<name>.autoStart.description: Whether the container is automatically started at boot-time.

containers.<name>.bindMounts.description: An extra list of directories that is bound to the container.
containers.<name>.bindMounts.type: list or attribute set of submodules

containers.<name>.bindMounts.<name?>.hos.description: Location of the host path to be mounted.

containers.<name>.bindMounts.<name?>.isR.description: Determine whether the mounted path will be accessed in read-only mode.

containers.<name>.bindMounts.<name?>.mou.description: Mount point on the container file system.

containers.<name>.config.description:
A specification of the desired configuration of this
container, as a NixOS module.

containers.<name>.enableTun.description:
Allows the container to create and setup tunnel interfaces
by granting the <literal>NET_ADMIN</literal> capability and
enabling access to <literal>/dev/net/tun</literal>.

containers.<name>.extraVeths.description: Extra veth-pairs to be created for the container

containers.<name>.extraVeths.<name>.forw.description:
List of forwarded ports from host to container. Each forwarded port
is specified by protocol, hostPort and containerPort. By default,
protocol is tcp and hostPort and containerPort are assumed to be
the same if containerPort is not explicitly given.
Source port of the external interface on host
The protocol specifier for port forwarding between host and container

containers.<name>.extraVeths.<name>.host.description:
The IPv4 address assigned to the host interface.
(Not used when hostBridge is set.)

The IPv6 address assigned to the host interface.
(Not used when hostBridge is set.)

Put the host-side of the veth-pair into the named bridge.
Only one of hostAddress* or hostBridge can be given.

containers.<name>.extraVeths.<name>.loca.description:
The IPv4 address assigned to the interface in the container.
If a hostBridge is used, this should be given with netmask to access
the whole network. Otherwise the default netmask is /32 and routing is
set up from localAddress to hostAddress and back.

The IPv6 address assigned to the interface in the container.
If a hostBridge is used, this should be given with netmask to access
the whole network. Otherwise the default netmask is /128 and routing is
set up from localAddress6 to hostAddress6 and back.

containers.<name>.forwardPorts.description:
List of forwarded ports from host to container. Each forwarded port
is specified by protocol, hostPort and containerPort. By default,
protocol is tcp and hostPort and containerPort are assumed to be
the same if containerPort is not explicitly given.

containers.<name>.forwardPorts.*.hostPor.description: Source port of the external interface on host

containers.<name>.forwardPorts.*.protoco.description: The protocol specifier for port forwarding between host and container

containers.<name>.hostAddress.description:
The IPv4 address assigned to the host interface.
(Not used when hostBridge is set.)

containers.<name>.hostAddress6.description:
The IPv6 address assigned to the host interface.
(Not used when hostBridge is set.)

containers.<name>.hostBridge.description:
Put the host-side of the veth-pair into the named bridge.
Only one of hostAddress* or hostBridge can be given.

containers.<name>.interfaces.description: The list of interfaces to be moved into the container.

containers.<name>.localAddress.description:
The IPv4 address assigned to the interface in the container.
If a hostBridge is used, this should be given with netmask to access
the whole network. Otherwise the default netmask is /32 and routing is
set up from localAddress to hostAddress and back.

containers.<name>.localAddress6.description:
The IPv6 address assigned to the interface in the container.
If a hostBridge is used, this should be given with netmask to access
the whole network. Otherwise the default netmask is /128 and routing is
set up from localAddress6 to hostAddress6 and back.

containers.<name>.macvlans.description:
The list of host interfaces from which macvlans will be
created. For each interface specified, a macvlan interface
will be created and moved to the container.

containers.<name>.path.description:
As an alternative to specifying
<option>config</option>, you can specify the path to
the evaluated NixOS system configuration, typically a
symlink to a system profile.

containers.<name>.privateNetwork.description:
Whether to give the container its own private virtual
Ethernet interface.  The interface is called
<literal>eth0</literal>, and is hooked up to the interface
<literal>ve-<replaceable>container-name</replaceable></literal>
on the host.  If this option is not set, then the
container shares the network interfaces of the host,
and can bind to any port on any interface.

containers.<name>.tmpfs.description:
Mounts a set of tmpfs file systems into the container.
Multiple paths can be specified.
Valid items must conform to the --tmpfs argument
of systemd-nspawn. See systemd-nspawn(1) for details.

dysnomia.components.description: An atttribute set in which each key represents a container and each value an attribute set in which each key represents a component and each value a derivation constructing its initial state

dysnomia.containers.description: An attribute set in which each key represents a container and each value an attribute set providing its configuration properties

dysnomia.enableAuthentication.description: Whether to publish privacy-sensitive authentication credentials

dysnomia.extraContainerPaths.description: A list of paths containing additional container configurations that are added to the search folders

dysnomia.extraContainerProperties.description: An attribute set providing additional container settings in addition to the default properties

dysnomia.extraModulePaths.description: A list of paths containing additional modules that are added to the search folders

dysnomia.properties.description: An attribute set in which each attribute represents a machine property. Optionally, these values can be shell substitutions.

environment.blcr.enable.description: Whether to enable support for the BLCR checkpointing tool.

environment.etc.description: Set of files that have to be linked in <filename>/etc</filename>.
environment.etc.type: list or attribute set of submodules

environment.etc.<name?>.enable.description:
Whether this /etc file should be generated.  This
option allows specific /etc files to be disabled.

environment.etc.<name?>.gid.description:
GID of created file. Only takes affect when the file is
copied (that is, the mode is not 'symlink').

environment.etc.<name?>.group.description:
Group name of created file.
Only takes affect when the file is copied (that is, the mode is not 'symlink').
Changing this option takes precedence over <literal>gid</literal>.

environment.etc.<name?>.mode.description:
If set to something else than <literal>symlink</literal>,
the file is copied instead of symlinked, with the given
file mode.

environment.etc.<name?>.target.description:
Name of symlink (relative to
<filename>/etc</filename>).  Defaults to the attribute
name.

environment.etc.<name?>.uid.description:
UID of created file. Only takes affect when the file is
copied (that is, the mode is not 'symlink').

environment.etc.<name?>.user.description:
User name of created file.
Only takes affect when the file is copied (that is, the mode is not 'symlink').
Changing this option takes precedence over <literal>uid</literal>.

environment.extraInit.description:
Shell script code called during global environment initialisation
after all variables and profileVariables have been set.
This code is asumed to be shell-independent, which means you should
stick to pure sh without sh word split.

environment.extraOutputsToInstall.description: List of additional package outputs to be symlinked into <filename>/run/current-system/sw</filename>.

environment.freetds.description:
Configure freetds database entries. Each attribute denotes
a section within freetds.conf, and the value (a string) is the config
content for that section. When at least one entry is configured
the global environment variables FREETDSCONF, FREETDS and SYBASE
will be configured to allow the programs that use freetds to find the
library and config.

environment.gnome3.excludePackages.description: Which packages gnome should exclude from the default environment

environment.interactiveShellInit.description:
Shell script code called during interactive shell initialisation.
This code is asumed to be shell-independent, which means you should
stick to pure sh without sh word split.

environment.loginShellInit.description:
Shell script code called during login shell initialisation.
This code is asumed to be shell-independent, which means you should
stick to pure sh without sh word split.

environment.lxqt.excludePackages.description: Which LXQt packages to exclude from the default environment

environment.mate.excludePackages.description: Which MATE packages to exclude from the default environment

environment.noXlibs.description:
Switch off the options in the default configuration that
require X11 libraries. This includes client-side font
configuration and SSH forwarding of X11 authentication
in. Thus, you probably do not want to enable this option if
you want to run X11 programs on this machine via SSH.

environment.pathsToLink.description: List of directories to be symlinked in <filename>/run/current-system/sw</filename>.

environment.profileRelativeEnvVars.description:
Attribute set of environment variable.  Each attribute maps to a list
of relative paths.  Each relative path is appended to the each profile
of <option>environment.profiles</option> to form the content of the
corresponding environment variable.
environment.profileRelativeEnvVars.type: attribute set of list of stringss

environment.profiles.description: A list of profiles used to setup the global environment.

environment.sessionVariables.description:
A set of environment variables used in the global environment.
These variables will be set by PAM.
The value of each variable can be either a string or a list of
strings.  The latter is concatenated, interspersed with colon
characters.
environment.sessionVariables.type: attribute set of string or list of stringss

environment.shellAliases.description:
An attribute set that maps aliases (the top level attribute names in
this option) to command strings or directly to build outputs. The
aliases are added to all users' shells.

environment.shellInit.description:
Shell script code called during shell initialisation.
This code is asumed to be shell-independent, which means you should
stick to pure sh without sh word split.

environment.shells.description:
A list of permissible login shells for user accounts.
No need to mention <literal>/bin/sh</literal>
here, it is placed into this list implicitly.

environment.systemPackages.description:
The set of packages that appear in
/run/current-system/sw.  These packages are
automatically available to all users, and are
automatically updated every time you rebuild the system
configuration.  (The latter is the main difference with
installing them in the default profile,
<filename>/nix/var/nix/profiles/default</filename>.

environment.unixODBCDrivers.description:
Specifies Unix ODBC drivers to be registered in
<filename>/etc/odbcinst.ini</filename>.  You may also want to
add <literal>pkgs.unixODBC</literal> to the system path to get
a command line client to connnect to ODBC databases.

environment.variables.description:
A set of environment variables used in the global environment.
These variables will be set on shell initialisation.
The value of each variable can be either a string or a list of
strings.  The latter is concatenated, interspersed with colon
characters.
environment.variables.type: attribute set of string or list of stringss

fileSystems.description:
The file systems to be mounted.  It must include an entry for
the root directory (<literal>mountPoint = "/"</literal>).  Each
entry in the list is an attribute set with the following fields:
<literal>mountPoint</literal>, <literal>device</literal>,
<literal>fsType</literal> (a file system type recognised by
<command>mount</command>; defaults to
<literal>"auto"</literal>), and <literal>options</literal>
(the mount options passed to <command>mount</command> using the
<option>-o</option> flag; defaults to <literal>[ "defaults" ]</literal>).

Instead of specifying <literal>device</literal>, you can also
specify a volume label (<literal>label</literal>) for file
systems that support it, such as ext2/ext3 (see <command>mke2fs
-L</command>).
fileSystems.type: list or attribute set of submodules

fileSystems.<name?>.autoFormat.description:
If the device does not currently contain a filesystem (as
determined by <command>blkid</command>, then automatically
format it with the filesystem type specified in
<option>fsType</option>.  Use with caution.

fileSystems.<name?>.autoResize.description:
If set, the filesystem is grown to its maximum size before
being mounted. (This is typically the size of the containing
partition.) This is currently only supported for ext2/3/4
filesystems that are mounted during early boot.

fileSystems.<name?>.encrypted.blkDev.description: Location of the backing encrypted device.

fileSystems.<name?>.encrypted.enable.description: The block device is backed by an encrypted one, adds this device as a initrd luks entry.

fileSystems.<name?>.encrypted.keyFile.description: File system location of keyfile. This unlocks the drive after the root has been mounted to <literal>/mnt-root</literal>.

fileSystems.<name?>.encrypted.label.description: Label of the unlocked encrypted device. Set <literal>fileSystems.<name?>.device</literal> to <literal>/dev/mapper/<label></literal> to mount the unlocked device.

fileSystems.<name?>.formatOptions.description:
If <option>autoFormat</option> option is set specifies
extra options passed to mkfs.

fileSystems.<name?>.mountPoint.description: Location of the mounted the file system.

fileSystems.<name?>.neededForBoot.description:
If set, this file system will be mounted in the initial
ramdisk.  By default, this applies to the root file system
and to the file system containing
<filename>/nix/store</filename>.

fileSystems.<name?>.noCheck.description: Disable running fsck on this filesystem.

fileSystems.<name?>.options.description: Options used to mount the file system.

fonts.enableDefaultFonts.description:
Enable a basic set of fonts providing several font styles
and families and reasonable coverage of Unicode.

fonts.enableFontDir.description:
Whether to create a directory with links to all fonts in
<filename>/run/current-system/sw/share/X11-fonts</filename>.

fonts.enableGhostscriptFonts.description:
Whether to add the fonts provided by Ghostscript (such as
various URW fonts and the Base-14 Postscript fonts) to the
list of system fonts, making them available to X11
applications.

fonts.fontconfig.allowBitmaps.description:
Allow bitmap fonts. Set to <literal>false</literal> to ban all
bitmap fonts.

fonts.fontconfig.allowType1.description:
Allow Type-1 fonts. Default is <literal>false</literal> because of
poor rendering.

fonts.fontconfig.antialias.description:
Enable font antialiasing. At high resolution (> 200 DPI),
antialiasing has no visible effect; users of such displays may want
to disable this option.

fonts.fontconfig.cache32Bit.description: Generate system fonts cache for 32-bit applications.

fonts.fontconfig.defaultFonts.monospace.description:
System-wide default monospace font(s). Multiple fonts may be
listed in case multiple languages must be supported.

fonts.fontconfig.defaultFonts.sansSerif.description:
System-wide default sans serif font(s). Multiple fonts may be
listed in case multiple languages must be supported.

fonts.fontconfig.defaultFonts.serif.description:
System-wide default serif font(s). Multiple fonts may be listed
in case multiple languages must be supported.

fonts.fontconfig.dpi.description:
Force DPI setting. Setting to <literal>0</literal> disables DPI
forcing; the DPI detected for the display will be used.

fonts.fontconfig.enable.description:
If enabled, a Fontconfig configuration file will be built
pointing to a set of default fonts.  If you don't care about
running X11 applications or any other program that uses
Fontconfig, you can turn this option off and prevent a
dependency on all those fonts.

fonts.fontconfig.hinting.autohint.description:
Enable the autohinter in place of the default interpreter.
The results are usually lower quality than correctly-hinted
fonts, but better than unhinted fonts.

fonts.fontconfig.hinting.enable.description:
Enable font hinting. Hinting aligns glyphs to pixel boundaries to
improve rendering sharpness at low resolution. At high resolution
(> 200 dpi) hinting will do nothing (at best); users of such
displays may want to disable this option.

fonts.fontconfig.includeUserConf.description:
Include the user configuration from
<filename>~/.config/fontconfig/fonts.conf</filename> or
<filename>~/.config/fontconfig/conf.d</filename>.

fonts.fontconfig.localConf.description:
System-wide customization file contents, has higher priority than
<literal>defaultFonts</literal> settings.

fonts.fontconfig.penultimate.enable.description:
Enable fontconfig-penultimate settings to supplement the
NixOS defaults by providing per-font rendering defaults and
metric aliases.

fonts.fontconfig.subpixel.lcdfilter.description:
FreeType LCD filter. At high resolution (> 200 DPI), LCD filtering
has no visible effect; users of such displays may want to select
<literal>none</literal>.

fonts.fontconfig.subpixel.rgba.description:
Subpixel order. The overwhelming majority of displays are
<literal>rgb</literal> in their normal orientation. Select
<literal>vrgb</literal> for mounting such a display 90 degrees
clockwise from its normal orientation or <literal>vbgr</literal>
for mounting 90 degrees counter-clockwise. Select
<literal>bgr</literal> in the unlikely event of mounting 180
degrees from the normal orientation. Reverse these directions in
the improbable event that the display's native subpixel order is
<literal>bgr</literal>.

fonts.fontconfig.ultimate.enable.description:
Enable fontconfig-ultimate settings (formerly known as
Infinality). Besides the customizable settings in this NixOS
module, fontconfig-ultimate also provides many font-specific
rendering tweaks.

fonts.fontconfig.ultimate.preset.description:
FreeType rendering settings preset. Any of the presets may be
customized by setting environment variables.

fonts.fontconfig.ultimate.substitutions.description:
Font substitutions to replace common Type 1 fonts with nicer
TrueType fonts. <literal>free</literal> uses free fonts,
<literal>ms</literal> uses Microsoft fonts,
<literal>combi</literal> uses a combination, and
<literal>none</literal> disables the substitutions.

fonts.fontconfig.useEmbeddedBitmaps.description: Use embedded bitmaps in fonts like Calibri.

gnu.description:
When enabled, GNU software is chosen by default whenever a there is
a choice between GNU and non-GNU software (e.g., GNU lsh
vs. OpenSSH).

hardware.amdHybridGraphics.disable.description:
Completely disable the AMD graphics card and use the
integrated graphics processor instead.

hardware.bluetooth.enable.description: Whether to enable support for Bluetooth..

hardware.bluetooth.extraConfig.description:
Set additional configuration for system-wide bluetooth (/etc/bluetooth/main.conf).

NOTE: We already include [Policy], so any configuration under the Policy group should come first.

hardware.bluetooth.powerOnBoot.description: Whether to power up the default Bluetooth controller on boot.

hardware.bumblebee.connectDisplay.description:
Set to true if you intend to connect your discrete card to a
monitor. This option will set up your Nvidia card for EDID
discovery and to turn on the monitor signal.

Only nvidia driver is supported so far.

hardware.bumblebee.driver.description: Set driver used by bumblebeed. Supported are nouveau and nvidia.

hardware.bumblebee.enable.description:
Enable the bumblebee daemon to manage Optimus hybrid video cards.
This should power off secondary GPU until its use is requested
by running an application with optirun.

hardware.bumblebee.pmMethod.description: Set preferred power management method for unused card.

hardware.ckb.enable.description: Whether to enable the Corsair keyboard/mouse driver.

hardware.ckb.package.description: The package implementing the Corsair keyboard/mouse driver.

hardware.cpu.amd.updateMicrocode.description: Update the CPU microcode for AMD processors.

hardware.cpu.intel.updateMicrocode.description: Update the CPU microcode for Intel processors.

hardware.enableAllFirmware.description: Turn on this option if you want to enable all the firmware.

hardware.enableKSM.description: Whether to enable Kernel Same-Page Merging.

hardware.enableRedistributableFirmware.description:
Turn on this option if you want to enable all the firmware with a license allowing redistribution.
(i.e. free firmware and <literal>firmware-linux-nonfree</literal>)

hardware.facetimehd.enable.description: Whether to enable facetimehd kernel module.

hardware.firmware.description:
List of packages containing firmware files.  Such files
will be loaded automatically if the kernel asks for them
(i.e., when it has detected specific hardware that requires
firmware to function).  If multiple packages contain firmware
files with the same name, the first package in the list takes
precedence.  Note that you must rebuild your system if you add
files to any of these directories.

hardware.mcelog.enable.description: Enable the Machine Check Exception logger.

hardware.mwProCapture.enable.description: Whether to enable Magewell Pro Capture family kernel module.

hardware.nitrokey.enable.description:
Enables udev rules for Nitrokey devices. By default grants access
to users in the "nitrokey" group. You may want to install the
nitrokey-app package, depending on your device and needs.

hardware.nitrokey.group.description: Grant access to Nitrokey devices to users in this group.

hardware.nvidiaOptimus.disable.description:
Completely disable the NVIDIA graphics card and use the
integrated graphics processor instead.

hardware.opengl.driSupport.description:
Whether to enable accelerated OpenGL rendering through the
Direct Rendering Interface (DRI).

hardware.opengl.driSupport32Bit.description:
On 64-bit systems, whether to support Direct Rendering for
32-bit applications (such as Wine).  This is currently only
supported for the <literal>nvidia</literal> and 
<literal>ati_unfree</literal> drivers, as well as
<literal>Mesa</literal>.

hardware.opengl.extraPackages.description:
Additional packages to add to OpenGL drivers. This can be used
to add OpenCL drivers, VA-API/VDPAU drivers etc.

example.text: with pkgs; [ vaapiIntel libvdpau-va-gl vaapiVdpau intel-ocl ]

hardware.opengl.extraPackages32.description:
Additional packages to add to 32-bit OpenGL drivers on
64-bit systems. Used when <option>driSupport32Bit</option> is
set. This can be used to add OpenCL drivers, VA-API/VDPAU drivers etc.

hardware.opengl.s3tcSupport.description:
Make S3TC(S3 Texture Compression) via libtxc_dxtn available
to OpenGL drivers instead of the patent-free S2TC replacement.

Using this library may require a patent license depending on your location.

hardware.parallels.enable.description:
This enables Parallels Tools for Linux guests, along with provided
video, mouse and other hardware drivers.

hardware.pcmcia.config.description:
Path to the configuration file which maps the memory, IRQs
and ports used by the PCMCIA hardware.

hardware.pcmcia.enable.description: Enable this option to support PCMCIA card.

hardware.pcmcia.firmware.description: List of firmware used to handle specific PCMCIA card.

hardware.pulseaudio.configFile.description:
The path to the default configuration options the PulseAudio server
should use. By default, the "default.pa" configuration
from the PulseAudio distribution is used.

hardware.pulseaudio.daemon.config.description: Config of the pulse daemon. See <literal>man pulse-daemon.conf</literal>.

hardware.pulseaudio.daemon.logLevel.description:
The log level that the system-wide pulseaudio daemon should use,
if activated.

hardware.pulseaudio.enable.description: Whether to enable the PulseAudio sound server.

hardware.pulseaudio.extraClientConf.description: Extra configuration appended to pulse/client.conf file.

hardware.pulseaudio.extraConfig.description:
Literal string to append to <literal>configFile</literal>
and the config file generated by the pulseaudio module.

hardware.pulseaudio.package.description:
The PulseAudio derivation to use.  This can be used to enable
features (such as JACK support, Bluetooth) via the
<literal>pulseaudioFull</literal> package.

hardware.pulseaudio.support32Bit.description:
Whether to include the 32-bit pulseaudio libraries in the system or not.
This is only useful on 64-bit systems and currently limited to x86_64-linux.

hardware.pulseaudio.systemWide.description:
If false, a PulseAudio server is launched automatically for
each user that tries to use the sound system. The server runs
with user privileges. This is the recommended and most secure
way to use PulseAudio. If true, one system-wide PulseAudio
server is launched on boot, running as the user "pulse".
Please read the PulseAudio documentation for more details.

hardware.pulseaudio.tcp.anonymousClients.description: Whether to enable all anonymous clients to stream to the server.
A list of IP subnets that are allowed to stream to the server.

hardware.pulseaudio.tcp.enable.description: Whether to enable tcp streaming support.

hardware.pulseaudio.zeroconf.discovery.e.description: Whether to enable discovery of pulseaudio sinks in the local network.

hardware.pulseaudio.zeroconf.publish.ena.description: Whether to enable publishing the pulseaudio sink in the local network.

hardware.raid.HPSmartArray.enable.description: Whether to enable HP Smart Array kernel modules and CLI utility.

hardware.sane.enable.description:
Enable support for SANE scanners.

<note><para>
  Users in the "scanner" group will gain access to the scanner, or the "lp" group if it's also a printer.
</para></note>

hardware.sane.extraBackends.description:
Packages providing extra SANE backends to enable.

<note><para>
  The example contains the package for HP scanners.
</para></note>

hardware.sane.netConf.description: Network hosts that should be probed for remote scanners.

hardware.sane.snapshot.description: Use a development snapshot of SANE scanner drivers.

hardware.sensor.iio.enable.description: Enable this option to support IIO sensors.

hardware.trackpoint.emulateWheel.description: Enable scrolling while holding the middle mouse button.

hardware.trackpoint.enable.description: Enable sensitivity and speed configuration for trackpoints.

hardware.trackpoint.fakeButtons.description:
Switch to "bare" PS/2 mouse support in case Trackpoint buttons are not recognized
properly. This can happen for example on models like the L430, T450, T450s, on
which the Trackpoint buttons are actually a part of the Synaptics touchpad.

hardware.trackpoint.sensitivity.description:
Configure the trackpoint sensitivity. By default, the kernel
configures 128.

hardware.trackpoint.speed.description:
Configure the trackpoint speed. By default, the kernel
configures 97.

hardware.usbWwan.enable.description: Enable this option to support USB WWAN adapters.

i18n.consoleColors.description:
The 16 colors palette used by the virtual consoles.
Leave empty to use the default colors.
Colors must be in hexadecimal format and listed in
order from color 0 to color 15.

i18n.consoleFont.description:
The font used for the virtual consoles.  Leave empty to use
whatever the <command>setfont</command> program considers the
default font.

i18n.consoleKeyMap.description: The keyboard mapping table for the virtual consoles.

i18n.consolePackages.description:
List of additional packages that provide console fonts, keymaps and
other resources.

i18n.consoleUseXkbConfig.description:
If set, configure the console keymap from the xserver keyboard
settings.

i18n.defaultLocale.description:
The default locale.  It determines the language for program
messages, the format for dates and times, sort order, and so on.
It also determines the character set, such as UTF-8.

i18n.glibcLocales.description:
Customized pkg.glibcLocales package.

Changing this option can disable handling of i18n.defaultLocale
and supportedLocale.

i18n.inputMethod.enabled.description:
Select the enabled input method. Input methods is a software to input symbols that are not available on standard input devices.

Input methods are specially used to input Chinese, Japanese and Korean characters.

Currently the following input methods are available in NixOS:

<itemizedlist>
<listitem><para>ibus: The intelligent input bus, extra input engines can be added using <literal>i18n.inputMethod.ibus.engines</literal>.</para></listitem>
<listitem><para>fcitx: A customizable lightweight input method, extra input engines can be added using <literal>i18n.inputMethod.fcitx.engines</literal>.</para></listitem>
<listitem><para>nabi: A Korean input method based on XIM. Nabi doesn't support Qt 5.</para></listitem>
<listitem><para>uim: The universal input method, is a library with a XIM bridge. uim mainly support Chinese, Japanese and Korean.</para></listitem>
</itemizedlist>

i18n.inputMethod.fcitx.engines.description: Enabled Fcitx engines. Available engines are: <literal>anthy</literal>, <literal>chewing</literal>, <literal>cloudpinyin</literal>, <literal>hangul</literal>, <literal>libpinyin</literal>, <literal>m17n</literal>, <literal>mozc</literal>, <literal>rime</literal>, <literal>table-other</literal>, <literal>unikey</literal>.

i18n.inputMethod.ibus.engines.description: Enabled IBus engines. Available engines are: <literal>anthy</literal>, <literal>hangul</literal>, <literal>libpinyin</literal>, <literal>m17n</literal>, <literal>mozc</literal>, <literal>table</literal>, <literal>table-others</literal>, <literal>uniemoji</literal>.

i18n.inputMethod.ibus.panel.description: Replace the IBus panel with another panel.

i18n.supportedLocales.description:
List of locales that the system should support.  The value
<literal>"all"</literal> means that all locales supported by
Glibc will be installed.  A full list of supported locales
can be found at <link
xlink:href="https://sourceware.org/git/?p=glibc.git;a=blob;f=localedata/SUPPORTED"/>.

krb5.appdefaults.description: Settings used by some Kerberos V5 applications.

krb5.capaths.description: Authentication paths for non-hierarchical cross-realm authentication.

krb5.config.description:
Verbatim <literal>krb5.conf</literal> configuration.  Note that this
is mutually exclusive with configuration via
<literal>libdefaults</literal>, <literal>realms</literal>,
<literal>domain_realm</literal>, <literal>capaths</literal>,
<literal>appdefaults</literal>, <literal>plugins</literal> and
<literal>extraConfig</literal> configuration options.  Consult
<literal>man krb5.conf</literal> for documentation.
krb5.config.example:
[libdefaults]
  default_realm = EXAMPLE.COM

[realms]
  EXAMPLE.COM = {
    admin_server = kerberos.example.com
    kdc = kerberos.example.com
    default_principal_flags = +preauth
  }

[domain_realm]
  example.com  = EXAMPLE.COM
  .example.com = EXAMPLE.COM

[logging]
  kdc          = SYSLOG:NOTICE
  admin_server = SYSLOG:NOTICE
  default      = SYSLOG:NOTICE

krb5.domainRealm.description:
DEPRECATED, please create a map of server hostnames to Kerberos realms
in <literal>krb5.domain_realm</literal>.

krb5.domain_realm.description: Map of server hostnames to Kerberos realms.

krb5.enable.description: Whether to enable Whether to enable Kerberos V..

krb5.extraConfig.description:
These lines go to the end of <literal>krb5.conf</literal> verbatim.
<literal>krb5.conf</literal> may include any of the relations that are
valid for <literal>kdc.conf</literal> (see <literal>man
kdc.conf</literal>), but it is not a recommended practice.
krb5.extraConfig.example:
[logging]
  kdc          = SYSLOG:NOTICE
  admin_server = SYSLOG:NOTICE
  default      = SYSLOG:NOTICE

krb5.kdc.description:
DEPRECATED, please pass a <literal>kdc</literal> attribute to a realm
in <literal>krb5.realms</literal>.

krb5.kerberos.description:
The Kerberos implementation that will be present in
<literal>environment.systemPackages</literal> after enabling this
service.

krb5.kerberosAdminServer.description:
DEPRECATED, please pass an <literal>admin_server</literal> attribute
to a realm in <literal>krb5.realms</literal>.

krb5.libdefaults.description: Settings used by the Kerberos V5 library.

lib.description: This option allows modules to define helper functions, constants, etc.

nesting.clone.description:
Additional configurations to build based on the current
configuration which then has a lower priority.

networking.bonds.description:
This option allows you to define bond devices that aggregate multiple,
underlying networking interfaces together. The value of this option is
an attribute set. Each attribute specifies a bond, with the attribute
name specifying the name of the bond's network interface

networking.bonds.<name>.driverOptions.description:
Options for the bonding driver.
Documentation can be found in
<link xlink:href="https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/bonding.txt" />

networking.bonds.<name>.lacp_rate.description:
DEPRECATED, use `driverOptions`.
Option specifying the rate in which we'll ask our link partner
to transmit LACPDU packets in 802.3ad mode.

networking.bonds.<name>.miimon.description:
DEPRECATED, use `driverOptions`.
Miimon is the number of millisecond in between each round of polling
by the device driver for failed links. By default polling is not
enabled and the driver is trusted to properly detect and handle
failure scenarios.

networking.bonds.<name>.mode.description:
DEPRECATED, use `driverOptions`.
The mode which the bond will be running. The default mode for
the bonding driver is balance-rr, optimizing for throughput.
More information about valid modes can be found at
https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/bonding.txt

networking.bonds.<name>.xmit_hash_policy.description:
DEPRECATED, use `driverOptions`.
Selects the transmit hash policy to use for slave selection in
balance-xor, 802.3ad, and tlb modes.

networking.bridges.description:
This option allows you to define Ethernet bridge devices
that connect physical networks together.  The value of this
option is an attribute set.  Each attribute specifies a
bridge, with the attribute name specifying the name of the
bridge's network interface.

networking.bridges.<name>.interfaces.description: The physical network interfaces connected by the bridge.

networking.bridges.<name>.rstp.description: Whether the bridge interface should enable rstp.

networking.connman.enable.description: Whether to use ConnMan for managing your network connections.

networking.connman.enableVPN.description: Whether to enable ConnMan VPN service.

networking.connman.extraConfig.description: Configuration lines appended to the generated connman configuration file.

networking.connman.networkInterfaceBlack.description: Default blacklisted interfaces, this includes NixOS containers interfaces (ve).

networking.defaultGateway.description:
The default gateway. It can be left empty if it is auto-detected through DHCP.
It can be specified as a string or an option set along with a network interface.

networking.defaultGateway6.description:
The default ipv6 gateway. It can be left empty if it is auto-detected through DHCP.
It can be specified as a string or an option set along with a network interface.

networking.defaultGatewayWindowSize.description:
The window size of the default gateway. It limits maximal data bursts that TCP peers
are allowed to send to us.

networking.defaultMailServer.authPass.description:
Password used for SMTP auth. (STORED PLAIN TEXT, WORLD-READABLE IN NIX STORE)

It's recommended to use <option>authPassFile</option>
which takes precedence over <option>authPass</option>.

networking.defaultMailServer.authPassFil.description:
Path to a file that contains the password used for SMTP auth. The file
should not contain a trailing newline, if the password does not contain one.
This file should be readable by the users that need to execute ssmtp.

<option>authPassFile</option> takes precedence over <option>authPass</option>.

Warning: when <option>authPass</option> is non-empty <option>authPassFile</option>
defaults to a file in the WORLD-READABLE Nix store containing that password.

networking.defaultMailServer.authUser.description: Username used for SMTP auth. Leave blank to disable.

networking.defaultMailServer.directDeliv.description:
Use the trivial Mail Transfer Agent (MTA)
<command>ssmtp</command> package to allow programs to send
e-mail.  If you don't want to run a real MTA like
<command>sendmail</command> or <command>postfix</command> on
your machine, set this option to <literal>true</literal>, and
set the option
<option>networking.defaultMailServer.hostName</option> to the
host name of your preferred mail server.

networking.defaultMailServer.domain.description: The domain from which mail will appear to be sent.

networking.defaultMailServer.hostName.description:
The host name of the default mail server to use to deliver
e-mail. Can also contain a port number (ex: mail.example.org:587),
defaults to port 25 if no port is given.

networking.defaultMailServer.root.description: The e-mail to which mail for users with UID < 1000 is forwarded.

networking.defaultMailServer.setSendmail.description: Whether to set the system sendmail to ssmtp's.

networking.defaultMailServer.useSTARTTLS.description:
Whether the STARTTLS should be used to connect to the default
mail server.  (This is needed for TLS-capable mail servers
running on the default SMTP port 25.)

networking.defaultMailServer.useTLS.description:
Whether TLS should be used to connect to the default mail
server.

networking.dhcpcd.allowInterfaces.description:
Enable the DHCP client for any interface whose name matches
any of the shell glob patterns in this list. Any interface not
explicitly matched by this pattern will be denied. This pattern only
applies when non-null.

networking.dhcpcd.denyInterfaces.description:
Disable the DHCP client for any interface whose name matches
any of the shell glob patterns in this list. The purpose of
this option is to blacklist virtual interfaces such as those
created by Xen, libvirt, LXC, etc.

networking.dhcpcd.enable.description:
Whether to enable dhcpcd for device configuration. This is mainly to
explicitly disable dhcpcd (for example when using networkd).

networking.dhcpcd.extraConfig.description: Literal string to append to the config file generated for dhcpcd.

networking.dhcpcd.persistent.description:
Whenever to leave interfaces configured on dhcpcd daemon
shutdown. Set to true if you have your root or store mounted
over the network or this machine accepts SSH connections
through DHCP interfaces and clients should be notified when
it shuts down.

networking.dhcpcd.runHook.description:
Shell code that will be run after all other hooks. See
`man dhcpcd-run-hooks` for details on what is possible.
networking.dhcpcd.runHook.example: if [[ $reason =~ BOUND ]]; then echo $interface: Routers are $new_routers - were $old_routers; fi

networking.dnsExtensionMechanism.description: Enable the edns0 option in resolv.conf. With that option set, glibc supports use of the extension mechanisms for DNS (EDNS) specified in RFC 2671. The most popular user of that feature is DNSSEC, which does not work without it.

networking.dnsSingleRequest.description:
Recent versions of glibc will issue both ipv4 (A) and ipv6 (AAAA)
address queries at the same time, from the same port. Sometimes upstream
routers will systemically drop the ipv4 queries. The symptom of this problem is
that 'getent hosts example.com' only returns ipv6 (or perhaps only ipv4) addresses. The
workaround for this is to specify the option 'single-request' in
/etc/resolv.conf. This option enables that.

networking.domain.description: The domain.  It can be left empty if it is auto-detected through DHCP.

networking.enableB43Firmware.description: Turn on this option if you want firmware for the NICs supported by the b43 module.

networking.enableIPv6.description: Whether to enable support for IPv6.

networking.extraHosts.description: Additional verbatim entries to be appended to <filename>/etc/hosts</filename>.

networking.firewall.allowPing.description:
Whether to respond to incoming ICMPv4 echo requests
("pings").  ICMPv6 pings are always allowed because the
larger address space of IPv6 makes network scanning much
less effective.

networking.firewall.allowedTCPPortRanges.description:
A range of TCP ports on which incoming connections are
accepted.
networking.firewall.allowedTCPPortRanges.type: list of attribute set of signed integerss

networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts.description:
List of TCP ports on which incoming connections are
accepted.

networking.firewall.allowedUDPPortRanges.type: list of attribute set of signed integerss

networking.firewall.autoLoadConntrackHel.description:
Whether to auto-load connection-tracking helpers.
See the description at networking.firewall.connectionTrackingModules

(needs kernel 3.5+)

networking.firewall.checkReversePath.description:
Performs a reverse path filter test on a packet.  If a reply
to the packet would not be sent via the same interface that
the packet arrived on, it is refused.

If using asymmetric routing or other complicated routing, set
this option to loose mode or disable it and setup your own
counter-measures.

This option can be either true (or "strict"), "loose" (only
drop the packet if the source address is not reachable via any
interface) or false.  Defaults to the value of
kernelHasRPFilter.

(needs kernel 3.3+)

networking.firewall.connectionTrackingMo.description:
List of connection-tracking helpers that are auto-loaded.
The complete list of possible values is given in the example.

As helpers can pose as a security risk, it is advised to
set this to an empty list and disable the setting
networking.firewall.autoLoadConntrackHelpers unless you
know what you are doing. Connection tracking is disabled
by default.

Loading of helpers is recommended to be done through the
CT target.  More info:
https://home.regit.org/netfilter-en/secure-use-of-helpers/

networking.firewall.enable.description:
Whether to enable the firewall.  This is a simple stateful
firewall that blocks connection attempts to unauthorised TCP
or UDP ports on this machine.  It does not affect packet
forwarding.

networking.firewall.extraCommands.description:
Additional shell commands executed as part of the firewall
initialisation script.  These are executed just before the
final "reject" firewall rule is added, so they can be used
to allow packets that would otherwise be refused.

networking.firewall.extraPackages.description:
Additional packages to be included in the environment of the system
as well as the path of networking.firewall.extraCommands.

networking.firewall.extraStopCommands.description:
Additional shell commands executed as part of the firewall
shutdown script.  These are executed just after the removal
of the NixOS input rule, or if the service enters a failed
state.

networking.firewall.logRefusedConnection.description: Whether to log rejected or dropped incoming connections.

networking.firewall.logRefusedPackets.description:
Whether to log all rejected or dropped incoming packets.
This tends to give a lot of log messages, so it's mostly
useful for debugging.

networking.firewall.logRefusedUnicastsOn.description:
If <option>networking.firewall.logRefusedPackets</option>
and this option are enabled, then only log packets
specifically directed at this machine, i.e., not broadcasts
or multicasts.

networking.firewall.logReversePathDrops.description:
Logs dropped packets failing the reverse path filter test if
the option networking.firewall.checkReversePath is enabled.

networking.firewall.pingLimit.description:
If pings are allowed, this allows setting rate limits
on them.  If non-null, this option should be in the form of
flags like "--limit 1/minute --limit-burst 5"

networking.firewall.rejectPackets.description:
If set, refused packets are rejected rather than dropped
(ignored).  This means that an ICMP "port unreachable" error
message is sent back to the client (or a TCP RST packet in
case of an existing connection).  Rejecting packets makes
port scanning somewhat easier.

networking.firewall.trustedInterfaces.description:
Traffic coming in from these interfaces will be accepted
unconditionally.  Traffic from the loopback (lo) interface
will always be accepted.

networking.hostConf.example:
multi on
reorder on
trim lan

networking.hostId.description:
The 32-bit host ID of the machine, formatted as 8 hexadecimal characters.

You should try to make this ID unique among your machines. You can
generate a random 32-bit ID using the following commands:

<literal>cksum /etc/machine-id | while read c rest; do printf "%x" $c; done</literal>

(this derives it from the machine-id that systemd generates) or

<literal>head -c4 /dev/urandom | od -A none -t x4</literal>

networking.hostName.description:
The name of the machine.  Leave it empty if you want to obtain
it from a DHCP server (if using DHCP).

networking.hosts.description: Locally defined maps of hostnames to IP addresses.
networking.hosts.type: attribute set of list of stringss

networking.interfaces.description:
The configuration for each network interface.  If
<option>networking.useDHCP</option> is true, then every
interface not listed here will be configured using DHCP.
networking.interfaces.type: list or attribute set of submodules

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ip4.description: List of IPv4 addresses that will be statically assigned to the interface.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ip4.*.addr.description:
IPv4 address of the interface.  Leave empty to configure the
interface using DHCP.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ip4.*.pref.description:
Subnet mask of the interface, specified as the number of
bits in the prefix (<literal>24</literal>).

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ip6.description: List of IPv6 addresses that will be statically assigned to the interface.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ip6.*.addr.description:
IPv6 address of the interface.  Leave empty to configure the
interface using DHCP.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ip6.*.pref.description:
Subnet mask of the interface, specified as the number of
bits in the prefix (<literal>64</literal>).

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ipAddress.description:
IP address of the interface.  Leave empty to configure the
interface using DHCP.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ipv6Addres.description:
IPv6 address of the interface.  Leave empty to configure the
interface using NDP.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.ipv6Prefix.description:
Subnet mask of the interface, specified as the number of
bits in the prefix (<literal>64</literal>).

networking.interfaces.<name?>.macAddress.description: MAC address of the interface. Leave empty to use the default.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.mtu.description: MTU size for packets leaving the interface. Leave empty to use the default.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.prefixLeng.description:
Subnet mask of the interface, specified as the number of
bits in the prefix (<literal>24</literal>).

networking.interfaces.<name?>.proxyARP.description:
Turn on proxy_arp for this device (and proxy_ndp for ipv6).
This is mainly useful for creating pseudo-bridges between a real
interface and a virtual network such as VPN or a virtual machine for
interfaces that don't support real bridging (most wlan interfaces).
As ARP proxying acts slightly above the link-layer, below-ip traffic
isn't bridged, so things like DHCP won't work. The advantage above
using NAT lies in the fact that no IP addresses are shared, so all
hosts are reachable/routeable.

WARNING: turns on ip-routing, so if you have multiple interfaces, you
should think of the consequence and setup firewall rules to limit this.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.subnetMask.description: Defunct, supply the prefix length instead.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.useDHCP.description:
Whether this interface should be configured with dhcp.
Null implies the old behavior which depends on whether ip addresses
are specified or not.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.virtual.description:
Whether this interface is virtual and should be created by tunctl.
This is mainly useful for creating bridges between a host and a virtual
network such as VPN or a virtual machine.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.virtualOwn.description: In case of a virtual device, the user who owns it.

networking.interfaces.<name?>.virtualTyp.description:
The explicit type of interface to create. Accepts tun or tap strings.
Also accepts null to implicitly detect the type of device.

networking.localCommands.description:
Shell commands to be executed at the end of the
<literal>network-setup</literal> systemd service.  Note that if
you are using DHCP to obtain the network configuration,
interfaces may not be fully configured yet.
networking.localCommands.example: text=anything; echo You can put $text here.

networking.macvlans.description:
This option allows you to define macvlan interfaces which should
be automatically created.

networking.macvlans.<name>.interface.description: The interface the macvlan will transmit packets through.

networking.macvlans.<name>.mode.description: The mode of the macvlan device.

networking.nameservers.description: The list of nameservers.  It can be left empty if it is auto-detected through DHCP.

networking.nat.enable.description: Whether to enable Network Address Translation (NAT).

networking.nat.externalIP.description:
The public IP address to which packets from the local
network are to be rewritten.  If this is left empty, the
IP address associated with the external interface will be
used.

networking.nat.externalInterface.description: The name of the external network interface.

networking.nat.forwardPorts.description:
List of forwarded ports from the external interface to
internal destinations by using DNAT.

networking.nat.forwardPorts.*.sourcePort.description: Source port of the external interface

networking.nat.internalIPs.description:
The IP address ranges for which to perform NAT.  Packets
coming from these addresses (on any interface) and destined
for the external interface will be rewritten.

networking.nat.internalInterfaces.description:
The interfaces for which to perform NAT. Packets coming from
these interface and destined for the external interface will
be rewritten.

networking.networkmanager.appendNameserv.description:
A list of name servers that should be appended
to the ones configured in NetworkManager or received by DHCP.

networking.networkmanager.dhcp.description: Which program (or internal library) should be used for DHCP.

networking.networkmanager.dispatcherScri.description: A list of scripts which will be executed in response to  network  events.
Dispatcher hook type. Only basic hooks are currently available.

networking.networkmanager.enable.description:
Whether to use NetworkManager to obtain an IP address and other
configuration for all network interfaces that are not manually
configured. If enabled, a group <literal>networkmanager</literal>
will be created. Add all users that should have permission
to change network settings to this group.

networking.networkmanager.ethernet.macAd.description:
"XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:XX": MAC address of the interface.
<literal>permanent</literal>: use the permanent MAC address of the device.
<literal>preserve</literal>: dont change the MAC address of the device upon activation.
