services.confluence.home.description: Home directory of the confluence instance.

services.confluence.jrePackage.description: Java Runtime to use for Confluence. Note that Atlassian recommends the Oracle JRE.

services.confluence.sso.applicationName.description: Exact name of this Confluence instance in Crowd

services.confluence.sso.applicationPassw.description: Application password of this Confluence instance in Crowd

services.confluence.sso.crowd.description: Crowd Base URL without trailing slash

services.confluence.sso.enable.description: Whether to enable SSO with Atlassian Crowd.

services.confluence.sso.validationInterv.description:
Set to 0, if you want authentication checks to occur on each
request. Otherwise set to the number of minutes between request
to validate if the user is logged in or out of the Crowd SSO
server. Setting this value to 1 or higher will increase the
performance of Crowd's integration.

services.consul.dropPrivileges.description: Whether the consul agent should be run as a non-root consul user.

services.consul.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration options which are serialized to json and added
to the config.json file.

services.consul.extraConfigFiles.description:
Additional configuration files to pass to consul
NOTE: These will not trigger the service to be restarted when altered.

services.consul.forceIpv4.description: Whether we should force the interfaces to only pull ipv4 addresses.

services.consul.interface.advertise.description: The name of the interface to pull the advertise_addr from.

services.consul.interface.bind.description: The name of the interface to pull the bind_addr from.

services.consul.leaveOnStop.description:
If enabled, causes a leave action to be sent when closing consul.
This allows a clean termination of the node, but permanently removes
it from the cluster. You probably don't want this option unless you
are running a node which going offline in a permanent / semi-permanent
fashion.

services.consul.package.description: The package used for the Consul agent and CLI.

services.consul.webUi.description: Enables the web interface on the consul http port.

services.coturn.alt-listening-port.description:
Alternative listening port for UDP and TCP listeners;
default (or zero) value means "listening port plus one".
This is needed for RFC 5780 support
(STUN extension specs, NAT behavior discovery). The TURN Server
supports RFC 5780 only if it is started with more than one
listening IP address of the same family (IPv4 or IPv6).
RFC 5780 is supported only by UDP protocol, other protocols
are listening to that endpoint only for "symmetry".

services.coturn.alt-tls-listening-port.description: Alternative listening port for TLS and DTLS protocols.

services.coturn.cli-ip.description: Local system IP address to be used for CLI server endpoint.

services.coturn.cli-password.description:
CLI access password.
For the security reasons, it is recommended to use the encrypted
for of the password (see the -P command in the turnadmin utility).

services.coturn.dh-file.description: Use custom DH TLS key, stored in PEM format in the file.

services.coturn.enable.description: Whether to enable coturn TURN server.

services.coturn.listening-ips.description:
Listener IP addresses of relay server.
If no IP(s) specified in the config file or in the command line options,
then all IPv4 and IPv6 system IPs will be used for listening.

services.coturn.listening-port.description:
TURN listener port for UDP and TCP.
Note: actually, TLS and DTLS sessions can connect to the
"plain" TCP and UDP port(s), too - if allowed by configuration.

services.coturn.max-port.description: Upper bound of UDP relay endpoints

services.coturn.min-port.description: Lower bound of UDP relay endpoints

services.coturn.no-auth.description:
This option is opposite to lt-cred-mech.
(TURN Server with no-auth option allows anonymous access).
If neither option is defined, and no users are defined,
then no-auth is default. If at least one user is defined,
in this file or in command line or in usersdb file, then
lt-cred-mech is default.

services.coturn.pkey.description: Private key file in PEM format.

services.coturn.realm.description:
The default realm to be used for the users when no explicit
origin/realm relationship was found in the database, or if the TURN
server is not using any database (just the commands-line settings
and the userdb file). Must be used with long-term credentials
mechanism or with TURN REST API.

services.coturn.relay-ips.description:
Relay address (the local IP address that will be used to relay the
packets to the peer).
Multiple relay addresses may be used.
The same IP(s) can be used as both listening IP(s) and relay IP(s).

If no relay IP(s) specified, then the turnserver will apply the default
policy: it will decide itself which relay addresses to be used, and it
will always be using the client socket IP address as the relay IP address
of the TURN session (if the requested relay address family is the same
as the family of the client socket).

services.coturn.secure-stun.description:
Require authentication of the STUN Binding request.
By default, the clients are allowed anonymous access to the STUN Binding functionality.

services.coturn.static-auth-secret.description:
'Static' authentication secret value (a string) for TURN REST API only.
If not set, then the turn server
will try to use the 'dynamic' value in turn_secret table
in user database (if present). The database-stored  value can be changed on-the-fly
by a separate program, so this is why that other mode is 'dynamic'.

services.coturn.tls-listening-port.description:
TURN listener port for TLS.
Note: actually, "plain" TCP and UDP sessions can connect to the TLS and
DTLS port(s), too - if allowed by configuration. The TURN server
"automatically" recognizes the type of traffic. Actually, two listening
endpoints (the "plain" one and the "tls" one) are equivalent in terms of
functionality; but we keep both endpoints to satisfy the RFC 5766 specs.
For secure TCP connections, we currently support SSL version 3 and
TLS version 1.0, 1.1 and 1.2.
For secure UDP connections, we support DTLS version 1.

services.coturn.use-auth-secret.description:
TURN REST API flag.
Flag that sets a special authorization option that is based upon authentication secret.
This feature can be used with the long-term authentication mechanism, only.
This feature purpose is to support "TURN Server REST API", see
"TURN REST API" link in the project's page
https://github.com/coturn/coturn/

This option is used with timestamp:

usercombo -> "timestamp:userid"
turn user -> usercombo
turn password -> base64(hmac(secret key, usercombo))

This allows TURN credentials to be accounted for a specific user id.
If you don't have a suitable id, the timestamp alone can be used.
This option is just turning on secret-based authentication.
The actual value of the secret is defined either by option static-auth-secret,
or can be found in the turn_secret table in the database.

services.couchdb.bindAddress.description: Defines the IP address by which CouchDB will be accessible.

services.couchdb.configFile.description:
Configuration file for persisting runtime changes. File
needs to be readable and writable from couchdb user/group.

services.couchdb.databaseDir.description:
Specifies location of CouchDB database files (*.couch named). This
location should be writable and readable for the user the CouchDB
service runs as (couchdb by default).

services.couchdb.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration. Overrides any other cofiguration.

services.couchdb.group.description: Group account under which couchdb runs.

services.couchdb.logFile.description: Specifies the location of file for logging output.

services.couchdb.port.description: Defined the port number to listen.

services.couchdb.uriFile.description:
This file contains the full URI that can be used to access this
instance of CouchDB. It is used to help discover the port CouchDB is
running on (if it was set to 0 (e.g. automatically assigned any free
one). This file should be writable and readable for the user that
runs the CouchDB service (couchdb by default).

services.couchdb.user.description: User account under which couchdb runs.

services.couchdb.viewIndexDir.description:
Specifies location of CouchDB view index files. This location should
be writable and readable for the user that runs the CouchDB service
(couchdb by default).

services.cpuminer-cryptonight.enable.description: Whether to enable the cpuminer cryptonight miner.

services.cpuminer-cryptonight.threads.description: Number of miner threads, defaults to available processors

services.cron.cronFiles.description:
A list of extra crontab files that will be read and appended to the main
crontab file when the cron service starts.

services.cron.enable.description: Whether to enable the Vixie cron daemon.

services.cron.mailto.description: Email address to which job output will be mailed.

services.cron.systemCronJobs.description:
A list of Cron jobs to be appended to the system-wide
crontab.  See the manual page for crontab for the expected
format. If you want to get the results mailed you must setuid
sendmail. See <option>security.wrappers</option>

If neither /var/cron/cron.deny nor /var/cron/cron.allow exist only root
will is allowed to have its own crontab file. The /var/cron/cron.deny file
is created automatically for you. So every user can use a crontab.

Many nixos modules set systemCronJobs, so if you decide to disable vixie cron
and enable another cron daemon, you may want it to get its system crontab
based on systemCronJobs.

services.crowd.catalinaOptions.description: Java options to pass to catalina/tomcat.

services.crowd.enable.description: Whether to enable Atlassian Crowd service.

services.crowd.home.description: Home directory of the Crowd instance.

services.crowd.jrePackage.description: Java Runtime to use for Crowd. Note that Atlassian recommends the Oracle JRE.

services.crowd.proxy.enable.description: Whether to enable reverse proxy support.

services.crowd.proxy.secure.description: Whether the connections to the proxy should be considered secure.

services.dante.config.description:

services.dbus.packages.description:
Packages whose D-Bus configuration files should be included in
the configuration of the D-Bus system-wide or session-wide
message bus.  Specifically, files in the following directories
will be included into their respective DBus configuration paths:
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/etc/dbus-1/system.d</filename>
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/share/dbus-1/system-services</filename>
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/etc/dbus-1/session.d</filename>
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/share/dbus-1/services</filename>

services.dbus.socketActivated.description: Make the user instance socket activated.

services.dd-agent.api_key.description: The Datadog API key to associate the agent with your account

services.dd-agent.enable.description: Whether to enable the dd-agent montioring service

services.dd-agent.hostname.description: The hostname to show in the Datadog dashboard (optional)

services.dd-agent.tags.description: The tags to mark this Datadog agent

services.ddclient.configFile.description:
Path to configuration file.
When set to the default '/etc/ddclient.conf' it will be populated with the various other options in this module. When it is changed (for example: '/root/nixos/secrets/ddclient.conf') the file read directly to configure ddclient. This is a source of impurity.
The purpose of this is to avoid placing secrets into the store.

services.ddclient.enable.description: Whether to synchronise your machine's IP address with a dynamic DNS provider (e.g. dyndns.org).

services.ddclient.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the configuration file.

services.ddclient.homeDir.description: Home directory for the daemon user.

services.ddclient.interval.description: The interval at which to run the check and update.

services.ddclient.password.description: Password. WARNING: The password becomes world readable in the Nix store.

services.ddclient.protocol.description: Protocol to use with dynamic DNS provider (see http://sourceforge.net/apps/trac/ddclient/wiki/Protocols).

services.ddclient.quiet.description: Print no messages for unnecessary updates.

services.ddclient.ssl.description: Whether to use to use SSL/TLS to connect to dynamic DNS provider.

services.ddclient.use.description: Method to determine the IP address to send to the dynamic DNS provider.

services.deluge.openFilesLimit.description: Number of files to allow deluged to open.

services.devmon.enable.description: Whether to enable devmon, an automatic device mounting daemon.

The path of the DHCP server configuration file.  If no file
is specified, a file is generated using the other options.

services.dhcpd4.enable.description: Whether to enable the DHCPv4 server.

services.dhcpd4.extraConfig.description:
Extra text to be appended to the DHCP server configuration
file. Currently, you almost certainly need to specify something
there, such as the options specifying the subnet mask, DNS servers,
etc.

services.dhcpd4.extraFlags.description: Additional command line flags to be passed to the dhcpd daemon.

services.dhcpd4.interfaces.description: The interfaces on which the DHCP server should listen.

services.dhcpd4.machines.description:
A list mapping Ethernet addresses to IPv4 addresses for the
DHCP server.

services.dhcpd4.machines.*.hostName.description: Hostname which is assigned statically to the machine.

services.dhcpd4.stateDir.description: State directory for the DHCP server.

services.dhcpd6.configFile.description:
The path of the DHCP server configuration file.  If no file
is specified, a file is generated using the other options.

services.dhcpd6.enable.description: Whether to enable the DHCPv6 server.

services.dhcpd6.extraConfig.description:
Extra text to be appended to the DHCP server configuration
file. Currently, you almost certainly need to specify something
there, such as the options specifying the subnet mask, DNS servers,
etc.

services.dhcpd6.extraFlags.description: Additional command line flags to be passed to the dhcpd daemon.

services.dhcpd6.interfaces.description: The interfaces on which the DHCP server should listen.

services.dhcpd6.machines.description:
A list mapping Ethernet addresses to IPv6 addresses for the
DHCP server.

services.dhcpd6.machines.*.hostName.description: Hostname which is assigned statically to the machine.

services.dhcpd6.stateDir.description: State directory for the DHCP server.

services.dictd.DBs.description: List of databases to make available.

services.dictd.enable.description: Whether to enable the DICT.org dictionary server.

services.diod.allsquash.description:
Remap all users to "nobody". The attaching user need not be present in the
password file.

services.diod.authRequired.description: Allow clients to connect without authentication, i.e. without a valid MUNGE credential.

services.diod.enable.description: Whether to enable the diod 9P file server.

services.diod.exportall.description:
Export all file systems listed in /proc/mounts. If new file systems are mounted
after diod has started, they will become immediately mountable. If there is a
duplicate entry for a file system in the exports list, any options listed in
the exports entry will apply.

services.diod.exportopts.description:
Establish a default set of export options. These are overridden, not appended
to, by opts attributes in an "exports" entry.

services.diod.exports.description:
List the file systems that clients will be allowed to mount. All paths should
be fully qualified. The exports table can include two types of element:
a string element (as above),
or an alternate table element form { path="/path", opts="ro" }.
In the alternate form, the (optional) opts attribute is a comma-separated list
of export options. The two table element forms can be mixed in the exports
table. Note that although diod will not traverse file system boundaries for a
given mount due to inode uniqueness constraints, subdirectories of a file
system can be separately exported.

services.diod.listen.description:
[ "IP:PORT" [,"IP:PORT",...] ]
List the interfaces and ports that diod should listen on.

services.diod.logdest.description:
Set the destination for logging.
The value has the form of "syslog:facility:level" or "filename".

services.diod.nwthreads.description:
Sets the (fixed) number of worker threads created to handle 9P
requests for a unique aname.

services.diod.squashuser.description: Change the squash user. The squash user must be present in the password file.

services.diod.statfsPassthru.description:
This option configures statfs to return the host file system's type
rather than V9FS_MAGIC.

services.diod.userdb.description:
This option disables password/group lookups. It allows any uid to attach and
assumes gid=uid, and supplementary groups contain only the primary gid.

services.disnix.useWebServiceInterface.description: Whether to enable the DisnixWebService interface running on Apache Tomcat

services.dnscache.clientIps.description: client IP addresses (or prefixes) from which to accept connections

services.dnscache.domainServers.description: table of {hostname: server} pairs to use as authoritative servers for hosts (and subhosts)
services.dnscache.domainServers.type: attribute set of list of stringss

services.dnscache.enable.description: Whether to run the dnscache caching dns server

services.dnscache.ip.description: IP address on which to listen for connections

services.dnschain.api.hostname.description: The hostname (or IP address) the DNSChain API server will bind to.

services.dnschain.api.port.description: The port the DNSChain API server (HTTP) will bind to.

services.dnschain.api.tlsPort.description: The port the DNSChain API server (HTTPS) will bind to.

services.dnschain.dns.address.description:
The IP address the DNSChain resolver will bind to.
Leave this unchanged if you do not wish to directly expose the resolver.

services.dnschain.dns.externalAddress.description:
The IP address used by clients to reach the resolver and the value of
the <literal>namecoin.dns</literal> record. Set this in case the bind address
is not the actual IP address (e.g. the machine is behind a NAT).

services.dnschain.dns.port.description: The port the DNSChain resolver will bind to.

services.dnschain.enable.description:
Whether to enable DNSChain, a blockchain based DNS + HTTP server.
To resolve .bit domains set <literal>services.namecoind.enable = true;</literal>
and an RPC username/password.
.

services.dnschain.extraConfig.description: Additional options that will be appended to the configuration file.

services.dnscrypt-proxy.customResolver.description:
Use an unlisted resolver (e.g., a private DNSCrypt provider). For
advanced users only. If specified, this option takes precedence.

services.dnscrypt-proxy.enable.description: Whether to enable the DNSCrypt client proxy

services.dnscrypt-proxy.extraArgs.description:
Additional command-line arguments passed verbatim to the daemon.
See <citerefentry><refentrytitle>dnscrypt-proxy</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry> for details.

services.dnscrypt-proxy.localAddress.description:
Listen for DNS queries to relay on this address. The only reason to
change this from its default value is to proxy queries on behalf
of other machines (typically on the local network).

services.dnscrypt-proxy.localPort.description:
Listen for DNS queries to relay on this port. The default value
assumes that the DNSCrypt proxy should relay DNS queries directly.
When running as a forwarder for another DNS client, set this option
to a different value; otherwise leave the default.

services.dnscrypt-proxy.resolverName.description:
The name of the DNSCrypt resolver to use, taken from
<filename>/var/lib/dnscrypt-proxy/dnscrypt-resolvers.csv</filename>.  The default is to
pick a random non-logging resolver that supports DNSSEC.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.address.description: The DNSCrypt wrapper will bind to this IP address.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.keys.checkInte.description: The time interval (in minutes) between key expiration checks.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.keys.expiratio.description:
The duration (in days) of the time-limited secret key.
This will be automatically rotated before expiration.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.port.description: The DNSCrypt wrapper will listen for DNS queries on this port.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.providerName.description:
The name that will be given to this DNSCrypt resolver.
Note: the resolver name must start with <literal>2.dnscrypt-cert.</literal>.

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.upstream.addre.description: The IP address of the upstream DNS server DNSCrypt will "wrap".

services.dnscrypt-wrapper.upstream.port.description: The port of the upstream DNS server DNSCrypt will "wrap".

services.dnsmasq.alwaysKeepRunning.description: If enabled, systemd will always respawn dnsmasq even if shut down manually. The default, disabled, will only restart it on error.

services.dnsmasq.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration directives that should be added to
<literal>dnsmasq.conf</literal>.

services.dnsmasq.resolveDNSChainQueries.description: Resolve <literal>.bit</literal> top-level domains using DNSChain and namecoin.

services.dnsmasq.resolveLocalQueries.description:
Whether dnsmasq should resolve local queries (i.e. add 127.0.0.1 to
/etc/resolv.conf).

services.dnsmasq.servers.description: The DNS servers which dnsmasq should query.

services.dockerRegistry.extraConfig.description: Docker extra registry configuration via environment variables.

services.dockerRegistry.listenAddress.description: Docker registry host or ip to bind to.

services.dockerRegistry.port.description: Docker registry port to bind to.

services.dovecot2.configFile.description: Config file used for the whole dovecot configuration.

services.dovecot2.createMailUser.description:
Whether to automatically create the user
        given in <option>services.dovecot.user</option> and the group
        given in <option>services.dovecot.group</option>.

services.dovecot2.enable.description: Whether to enable Dovecot 2.x POP3/IMAP server.

services.dovecot2.enableImap.description: Start the IMAP listener (when Dovecot is enabled).

services.dovecot2.enableLmtp.description: Start the LMTP listener (when Dovecot is enabled).

services.dovecot2.enablePAM.description: Whether to create a own Dovecot PAM service and configure PAM user logins.

services.dovecot2.enablePop3.description: Start the POP3 listener (when Dovecot is enabled).

services.dovecot2.enableQuota.description: Whether to enable the dovecot quota service.

services.dovecot2.extraConfig.description: Additional entries to put verbatim into Dovecot's config file.

services.dovecot2.mailGroup.description: Default group to store mail for virtual users.

services.dovecot2.mailLocation.description: Location that dovecot will use for mail folders. Dovecot mail_location option.

services.dovecot2.mailUser.description: Default user to store mail for virtual users.

services.dovecot2.mailboxes.description: Configure mailboxes and auto create or subscribe them.

services.dovecot2.mailboxes.*.auto.description: Whether to automatically create or create and subscribe to the mailbox or not.

services.dovecot2.mailboxes.*.specialUse.description: Null if no special use flag is set. Other than that every use flag mentioned in the RFC is valid.

services.dovecot2.modules.description:
Symlinks the contents of lib/dovecot of every given package into
/etc/dovecot/modules. This will make the given modules available
if a dovecot package with the module_dir patch applied is being used.

services.dovecot2.protocols.description: Additional listeners to start when Dovecot is enabled.

services.dovecot2.quotaGlobalPerUser.description: Quota limit for the user in bytes. Supports suffixes b, k, M, G, T and %.

services.dovecot2.quotaPort.description:
The Port the dovecot quota service binds to.
If using postfix, add check_policy_service inet:localhost:12340 to your smtpd_recipient_restrictions in your postfix config.

services.dovecot2.showPAMFailure.description: Show the PAM failure message on authentication error (useful for OTPW).

services.dovecot2.sieveScripts.description: Sieve scripts to be executed. Key is a sequence, e.g. 'before2', 'after' etc.

services.dovecot2.sslCACert.description: Path to the server's CA certificate key.

services.dovecot2.sslServerCert.description: Path to the server's public key.

services.dovecot2.sslServerKey.description: Path to the server's private key.

services.drbd.enable.description:
Whether to enable support for DRBD, the Distributed Replicated
Block Device.

services.dspam.domainSocket.description: Path to local domain socket which is used for communication with the daemon. Set to null to disable UNIX socket.

services.dspam.enable.description: Whether to enable the dspam spam filter.

services.dspam.maintenanceInterval.description: If set, maintenance script will be run at specified (in systemd.timer format) interval

services.dspam.storageDriver.description: Storage driver backend to use for dspam.

services.earlyoom.enable.description: Enable early out of memory killing.

services.earlyoom.freeMemThreshold.description:
Minimum of availabe memory (in percent).
If the free memory falls below this threshold and the analog is true for
<option>services.earlyoom.freeSwapThreshold</option>
the killing begins.

services.earlyoom.freeSwapThreshold.description:
Minimum of availabe swap space (in percent).
If the available swap space falls below this threshold and the analog
is true for <option>services.earlyoom.freeMemThreshold</option>
the killing begins.

services.earlyoom.ignoreOOMScoreAdjust.description:
Ignore oom_score_adjust values of processes.
User-space implementation only.

services.earlyoom.useKernelOOMKiller.description: Use kernel OOM killer instead of own user-space implementation.

services.ecs-agent.enable.description: Whether to enable Amazon ECS agent.

services.ecs-agent.extra-environment.description: The environment the ECS agent should run with. See the ECS agent documentation for keys that work here.

services.ecs-agent.package.description: The ECS agent package to use

services.ejabberd.configFile.description: Configuration file for ejabberd in YAML format

services.ejabberd.group.description: Group under which ejabberd is ran

services.ejabberd.imagemagick.description: Add ImageMagick to server's path; allows for image thumbnailing

services.ejabberd.loadDumps.description: Configuration dumps that should be loaded on the first startup

services.ejabberd.logsDir.description: Location of the logfile directory of ejabberd

services.ejabberd.spoolDir.description: Location of the spooldir of ejabberd

services.ejabberd.user.description: User under which ejabberd is ran

services.elasticsearch.cluster_name.description: Elasticsearch name that identifies your cluster for auto-discovery.

services.elasticsearch.extraCmdLineOptio.description: Extra command line options for the elasticsearch launcher.

services.elasticsearch.extraConf.example:
node.name: "elasticsearch"
node.master: true
node.data: false
index.number_of_shards: 5
index.number_of_replicas: 1

services.elasticsearch.extraJavaOptions.description: Extra command line options for Java.

services.elasticsearch.logging.default:
rootLogger: INFO, console
logger:
  action: INFO
  com.amazonaws: WARN
appender:
  console:
    type: console
    layout:
      type: consolePattern
      conversionPattern: "[%d{ISO8601}][%-5p][%-25c] %m%n"

services.elasticsearch.port.description: Elasticsearch port to listen for HTTP traffic.

services.emacs.defaultEditor.description:
When enabled, configures emacsclient to be the default editor
using the EDITOR environment variable.

services.emacs.enable.description:
Whether to enable a user service for the Emacs daemon. Use <literal>emacsclient</literal> to connect to the
daemon. If <literal>true</literal>, <varname>services.emacs.install</varname> is
considered <literal>true</literal>, whatever its value.

Whether to install a user service for the Emacs daemon. Once
the service is started, use emacsclient to connect to the
daemon.

The service must be manually started for each user with
"systemctl --user start emacs" or globally through
<varname>services.emacs.enable</varname>.

so as to enable complete ensemble management.

Optional credentials to use for s3backup or s3config. Argument is the path

services.exhibitor.servo.description:
ZooKeeper will be queried once a minute for its state via the 'mntr' four
letter word (this requires ZooKeeper 3.4.x+). Servo will be used to publish
this data via JMX.

services.exhibitor.zkConfigExhibitorPort.description:
If the ZooKeeper shared config is also running Exhibitor, the port that
Exhibitor is listening on. IMPORTANT: if this value is not set it implies
that Exhibitor is not being used on the ZooKeeper shared config.

services.exhibitor.zkConfigPollMs.description: The period in ms to check for changes in the config ensemble

services.exhibitor.zkConfigRetry.retryQu.description: Retries connecting to the ZooKeeper config

services.exhibitor.zkConfigRetry.sleepMs.description: Retry sleep time connecting to the ZooKeeper config

services.exhibitor.zkConfigZPath.description: The base ZPath that Exhibitor should use

services.exhibitor.zkElectionPort.description: The port for Zookeepers to use for leader election.

services.exhibitor.zkExtraCfg.description: Extra options to pass into Zookeeper

services.exhibitor.zkServersSpec.description: Zookeeper server spec for all servers in the ensemble.

services.exim.config.description:
Verbatim Exim configuration.  This should not contain exim_user,
exim_group, exim_path, or spool_directory.

services.exim.enable.description: Whether to enable the Exim mail transfer agent.

services.exim.group.description: Group to use when no root privileges are required.

services.exim.spoolDir.description: Location of the spool directory of exim.

services.exim.user.description:
User to use when no root privileges are required.
In particular, this applies when receiving messages and when doing
remote deliveries.  (Local deliveries run as various non-root users,
typically as the owner of a local mailbox.) Specifying this value
as root is not supported.

services.factorio.configFile.description:
The server's configuration file.

The default file generated by this module contains lines essential to
the server's operation. Use its contents as a basis for any
customizations.

services.factorio.description.description: Description of the game that will appear in the listing.

services.factorio.game-name.description: Name of the game as it will appear in the game listing.

services.factorio.lan.description: Game will be broadcast on LAN.

services.factorio.mods.description:
Mods the server should install and activate.

The derivations in this list must "build" the mod by simply copying
the .zip, named correctly, into the output directory. Eventually,
there will be a way to pull in the most up-to-date list of
derivations via nixos-channel. Until then, this is for experts only.

services.factorio.password.description: Your factorio.com login credentials. Required for games with visibility public.

services.factorio.port.description:
The port to which the service should bind.

This option will also open up the UDP port in the firewall configuration.

services.factorio.public.description: Game will be published on the official Factorio matching server.

services.factorio.saveName.description:
The name of the savegame that will be used by the server.

When not present in /var/lib/factorio/saves, a new map with default
settings will be generated before starting the service.

services.factorio.token.description: Authentication token. May be used instead of 'password' above.

services.factorio.username.description: Your factorio.com login credentials. Required for games with visibility public.

services.fail2ban.daemonConfig.default:
[Definition]
loglevel  = INFO
logtarget = SYSLOG
socket    = /run/fail2ban/fail2ban.sock
pidfile   = /run/fail2ban/fail2ban.pid
services.fail2ban.daemonConfig.description:
The contents of Fail2ban's main configuration file.  It's
generally not necessary to change it.

services.fail2ban.enable.description: Whether to enable the fail2ban service.

services.fail2ban.jails.description:
The configuration of each Fail2ban jail.  A jail
consists of an action (such as blocking a port using
<command>iptables</command>) that is triggered when a
filter applied to a log file triggers more than a certain
number of times in a certain time period.  Actions are
defined in <filename>/etc/fail2ban/action.d</filename>,
while filters are defined in
<filename>/etc/fail2ban/filter.d</filename>.

example.text:
{ apache-nohome-iptables = ''
    # Block an IP address if it accesses a non-existent
    # home directory more than 5 times in 10 minutes,
    # since that indicates that it's scanning.
    filter   = apache-nohome
    action   = iptables-multiport[name=HTTP, port="http,https"]
    logpath  = /var/log/httpd/error_log*
    findtime = 600
    bantime  = 600
    maxretry = 5
  '';
}

services.fakeroute.enable.description: Whether to enable the fakeroute service.

services.fakeroute.route.description:
Fake route that will appear after the real
one to any host running a traceroute.

services.fcgiwrap.enable.description: Whether to enable fcgiwrap, a server for running CGI applications over FastCGI.

services.fcgiwrap.socketAddress.description: Socket address. In case of a UNIX socket, this should be its filesystem path.

services.fcron.allow.description:
Users allowed to use fcrontab and fcrondyn (one name per
line, <literal>all</literal> for everyone).

services.fcron.maxSerialJobs.description: Maximum number of serial jobs which can run simultaneously.

services.fcron.queuelen.description: Number of jobs the serial queue and the lavg queue can contain.

services.felix.bundles.description: List of bundles that should be activated on startup

services.felix.enable.description: Whether to enable the Apache Felix OSGi service

services.felix.group.description: Group account under which Apache Felix runs.

services.felix.user.description: User account under which Apache Felix runs.

services.ferm.enable.description:
Whether to enable Ferm Firewall.
*Warning*: Enabling this service WILL disable the existing NixOS
firewall! Default firewall rules provided by packages are not
considered at the moment.

services.firebird.baseDir.description:
Location containing data/ and system/ directories.
data/ stores the databases, system/ stores the password database security2.fdb.

services.firebird.enable.description: Whether to enable the Firebird super server.

services.firebird.user.description: User account under which firebird runs.

services.firefox.syncserver.allowNewUser.description:
Whether to allow new-user signups on the server. Only request by
existing accounts will be honored.

services.firefox.syncserver.enable.description:
Whether to enable a Firefox Sync Server, this give the opportunity to
Firefox users to store all synchronized data on their own server. To use this
server, Firefox users should visit the <option>about:config</option>, and
replicate the following change

<screen>
services.sync.tokenServerURI: http://localhost:5000/token/1.0/sync/1.5
</screen>

where <option>http://localhost:5000/</option> corresponds to the
public url of the server.

services.firefox.syncserver.group.description: Group account under which syncserver runs.

services.firefox.syncserver.listen.addre.description: Address on which the sync server listen to.

services.firefox.syncserver.listen.port.description: Port on which the sync server listen to.

services.firefox.syncserver.privateConfi.description:
The private config file is used to extend the generated config with confidential
information, such as the <option>syncserver.sqlUri</option> setting if it contains a
password, and the <option>syncserver.secret</option> setting is used by the server to
generate cryptographically-signed authentication tokens.

If this file does not exists, then it is created with a generated
<option>syncserver.secret</option> settings.

services.firefox.syncserver.publicUrl.description: Public URL with which firefox users can use to access the sync server.

services.firefox.syncserver.sqlUri.description:
The location of the database. This URL is composed of
<option>dialect[+driver]://user:password@host/dbname[?key=value..]</option>,
where <option>dialect</option> is a database name such as
<option>mysql</option>, <option>oracle</option>, <option>postgresql</option>,
etc., and <option>driver</option> the name of a DBAPI, such as
<option>psycopg2</option>, <option>pyodbc</option>, <option>cx_oracle</option>,
etc. The <link
xlink:href="http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/core/engines.html#database-urls">
SQLAlchemy documentation</link> provides more examples and describe the syntax of
the expected URL.

services.firefox.syncserver.user.description: User account under which syncserver runs.

services.fireqos.config.example:
interface wlp3s0 world-in input rate 10mbit ethernet
  class web commit 50kbit
    match tcp ports 80,443

interface wlp3s0 world-out input rate 10mbit ethernet
  class web commit 50kbit
    match tcp ports 80,443

services.fireqos.enable.description:
If enabled, FireQOS will be launched with the specified
configuration given in `config`.

services.flannel.backend.description: Type of backend to use and specific configurations for that backend.

services.flannel.iface.description:
Interface to use (IP or name) for inter-host communication.
Defaults to the interface for the default route on the machine.

services.flannel.network.description: IPv4 network in CIDR format to use for the entire flannel network.

services.flannel.publicIp.description:
IP accessible by other nodes for inter-host communication.
Defaults to the IP of the interface being used for communication.

services.flannel.subnetLen.description:
The size of the subnet allocated to each host. Defaults to 24 (i.e. /24)
unless the Network was configured to be smaller than a /24 in which case
it is one less than the network.

services.flannel.subnetMax.description:
The end of IP range which the subnet allocation should start with.
Defaults to the last subnet of Network.

services.flannel.subnetMin.description:
The beginning of IP range which the subnet allocation should start with.
Defaults to the first subnet of Network.

services.flashpolicyd.enable.description:
Whether to enable the Flash Policy server.  This is
necessary if you want Flash applications to make
connections to your server.

services.flashpolicyd.policy.description: The policy to be served.  The default is to allow connections from any domain to any port.

services.fleet.etcdCafile.description:
Fleet TLS ca file when SSL certificate authentication is enabled
in etcd endpoints.

services.fleet.etcdCertfile.description:
Fleet TLS cert file when SSL certificate authentication is enabled
in etcd endpoints.

services.fleet.etcdKeyfile.description:
Fleet TLS key file when SSL certificate authentication is enabled
in etcd endpoints.

services.fleet.etcdServers.description: Fleet list of etcd endpoints to use.

services.fleet.extraConfig.description:
Fleet extra config. See
<link xlink:href="https://github.com/coreos/fleet/blob/master/Documentation/deployment-and-configuration.md"/>
for configuration options.

services.fleet.metadata.description:
Key/value pairs that are published with the local to the fleet registry.
This data can be used directly by a client of fleet to make scheduling decisions.

services.fleet.publicIp.description:
Fleet IP address that should be published with the local Machine's
state and any socket information. If not set, fleetd will attempt
to detect the IP it should publish based on the machine's IP
routing information.

services.flexget.enable.description: Whether to enable Run FlexGet Daemon.

services.flexget.systemScheduler.description: When true, execute the runs via the flexget-runner.timer. If false, you have to specify the settings yourself in the YML file.

services.flexget.user.description: The user under which to run flexget.

services.fluentd.plugins.description:
A list of plugin paths to pass into fluentd. It will make plugins defined in ruby files
there available in your config.

services.foldingAtHome.config.description:
Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the
configuration file.

services.foldingAtHome.enable.description: Whether to enable the Folding@Home to use idle CPU time.

services.fourStore.database.description: RDF database name. If it doesn't exist, it will be created. Databases are stored in /var/lib/4store.

services.fourStore.enable.description: Whether to enable 4Store RDF database server.

services.fourStore.options.description: Extra CLI options to pass to 4Store.

services.fourStoreEndpoint.database.description: RDF database name to expose via the endpoint. Defaults to local 4Store database name.

services.fourStoreEndpoint.options.description: Extra CLI options to pass to 4Store's 4s-httpd process.

services.fprintd.enable.description: Whether to enable fprintd daemon and PAM module for fingerprint readers handling.

services.fprot.updater.enable.description: Whether to enable automatic F-Prot virus definitions database updates.

services.fprot.updater.frequency.description: Update virus definitions every X minutes.

services.fprot.updater.licenseKeyfile.description: License keyfile. Defaults to the one supplied with installation package.

services.fprot.updater.productData.description: product.data file. Defaults to the one supplied with installation package.

services.frab.database.description: Rails database configuration for Frab as Nix attribute set.

services.frab.extraEnvironment.description:
Additional environment variables to set for frab for further
configuration. See the frab documentation for more information.

services.frab.host.description: Hostname under which this frab instance can be reached.

services.frab.listenAddress.description: Address or hostname frab should listen on.

services.frab.protocol.description:
Either http or https, depending on how your Frab instance
will be exposed to the public.

services.frab.secretKeyBase.description:
Your secret key is used for verifying the integrity of signed cookies.
If you change this key, all old signed cookies will become invalid!

Make sure the secret is at least 30 characters and all random,
no regular words or you'll be exposed to dictionary attacks.

services.frab.statePath.description: Directory where frab keeps its state.

services.freefall.devices.description: Device paths to all internal spinning hard drives.

services.freefall.enable.description: Whether to protect HP/Dell laptop hard drives (not SSDs) in free fall.

services.freenet.nice.description: Set the nice level for the Freenet daemon

services.fstrim.enable.description: Whether to enable periodic SSD TRIM of mounted partitions in background.

services.fstrim.interval.description:
How often we run fstrim. For most desktop and server systems
a sufficient trimming frequency is once a week.

The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.fusionInventory.enable.description: Whether to enable Fusion Inventory Agent.

services.fusionInventory.extraConfig.description: Configuration that is injected verbatim into the configuration file.

services.fusionInventory.servers.description: The urls of the OCS/GLPI servers to connect to.

services.gale.domain.description: Domain name for the Gale system.

services.gale.enable.description: Whether to enable the Gale messaging daemon.

services.gale.extraConfig.description: Additional text to be added to <filename>/etc/gale/conf</filename>.

services.gale.group.description: Group name for the Gale daemon.

services.gale.keyPath.description:
Directory containing the key pair for this Gale domain.  The expected
filename will be taken from the domain option with ".gpri" and ".gpub"
appended.

services.gale.setuidWrapper.description: Configuration for the Gale gksign setuid wrapper.

services.gammu-smsd.backend.files.errorS.description: Where SMSes with error in transmission is placed

services.gammu-smsd.backend.files.inboxP.description: Where the received SMSes are stored

services.gammu-smsd.backend.files.outbox.description: Where SMSes to be sent should be placed

services.gammu-smsd.backend.files.sentSM.description: Where the transmitted SMSes are placed

services.gammu-smsd.backend.service.description: Service to use to store sms data.

services.gammu-smsd.backend.sql.database.description: Database name to store sms data

services.gammu-smsd.backend.sql.password.description: User password used for connetion to the database

services.gammu-smsd.backend.sql.sqlDiale.description: SQL dialect to use (odbc driver only)

services.gammu-smsd.backend.sql.user.description: User name used for connection to the database

services.gammu-smsd.device.connection.description: Protocol which will be used to talk to the phone

services.gammu-smsd.device.path.description: Device node or address of the phone

services.gammu-smsd.device.synchronizeTi.description: Whether to set time from computer to the phone during starting connection

services.gammu-smsd.extraConfig.gammu.description: Extra config lines to be added into [gammu] section

services.gammu-smsd.extraConfig.smsd.description: Extra config lines to be added into [smsd] section

services.gammu-smsd.log.file.description: Path to file where information about communication will be stored

services.gammu-smsd.log.format.description: Determines what will be logged to the LogFile

services.gammu-smsd.user.description: User that has access to the device

services.gateone.pidDir.description: Path of pid files for GateOne.

services.gateone.settingsDir.description: Path of configuration files for GateOne.

services.gdomap.enable.description: Whether to enable GNUstep Distributed Objects name server.

services.geoclue2.enable.description:
Whether to enable GeoClue 2 daemon, a DBus service
that provides location information for accessing.

services.geoip-updater.databaseDir.description: Directory that will contain GeoIP databases.

services.geoip-updater.databases.description:
Which GeoIP databases to update. The full URL is https://geolite.maxmind.com/download/geoip/database/ +
<literal>the_database</literal>.

services.geoip-updater.enable.description:
Whether to enable periodic downloading of GeoIP databases from
maxmind.com. You might want to enable this if you, for instance, use
ntopng or Wireshark.

services.geoip-updater.interval.description:
Update the GeoIP databases at this time / interval.
The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.
To prevent load spikes on maxmind.com, the timer interval is
randomized by an additional delay of 3600
seconds. Setting a shorter interval than this is not recommended.

services.ghostOne.enable.description: Enable Ghost-One Warcraft3 game hosting server.

services.ghostOne.language.description: The language of bot messages: English, Spanish, Russian, Serbian or Turkish.

services.ghostOne.mappath.description:
The path to the directory where you keep your map files. GHost One doesn't require
map files but if it has access to them it can send them to players and automatically
calculate most map config values. GHost One will search [bot_mappath + map_localpath]
for the map file (map_localpath is set in each map's config file).

services.ghostOne.war3path.description: The path to your local Warcraft III directory, which must contain war3.exe, storm.dll, and game.dll.

services.gitDaemon.basePath.description:
Remap all the path requests as relative to the given path. For example,
if you set base-path to /srv/git, then if you later try to pull
git://example.com/hello.git, Git daemon will interpret the path as /srv/git/hello.git.

services.gitDaemon.enable.description:
Enable Git daemon, which allows public hosting of git repositories
without any access controls. This is mostly intended for read-only access.

You can allow write access by setting daemon.receivepack configuration
item of the repository to true. This is solely meant for a closed LAN setting
where everybody is friendly.

If you need any access controls, use something else.

services.gitDaemon.exportAll.description:
Publish all directories that look like Git repositories (have the objects
and refs subdirectories), even if they do not have the git-daemon-export-ok file.

If disabled, you need to touch .git/git-daemon-export-ok in each repository
you want the daemon to publish.

Warning: enabling this without a repository whitelist or basePath
publishes every git repository you have.

services.gitDaemon.group.description: Group under which Git daemon would be running.

services.gitDaemon.listenAddress.description: Listen on a specific IP address or hostname.

services.gitDaemon.options.description: Extra configuration options to be passed to Git daemon.

services.gitDaemon.repositories.description:
A whitelist of paths of git repositories, or directories containing repositories
all of which would be published. Paths must not end in "/".

Warning: leaving this empty and enabling exportAll publishes all
repositories in your filesystem or basePath if specified.

services.gitDaemon.user.description: User under which Git daemon would be running.

services.gitea.cookieSecure.description:
Marks session cookies as "secure" as a hint for browsers to only send
them via HTTPS. This option is recommend, if gitea is being served over HTTPS.

services.gitea.database.password.description:
The password corresponding to <option>database.user</option>.
Warning: this is stored in cleartext in the Nix store!
Use <option>database.passwordFile</option> instead.

services.gitea.database.passwordFile.description:
A file containing the password corresponding to
<option>database.user</option>.

services.gitea.database.path.description: Path to the sqlite3 database file.

services.gitea.extraConfig.description: Configuration lines appended to the generated gitea configuration file.

services.gitea.rootUrl.description: Full public URL of gitea server.

services.gitea.staticRootPath.description: Upper level of template and static files path.

services.gitea.useWizard.description: Do not generate a configuration and use gitea' installation wizard instead. The first registered user will be administrator.

services.gitea.user.description: User account under which gitea runs.

services.gitlab-runner.configFile.description:
Configuration file for gitlab-runner.
Use this option in favor of configOptions to avoid placing CI tokens in the nix store.

<option>configFile</option> takes precedence over <option>configOptions</option>.

Warning: Not using <option>configFile</option> will potentially result in secrets
leaking into the WORLD-READABLE nix store.

services.gitlab-runner.configOptions.description:
Configuration for gitlab-runner
<option>configFile</option> will take precedence over this option.

Warning: all Configuration, especially CI token, will be stored in a
WORLD-READABLE file in the Nix Store.

If you want to protect your CI token use <option>configFile</option> instead.

services.gitlab-runner.gracefulTerminati.description:
Finish all remaining jobs before stopping, restarting or reconfiguring.
If not set gitlab-runner will stop immediatly without waiting for jobs to finish,
which will lead to failed builds.

services.gitlab-runner.gracefulTimeout.description: Time to wait until a graceful shutdown is turned into a forceful one.

services.gitlab-runner.packages.description: Packages to add to PATH for the gitlab-runner process.

services.gitlab.extraConfig.description:
Extra options to be merged into config/gitlab.yml as nix
attribute set.

services.gitlab.group.description: Group to run gitlab and all related services.

services.gitlab.host.description: Gitlab host name. Used e.g. for copy-paste URLs.

services.gitlab.https.description: Whether gitlab prints URLs with https as scheme.

services.gitlab.initialRootEmail.description: Initial email address of the root account if this is a new install.

services.gitlab.initialRootPassword.description: Initial password of the root account if this is a new install.

services.gitlab.port.description:
Gitlab server port for copy-paste URLs, e.g. 80 or 443 if you're
service over https.

services.gitlab.secrets.db.description:
The secret is used to encrypt variables in the DB. If
you change or lose this key you will be unable to access variables
stored in database.

Make sure the secret is at least 30 characters and all random,
no regular words or you'll be exposed to dictionary attacks.

services.gitlab.secrets.jws.description:
The secret is used to encrypt session keys. If you change or lose
this key, users will be disconnected.

Make sure the secret is an RSA private key in PEM format. You can
generate one with

openssl genrsa 2048

services.gitlab.secrets.otp.description:
The secret is used to encrypt secrets for OTP tokens. If
you change or lose this key, users which have 2FA enabled for login
won't be able to login anymore.

Make sure the secret is at least 30 characters and all random,
no regular words or you'll be exposed to dictionary attacks.

services.gitlab.secrets.secret.description:
The secret is used to encrypt variables in the DB. If
you change or lose this key you will be unable to access variables
stored in database.

Make sure the secret is at least 30 characters and all random,
no regular words or you'll be exposed to dictionary attacks.

services.gitlab.smtp.address.description: Address of the SMTP server for Gitlab.

services.gitlab.smtp.domain.description: HELO domain to use for outgoing mail.

services.gitlab.smtp.enable.description: Enable gitlab mail delivery over SMTP.

services.gitlab.smtp.enableStartTLSAuto.description: Whether to try to use StartTLS.

services.gitlab.smtp.opensslVerifyMode.description: How OpenSSL checks the certificate, see http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActionMailer/Base.html

services.gitlab.smtp.password.description: Password of the SMTP server for Gitlab.

services.gitlab.smtp.port.description: Port of the SMTP server for Gitlab.

services.gitlab.smtp.username.description: Username of the SMTP server for Gitlab.

services.gitlab.statePath.description: Gitlab state directory, logs are stored here.

services.gitlab.user.description: User to run gitlab and all related services.

services.gitolite.adminPubkey.description:
Initial administrative public key for Gitolite. This should
be an SSH Public Key. Note that this key will only be used
once, upon the first initialization of the Gitolite user.
The key string cannot have any line breaks in it.

services.gitolite.commonHooks.description: A list of custom git hooks that get copied to <literal>~/.gitolite/hooks/common</literal>.

services.gitolite.dataDir.description: Gitolite home directory (used to store all the repositories).

services.gitolite.enable.description:
Enable gitolite management under the
<literal>gitolite</literal> user. After
switching to a configuration with Gitolite enabled, you can
then run <literal>git clone
gitolite@host:gitolite-admin.git</literal> to manage it further.

services.gitolite.enableGitAnnex.description:
Enable git-annex support. Uses the <literal>extraGitoliteRc</literal> option
to apply the necessary configuration.

services.gitolite.extraGitoliteRc.description:
Extra configuration to append to the default <literal>~/.gitolite.rc</literal>.

This should be Perl code that modifies the <literal>%RC</literal>
configuration variable. The default <literal>~/.gitolite.rc</literal>
content is generated by invoking <literal>gitolite print-default-rc</literal>,
and extra configuration from this option is appended to it. The result
is placed to Nix store, and the <literal>~/.gitolite.rc</literal> file
becomes a symlink to it.

If you already have a customized (or otherwise changed)
<literal>~/.gitolite.rc</literal> file, NixOS will refuse to replace
it with a symlink, and the `gitolite-init` initialization service
will fail. In this situation, in order to use this option, you
will need to take any customizations you may have in
<literal>~/.gitolite.rc</literal>, convert them to appropriate Perl
statements, add them to this option, and remove the file.

See also the <literal>enableGitAnnex</literal> option.

services.gitolite.group.description: Primary group of the Gitolite user account.

services.gitolite.user.description: Gitolite user account. This is the username of the gitolite endpoint.

services.glusterfs.enableGlustereventsd.description: Whether to enable the GlusterFS Events Daemon

services.glusterfs.extraFlags.description: Extra flags passed to the GlusterFS daemon

services.glusterfs.killMode.description:
The systemd KillMode to use for glusterd.

glusterd spawns other daemons like gsyncd.
If you want these to stop when glusterd is stopped (e.g. to ensure
that NixOS config changes are reflected even for these sub-daemons),
set this to 'control-group'.
If however you want running volume processes (glusterfsd) and thus
gluster mounts not be interrupted when glusterd is restarted
(for example, when you want to restart them manually at a later time),
set this to 'process'.

services.glusterfs.logLevel.description: Log level used by the GlusterFS daemon

services.glusterfs.stopKillTimeout.description:
The systemd TimeoutStopSec to use.

After this time after having been asked to shut down, glusterd
(and depending on the killMode setting also its child processes)
are killed by systemd.

The default is set low because GlusterFS (as of 3.10) is known to
not tell its children (like gsyncd) to terminate at all.

services.glusterfs.tlsSettings.description:
Make the server communicate via TLS.
This means it will only connect to other gluster
servers having certificates signed by the same CA.

Enabling this will create a file <filename>/var/lib/glusterd/secure-access</filename>.
Disabling will delete this file again.

See also: https://gluster.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Administrator%20Guide/SSL/

services.glusterfs.tlsSettings.caCert.description: Path certificate authority used to sign the cluster certificates.

services.glusterfs.tlsSettings.tlsKeyPat.description: Path to the private key used for TLS.

services.glusterfs.tlsSettings.tlsPem.description: Path to the certificate used for TLS.

services.glusterfs.useRpcbind.description:
Enable use of rpcbind. This is required for Gluster's NFS functionality.

You may want to turn it off to reduce the attack surface for DDoS reflection attacks.

See https://davelozier.com/glusterfs-and-rpcbind-portmap-ddos-reflection-attacks/
and https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1426842 for details.

services.gnome3.at-spi2-core.enable.description:

available on the GNOME platform.

services.gnome3.gnome-online-accounts.en.description:

services.gnome3.gnome-online-miners.enab.description:

services.gnome3.gnome-terminal-server.en.description:

services.gnome3.gnome-user-share.enable.description:

services.gnome3.gvfs.enable.description:

services.gnome3.tracker.enable.description:

when downloading data.

services.gnunet.udp.port.description: The UDP port for use by GNUnet.

services.gocd-server.maxJavaHeapMemory.description: Specifies the java maximum heap memory size for the Go.CD server's java process.

Marks session cookies as "secure" as a hint for browsers to only send

services.gogs.database.password.description:
The password corresponding to <option>database.user</option>.

A file containing the password corresponding to
<option>database.user</option>.

services.gollum.stateDir.description: Specifies the path of the repository directory. If it does not exist, Gollum will create it on startup.

services.gpm.enable.description:
Whether to enable GPM, the General Purpose Mouse daemon,

services.gpsd.device.description:
A device may be a local serial device for GPS input, or a URL of the form:
     <literal>[{dgpsip|ntrip}://][user:passwd@]host[:port][/stream]</literal>
in which case it specifies an input source for DGPS or ntrip data.

services.gpsd.enable.description: Whether to enable `gpsd', a GPS service daemon.

services.gpsd.port.description: The port where to listen for TCP connections.

services.gpsd.readonly.description:
Whether to enable the broken-device-safety, otherwise
known as read-only mode.  Some popular bluetooth and USB
receivers lock up or become totally inaccessible when
probed or reconfigured.  This switch prevents gpsd from
writing to a receiver.  This means that gpsd cannot
configure the receiver for optimal performance, but it
also means that gpsd cannot break the receiver.  A better
solution would be for Bluetooth to not be so fragile.  A
platform independent method to identify
serial-over-Bluetooth devices would also be nice.

services.grafana.analytics.reporting.ena.description: Whether to allow anonymous usage reporting to stats.grafana.net

services.graphite.api.enable.description:
Whether to enable graphite api. Graphite api is lightweight alternative
to graphite web, with api and without dashboard. It's advised to use
grafana as alternative dashboard and influxdb as alternative to
graphite carbon.

For more information visit
<link xlink:href="http://graphite-api.readthedocs.org/en/latest/"/>

services.graphite.api.extraConfig.example:
allowed_origins:
  - dashboard.example.com
cheat_times: true
influxdb:
  host: localhost
  port: 8086
  user: influxdb
  pass: influxdb
  db: metrics
cache:
  CACHE_TYPE: 'filesystem'
  CACHE_DIR: '/tmp/graphite-api-cache'

services.graphite.api.finders.description: List of finder plugins to load.

services.graphite.api.package.description: Package to use for graphite api.

services.graphite.carbon.aggregationRule.description: Defines if and how received metrics will be aggregated.

services.graphite.carbon.blacklist.description: Any metrics received which match one of the experssions will be dropped.

services.graphite.carbon.config.default:
[cache]
# Listen on localhost by default for security reasons
UDP_RECEIVER_INTERFACE = 127.0.0.1
PICKLE_RECEIVER_INTERFACE = 127.0.0.1
LINE_RECEIVER_INTERFACE = 127.0.0.1
CACHE_QUERY_INTERFACE = 127.0.0.1
# Do not log every update
LOG_UPDATES = False
LOG_CACHE_HITS = False

services.graphite.carbon.enableAggregato.description: Whether to enable carbon aggregator, the carbon buffering service.

services.graphite.carbon.enableCache.description: Whether to enable carbon cache, the graphite storage daemon.

services.graphite.carbon.enableRelay.description: Whether to enable carbon relay, the carbon replication and sharding service.

services.graphite.carbon.relayRules.description: Relay rules are used to send certain metrics to a certain backend.

services.graphite.carbon.rewriteRules.description:
Regular expression patterns that can be used to rewrite metric names
in a search and replace fashion.

services.graphite.carbon.storageAggregat.description: Defines how to aggregate data to lower-precision retentions.

services.graphite.carbon.storageSchemas.description: Defines retention rates for storing metrics.

services.graphite.carbon.whitelist.description: Only metrics received which match one of the experssions will be persisted.

services.graphite.pager.alerts.default:
alerts:
  - target: constantLine(100)
    warning: 90
    critical: 200
    name: Test
services.graphite.pager.alerts.example:
pushbullet_key: pushbullet_api_key
alerts:
  - target: stats.seatgeek.app.deal_quality.venue_info_cache.hit
    warning: .5
    critical: 1
    name: Deal quality venue cache hits

services.graphite.pager.enable.description:
Whether to enable graphite-pager service. For more information visit
<link xlink:href="https://github.com/seatgeek/graphite-pager"/>

services.graphite.web.enable.description: Whether to enable graphite web frontend.

services.graylog.elasticsearchHosts.description: List of valid URIs of the http ports of your elastic nodes. If one or more of your elasticsearch hosts require authentication, include the credentials in each node URI that requires authentication

services.graylog.extraConfig.description: Any other configuration options you might want to add

services.graylog.isMaster.description: Whether this is the master instance of your Graylog cluster

services.graylog.messageJournalDir.description: The directory which will be used to store the message journal. The directory must be exclusively used by Graylog and must not contain any other files than the ones created by Graylog itself

services.graylog.mongodbUri.description: MongoDB connection string. See http://docs.mongodb.org/manual/reference/connection-string/ for details

services.graylog.nodeIdFile.description: Path of the file containing the graylog node-id

services.graylog.passwordSecret.description:
You MUST set a secret to secure/pepper the stored user passwords here. Use at least 64 characters.
Generate one by using for example: pwgen -N 1 -s 96

services.graylog.rootPasswordSha2.description:
You MUST specify a hash password for the root user (which you only need to initially set up the
system and in case you lose connectivity to your authentication backend)
This password cannot be changed using the API or via the web interface. If you need to change it,
modify it here.
Create one by using for example: echo -n yourpassword | shasum -a 256
and use the resulting hash value as string for the option

services.graylog.rootUsername.description: Name of the default administrator user

services.graylog.user.description: User account under which graylog runs

udp-port = 655
mtu = 1480
ifname = vpn0

node = alpha
hostname = alpha.example.org
connect = always
enable-udp = true
enable-tcp = true
on alpha if-up = if-up-0
on alpha pid-file = /var/gvpe/gvpe.pid

services.gvpe.customIFSetup.description: Additional commands to apply in ifup script

services.hail.hydraJobUri.description: The URI of the Hydra Job.

Channel number (IEEE 802.11)

services.hostapd.enable.description:
Enable putting a wireless interface into infrastructure mode,
allowing other wireless devices to associate with the wireless
interface and do wireless networking. A simple access point will
<option>enable hostapd.wpa</option>,
<option>hostapd.wpaPassphrase</option>, and
<option>hostapd.ssid</option>, as well as DHCP on the wireless
interface to provide IP addresses to the associated stations, and
NAT (from the wireless interface to an upstream interface).

services.hostapd.ssid.description: SSID to be used in IEEE 802.11 management frames.

services.hostapd.wpa.description: Enable WPA (IEEE 802.11i/D3.0) to authenticate with the access point.

services.htpdate.extraOptions.description: Additional command line arguments to pass to htpdate.

services.htpdate.servers.description: HTTP servers to use for time synchronization.

services.httpd.adminAddr.description: E-mail address of the server administrator.

services.httpd.configFile.description:
Override the configuration file used by Apache. By default,

services.httpd.documentRoot.description:
The path of Apache's document root directory.  If left undefined,
