services.httpd.extraModules.description:
Additional Apache modules to be used.  These can be
specified as a string in the case of modules distributed
with Apache, or as an attribute set specifying the
<varname>name</varname> and <varname>path</varname> of the
module.

services.httpd.extraSubservices.description: Extra subservices to enable in the webserver.

services.httpd.globalRedirect.description:
If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to
the given URL.

services.httpd.group.description:
Group under which httpd runs.  The account is created
automatically if it doesn't exist.

services.httpd.listen.description: List of { /* ip: "*"; */ port = 80;} to listen on

services.httpd.listen.*.ip.description: Ip to listen on. 0.0.0.0 for ipv4 only, * for all.

services.httpd.logDir.description: Directory for Apache's log files.  It is created automatically.

services.httpd.logFormat.description: Log format for Apache's log files. Possible values are: combined, common, referer, agent.

services.httpd.logPerVirtualHost.description:
If enabled, each virtual host gets its own
<filename>access_log</filename> and
<filename>error_log</filename>, namely suffixed by the
<option>hostName</option> of the virtual host.

services.httpd.maxRequestsPerChild.description: Maximum number of httpd requests answered per httpd child (prefork), 0 means unlimited

services.httpd.multiProcessingModule.description:
Multi-processing module to be used by Apache.  Available
modules are <literal>prefork</literal> (the default;
handles each request in a separate child process),
<literal>worker</literal> (hybrid approach that starts a
number of child processes each running a number of
threads) and <literal>event</literal> (a recent variant of
<literal>worker</literal> that handles persistent
connections more efficiently).

services.httpd.package.description: Overridable attribute of the Apache HTTP Server package to use.

services.httpd.phpOptions.description: Options appended to the PHP configuration file <filename>php.ini</filename>.

services.httpd.phpPackage.description: Overridable attribute of the PHP package to use.

services.httpd.port.description: Port for the server. Option will be removed, use <option>listen</option> instead.

services.httpd.robotsEntries.description:
Specification of pages to be ignored by web crawlers. See <link
xlink:href='http://www.robotstxt.org/'/> for details.

services.httpd.servedDirs.description: This option provides a simple way to serve static directories.

services.httpd.servedFiles.description: This option provides a simple way to serve individual, static files.

services.httpd.serverAliases.description: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual host configuration.

services.httpd.sslServerChain.description: Path to server SSL chain file.

services.httpd.sslServerKey.description: Path to server SSL certificate key.

services.httpd.stateDir.description:
Directory for Apache's transient runtime state (such as PID
files).  It is created automatically.  Note that the default,
<filename>/run/httpd</filename>, is deleted at boot time.

services.httpd.user.description:
User account under which httpd runs.  The account is created
automatically if it doesn't exist.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.description:
Specification of the virtual hosts served by Apache.  Each
element should be an attribute set specifying the
configuration of the virtual host.  The available options
are the non-global options permissible for the main host.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.adminAddr.description: E-mail address of the server administrator.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.documentRo.description:
The path of Apache's document root directory.  If left undefined,
an empty directory in the Nix store will be used as root.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.extraConfi.description:
These lines go to httpd.conf verbatim. They will go after
directories and directory aliases defined by default.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.extraSubse.description: Extra subservices to enable in the webserver.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.globalRedi.description:
If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to
the given URL.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.listen.description: List of { /* ip: "*"; */ port = 80;} to listen on

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.listen.*.i.description: Ip to listen on. 0.0.0.0 for ipv4 only, * for all.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.logFormat.description: Log format for Apache's log files. Possible values are: combined, common, referer, agent.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.port.description: Port for the server. Option will be removed, use <option>listen</option> instead.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.robotsEntr.description:
Specification of pages to be ignored by web crawlers. See <link
xlink:href='http://www.robotstxt.org/'/> for details.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.servedDirs.description: This option provides a simple way to serve static directories.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.servedFile.description: This option provides a simple way to serve individual, static files.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.serverAlia.description: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual host configuration.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.sslServerC.description: Path to server SSL chain file.

services.httpd.virtualHosts.*.sslServerK.description: Path to server SSL certificate key.

services.hydra.buildMachinesFiles.description: List of files containing build machines.

services.hydra.dbi.description: The DBI string for Hydra database connection.

services.hydra.debugServer.description: Whether to run the server in debug mode.

services.hydra.extraConfig.description: Extra lines for the Hydra configuration.

services.hydra.gcRootsDir.description: Directory that holds Hydra garbage collector roots.

services.hydra.hydraURL.description: The base URL for the Hydra webserver instance. Used for links in emails.

services.hydra.listenHost.description:
The hostname or address to listen on or <literal>*</literal> to listen
on all interfaces.

services.hydra.logo.description: Path to a file containing the logo of your Hydra instance.

services.hydra.minimumDiskFree.description: Threshold of minimum disk space (GiB) to determine if the queue runner should run or not.

services.hydra.minimumDiskFreeEvaluator.description: Threshold of minimum disk space (GiB) to determine if the evaluator should run or not.

services.hydra.notificationSender.description: Sender email address used for email notifications.

services.hydra.port.description: TCP port the web server should listen to.

services.hydra.smtpHost.description: Hostname of the SMTP server to use to send email.

services.hydra.tracker.description: Piece of HTML that is included on all pages.

services.hydra.useSubstitutes.description:
Whether to use binary caches for downloading store paths. Note that
binary substitutions trigger (a potentially large number of) additional
HTTP requests that slow down the queue monitor thread significantly.
Also, this Hydra instance will serve those downloaded store paths to
its users with its own signature attached as if it had built them
itself, so don't enable this feature unless your active binary caches
are absolute trustworthy.

services.i2pd.addressbook.defaulturl.description: AddressBook subscription URL for initial setup

services.i2pd.bandwidth.description:
Set a router bandwidth limit integer in KBps.
If not set, <command>i2pd</command> defaults to 32KBps.

services.i2pd.enable.description:
Enables I2Pd as a running service upon activation.
Please read http://i2pd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ for further
configuration help.

services.i2pd.enableIPv4.description: Enables IPv4 connectivity. Enabled by default.

services.i2pd.enableIPv6.description: Enables IPv6 connectivity. Disabled by default.

services.i2pd.floodfill.description: If the router is declared to be unreachable and needs introduction nodes.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.description: Serve something on I2P network at port and delegate requests to address inPort.
services.i2pd.inTunnels.type: list or attribute set of submodules

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.accessLi.description: I2P nodes that are allowed to connect to this service.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.crypto.t.description: Number of ElGamal/AES tags to send.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.destinat.description: Remote endpoint, I2P hostname or b32.i2p address.

services.i2pd.inTunnels.<name?>.inPort.description: Service port. Default to the tunnel's listen port.

services.i2pd.limits.transittunnels.description: Maximum number of active transit sessions

services.i2pd.logLevel.description:
The log level. <command>i2pd</command> defaults to "info"
but that generates copious amounts of log messages.

We default to "error" which is similar to the default log
level of <command>tor</command>.

services.i2pd.nat.description: Assume router is NATed. Enabled by default.

services.i2pd.notransit.description: Tells the router to not accept transit tunnels during startup.

services.i2pd.outTunnels.description: Connect to someone as a client and establish a local accept endpoint
services.i2pd.outTunnels.type: list or attribute set of submodules

services.i2pd.outTunnels.<name?>.crypto..description: Number of ElGamal/AES tags to send.

services.i2pd.outTunnels.<name?>.destina.description: Remote endpoint, I2P hostname or b32.i2p address.

services.i2pd.port.description: I2P listen port. If no one is given the router will pick between 9111 and 30777.

services.i2pd.precomputation.elgamal.description:
Whenever to use precomputated tables for ElGamal.
<command>i2pd</command> defaults to <literal>false</literal>
to save 64M of memory (and looses some performance).

We default to <literal>true</literal> as that is what most
users want anyway.

services.i2pd.proto.bob.address.description: Bind address for bob endpoint. Default: 127.0.0.1

services.i2pd.proto.bob.port.description: Bind port for bob endoint. Default: 2827

services.i2pd.proto.http.address.description: Bind address for http endpoint. Default: 127.0.0.1

services.i2pd.proto.http.port.description: Bind port for http endoint. Default: 7070

services.i2pd.proto.httpProxy.address.description: Bind address for httpproxy endpoint. Default: 127.0.0.1

services.i2pd.proto.httpProxy.port.description: Bind port for httpproxy endoint. Default: 4444

services.i2pd.proto.i2cp.address.description: Bind address for i2cp endpoint. Default: 127.0.0.1

services.i2pd.proto.i2cp.port.description: Bind port for i2cp endoint. Default: 7654

services.i2pd.proto.i2pControl.address.description: Bind address for i2pcontrol endpoint. Default: 127.0.0.1

services.i2pd.proto.i2pControl.port.description: Bind port for i2pcontrol endoint. Default: 7650

services.i2pd.proto.sam.address.description: Bind address for sam endpoint. Default: 127.0.0.1

services.i2pd.proto.sam.port.description: Bind port for sam endoint. Default: 7656

services.i2pd.proto.socksProxy.address.description: Bind address for socksproxy endpoint. Default: 127.0.0.1

services.i2pd.proto.socksProxy.port.description: Bind port for socksproxy endoint. Default: 4447

services.i2pd.reseed.file.description: Full path to SU3 file to reseed from

services.i2pd.upnp.name.description: Name i2pd appears in UPnP forwardings list.

services.icecast.admin.password.description: Password used for all administration functions.

services.icecast.admin.user.description: Username used for all administration functions.

services.icecast.hostname.description: DNS name or IP address that will be used for the stream directory lookups or possibily the playlist generation if a Host header is not provided.

services.icecast.listen.port.description: TCP port that will be used to accept client connections.

services.ihaskell.extraPackages.description:
Extra packages available to ghc when running ihaskell. The
value must be a function which receives the attrset defined
in <varname>haskellPackages</varname> as the sole argument.

services.illum.enable.description: Enable illum, a daemon for controlling screen brightness with brightness buttons.

services.infinoted.certificateChain.description:
Chain of CA-certificates to which our `certificateFile` is relative.
Optional for TLS.

services.infinoted.certificateFile.description: Server certificate to use for TLS

services.infinoted.extraConfig.description: Additional configuration to append to infinoted.conf

services.infinoted.group.description: What to call the primary group of the dedicated user under which infinoted is run

services.infinoted.keyFile.description: Private key to use for TLS

services.infinoted.passwordFile.description: File to read server-wide password from

services.infinoted.rootDirectory.description: Root of the directory structure to serve

services.infinoted.securityPolicy.description: How strictly to enforce clients connection with TLS.

services.infinoted.user.description: What to call the dedicated user under which infinoted is run

services.influxdb.dataDir.description: Data directory for influxd data files.

services.influxdb.enable.description: Whether to enable the influxdb server

services.influxdb.user.description: User account under which influxdb runs

services.interception-tools.enable.description: Whether to enable the interception tools service.

services.interception-tools.plugins.description:
A list of interception tools plugins that will be made available to use
inside the udevmon configuration.

services.interception-tools.udevmonConfi.default:
- JOB: "intercept -g $DEVNODE | caps2esc | uinput -d $DEVNODE"
  DEVICE:
    EVENTS:
      EV_KEY: [KEY_CAPSLOCK, KEY_ESC]
services.interception-tools.udevmonConfi.description:
String of udevmon YAML configuration, or path to a udevmon YAML
configuration file.
services.interception-tools.udevmonConfi.example:
- JOB: "intercept -g $DEVNODE | y2z | x2y | uinput -d $DEVNODE"
  DEVICE:
    EVENTS:
      EV_KEY: [KEY_X, KEY_Y]

services.iodine.clients.description:
Each attribute of this option defines a systemd service that
runs iodine. Many or none may be defined.
The name of each service is
<literal>iodine-<replaceable>name</replaceable></literal>
where <replaceable>name</replaceable> is the name of the
corresponding attribute name.

services.iodine.clients.<name>.relay.description: DNS server to use as a intermediate relay to the iodined server

services.iodine.clients.<name>.server.description: Domain or Subdomain of server running iodined

services.iodine.server.domain.description: Domain or subdomain of which nameservers point to us

services.iodine.server.ip.description: The assigned ip address or ip range

services.ipfs.apiAddress.description: Where IPFS exposes its API to

services.ipfs.autoMount.description: Whether IPFS should try to mount /ipfs and /ipns at startup.

services.ipfs.defaultMode.description: systemd service that is enabled by default

services.ipfs.emptyRepo.description: If set to true, the repo won't be initialized with help files

services.ipfs.enable.description: Whether to enable Interplanetary File System.

services.ipfs.enableGC.description: Whether to enable automatic garbage collection

services.ipfs.extraConfig.description:
Attrset of daemon configuration to set using <command>ipfs config</command>, every time the daemon starts.
These are applied last, so may override configuration set by other options in this module.
Keep in mind that this configuration is stateful; i.e., unsetting anything in here does not reset the value to the default!

services.ipfs.extraFlags.description: Extra flags passed to the IPFS daemon

services.ipfs.gatewayAddress.description: Where the IPFS Gateway can be reached

services.ipfs.group.description: Group under which the IPFS daemon runs

services.ipfs.ipfsMountDir.description: Where to mount the IPFS namespace to

services.ipfs.ipnsMountDir.description: Where to mount the IPNS namespace to

services.ipfs.serviceFdlimit.description: The fdlimit for the IPFS systemd unit or <literal>null</literal> to have the daemon attempt to manage it

services.ipfs.user.description: User under which the IPFS daemon runs

services.ircdHybrid.certificate.description: IRCD server SSL certificate. There are some limitations - read manual.

services.ircdHybrid.sid.description: IRCD server unique ID in a net of servers.

services.irkerd.enable.description: Whether to enable irker, an IRC notification daemon.

services.irkerd.listenAddress.description:
Specifies the bind address on which the irker daemon listens.
The default is localhost.

Irker authors strongly warn about the risks of running this on
a publicly accessible interface, so change this with caution.

services.irkerd.openPorts.description: Open ports in the firewall for irkerd

services.jboss.enable.description: Whether to enable JBoss. WARNING : this package is outdated and is known to have vulnerabilities.

services.jboss.libUrl.description: Location where the shared library JARs are stored

services.jboss.logDir.description: Location of the logfile directory of JBoss

services.jboss.serverDir.description: Location of the server instance files

services.jboss.tempDir.description: Location where JBoss stores its temp files

services.jboss.useJK.description: Whether to use to connector to the Apache HTTP server

services.jboss.user.description: User account under which jboss runs.

services.jenkins.enable.description: Whether to enable the jenkins continuous integration server.

services.jenkins.environment.description:
Additional environment variables to be passed to the jenkins process.
As a base environment, jenkins receives NIX_PATH from
<option>environment.sessionVariables</option>, NIX_REMOTE is set to
"daemon" and JENKINS_HOME is set to the value of
<option>services.jenkins.home</option>.
This option has precedence and can be used to override those
mentioned variables.

services.jenkins.extraGroups.description: List of extra groups that the "jenkins" user should be a part of.

services.jenkins.extraJavaOptions.description: Additional command line arguments to pass to the Java run time (as opposed to Jenkins).

services.jenkins.extraOptions.description: Additional command line arguments to pass to Jenkins.

services.jenkins.group.description:
If the default user "jenkins" is configured then this is the primary
group of that user.

services.jenkins.home.description:
The path to use as JENKINS_HOME. If the default user "jenkins" is configured then
this is the home of the "jenkins" user.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.accessToken.description: User token in Jenkins used to reload config.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.accessUser.description: User id in Jenkins used to reload config.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.enable.description:
Whether or not to enable the Jenkins Job Builder (JJB) service. It
allows defining jobs for Jenkins in a declarative manner.

Jobs managed through the Jenkins WebUI (or by other means) are left
unchanged.

Note that it really is declarative configuration; if you remove a
previously defined job, the corresponding job directory will be
deleted.

Please see the Jenkins Job Builder documentation for more info:
<link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/infra/jenkins-job-builder/">
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/jenkins-job-builder/</link>

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.jsonJobs.description: Job descriptions for Jenkins Job Builder in JSON format.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.nixJobs.description:
Job descriptions for Jenkins Job Builder in Nix format.

This is a trivial wrapper around jsonJobs, using builtins.toJSON
behind the scene.

services.jenkins.jobBuilder.yamlJobs.description: Job descriptions for Jenkins Job Builder in YAML format.
services.jenkins.jobBuilder.yamlJobs.example:
- job:
    name: jenkins-job-test-1
    builders:
      - shell: echo 'Hello world!'

services.jenkins.listenAddress.description:
Specifies the bind address on which the jenkins HTTP interface listens.
The default is the wildcard address.

services.jenkins.packages.description: Packages to add to PATH for the jenkins process.

services.jenkins.plugins.description:
A set of plugins to activate. Note that this will completely
remove and replace any previously installed plugins. If you
have manually-installed plugins that you want to keep while
using this module, set this option to
<literal>null</literal>. You can generate this set with a
tool such as <literal>jenkinsPlugins2nix</literal>.
services.jenkins.plugins.type: null or attribute set of packages

services.jenkins.port.description:
Specifies port number on which the jenkins HTTP interface listens.
The default is 8080.

services.jenkins.prefix.description:
Specifies a urlPrefix to use with jenkins.
If the example /jenkins is given, the jenkins server will be
accessible using localhost:8080/jenkins.

services.jenkins.user.description: User the jenkins server should execute under.

services.jenkinsSlave.enable.description:
If true the system will be configured to work as a jenkins slave.
If the system is also configured to work as a jenkins master then this has no effect.
In progress: Currently only assures the jenkins user is configured.

services.jenkinsSlave.group.description:
If the default slave agent user "jenkins" is configured then this is
the primary group of that user.

services.jenkinsSlave.home.description:
The path to use as JENKINS_HOME. If the default user "jenkins" is configured then
this is the home of the "jenkins" user.

services.jenkinsSlave.user.description: User the jenkins slave agent should execute under.

services.jira.catalinaOptions.description: Java options to pass to catalina/tomcat.

services.jira.enable.description: Whether to enable Atlassian JIRA service.

services.jira.home.description: Home directory of the JIRA instance.

services.jira.jrePackage.description: Java Runtime to use for JIRA. Note that Atlassian recommends the Oracle JRE.

services.jira.proxy.enable.description: Whether to enable reverse proxy support.

services.jira.proxy.secure.description: Whether the connections to the proxy should be considered secure.

services.jira.sso.applicationName.description: Exact name of this JIRA instance in Crowd

services.jira.sso.applicationPassword.description: Application password of this JIRA instance in Crowd

services.jira.sso.crowd.description: Crowd Base URL without trailing slash

services.jira.sso.enable.description: Whether to enable SSO with Atlassian Crowd.

services.jira.sso.validationInterval.description:
Set to 0, if you want authentication checks to occur on each
request. Otherwise set to the number of minutes between request
to validate if the user is logged in or out of the Crowd SSO
server. Setting this value to 1 or higher will increase the
performance of Crowd's integration.

services.journalbeat.extraConfig.default:
journalbeat:
  seek_position: cursor
  cursor_seek_fallback: tail
  write_cursor_state: true
  cursor_flush_period: 5s
  clean_field_names: true
  convert_to_numbers: false
  move_metadata_to_field: journal
  default_type: journal
services.journalbeat.extraConfig.description: Any other configuration options you want to add

services.journalbeat.stateDir.description: The state directory. Journalbeat's own logs and other data are stored here.

services.journalbeat.tags.description: Tags to place on the shipped log messages

services.journald.console.description: If non-empty, write log messages to the specified TTY device.

services.journald.enableHttpGateway.description: Whether to enable the HTTP gateway to the journal.

services.journald.extraConfig.description:
Extra config options for systemd-journald. See man journald.conf
for available options.

services.journald.rateLimitBurst.description:
Configures the rate limiting burst limit (number of messages per
interval) that is applied to all messages generated on the system.
This rate limiting is applied per-service, so that two services
which log do not interfere with each other's limit.

services.journald.rateLimitInterval.description:
Configures the rate limiting interval that is applied to all
messages generated on the system. This rate limiting is applied
per-service, so that two services which log do not interfere with
each other's limit. The value may be specified in the following
units: s, min, h, ms, us. To turn off any kind of rate limiting,
set either value to 0.

services.journalwatch.accuracy.description:
The time window around the interval in which the journalwatch run will be scheduled.

The format is described in systemd.time(7).

services.journalwatch.enable.description: If enabled, periodically check the journal with journalwatch and report the results by mail.

services.journalwatch.extraConfig.description:
Extra lines to be added verbatim to the journalwatch/config configuration file.
You can add any commandline argument to the config, without the '--'.
See <literal>journalwatch --help</literal> for all arguments and their description.

default.filters:
(Stopped|Stopping|Starting|Started) .*
(Created slice|Removed slice) user-\d*\.slice\.
Received SIGRTMIN\+24 from PID .*
(Reached target|Stopped target) .*
Startup finished in \d*ms\.

services.journalwatch.filterBlocks.description:
filterBlocks can be defined to blacklist journal messages which are not errors.
Each block matches on a log entry field, and the filters in that block then are matched
against all messages with a matching log entry field.

All messages whose PRIORITY is at least 6 (INFO) are processed by journalwatch.
If you don't specify any filterBlocks, PRIORITY is reduced to 5 (NOTICE) by default.

All regular expressions are extended Python regular expressions, for details
see: http://doc.pyschools.com/html/regex.html

example.filters:
New session [a-z]?\d+ of user \w+\.
Removed session [a-z]?\d+\.

services.journalwatch.filterBlocks.*.fil.description:
The filters to apply on all messages which satisfy <option>match</option>.
Any of those messages that match any specified filter will be removed from journalwatch's output.
Each filter is an extended Python regular expression.
You can specify multiple filters and separate them by newlines.
Lines starting with '#' are comments. Inline-comments are not permitted.

services.journalwatch.filterBlocks.*.mat.description:
Syntax: <literal>field = value</literal>
Specifies the log entry <literal>field</literal> this block should apply to.
If the <literal>field</literal> of a message matches this <literal>value</literal>,
this patternBlock's <option>filters</option> are applied.
If <literal>value</literal> starts and ends with a slash, it is interpreted as
an extended python regular expression, if not, it's an exact match.
The journal fields are explained in systemd.journal-fields(7).

services.journalwatch.interval.description:
How often to run journalwatch.

The format is described in systemd.time(7).

services.journalwatch.mailBinary.description: Sendmail-compatible binary to be used to send the messages.

services.journalwatch.mailFrom.description: Mail address to send journalwatch reports from.

services.journalwatch.mailTo.description: Mail address to send journalwatch reports to.

services.journalwatch.priority.description:
Lowest priority of message to be considered.
A value between 7 ("debug"), and 0 ("emerg"). Defaults to 6 ("info").
If you don't care about anything with "info" priority, you can reduce
this to e.g. 5 ("notice") to considerably reduce the amount of
messages without needing many <option>filterBlocks</option>.

services.kbfs.enable.description: Whether to mount the Keybase filesystem.

services.kbfs.extraFlags.description: Additional flags to pass to the Keybase filesystem on launch.

services.keepalived.extraConfig.description: Extra lines to be added verbatim to the configuration file.

services.keepalived.extraGlobalDefs.description:
Extra lines to be added verbatim to the 'global_defs' block of the
configuration file

services.keepalived.snmp.enable.description: Whether to enable the builtin AgentX subagent.

services.keepalived.snmp.enableChecker.description: Enable SNMP handling of checker element of KEEPALIVED MIB.

services.keepalived.snmp.enableKeepalive.description: Enable SNMP handling of vrrp element of KEEPALIVED MIB.

services.keepalived.snmp.enableRfc.description: Enable SNMP handling of RFC2787 and RFC6527 VRRP MIBs.

services.keepalived.snmp.enableRfcV2.description: Enable SNMP handling of RFC2787 VRRP MIB.

services.keepalived.snmp.enableRfcV3.description: Enable SNMP handling of RFC6527 VRRP MIB.

services.keepalived.snmp.socket.description:
Socket to use for connecting to SNMP master agent. If this value is
set to null, keepalived's default will be used, which is
unix:/var/agentx/master, unless using a network namespace, when the
default is udp:localhost:705.

services.keepalived.vrrpInstances.<name>.description: Extra lines to be added verbatim to the vrrp_instance section.
Interface for inside_network, bound by vrrp.

VRRP will normally preempt a lower priority machine when a higher
priority machine comes online. "nopreempt" allows the lower priority
machine to maintain the master role, even when a higher priority machine
comes back online. NOTE: For this to work, the initial state of this
entry must be BACKUP.

For electing MASTER, highest priority wins. To be MASTER, make 50 more
than other machines.

Initial state. As soon as the other machine(s) come up, an election will
be held and the machine with the highest "priority" will become MASTER.
So the entry here doesn't matter a whole lot.

Do not send VRRP adverts over VRRP multicast group. Instead it sends
adverts to the following list of ip addresses using unicast design
fashion. It can be cool to use VRRP FSM and features in a networking
environment where multicast is not supported! IP Addresses specified can
IPv4 as well as IPv6.

Default IP for binding vrrpd is the primary IP on interface. If you
want to hide location of vrrpd, use this IP as src_addr for unicast
vrrp packets.
IP address, optionally with a netmask: IPADDR[/MASK]
The broadcast address on the interface.
The name of the device to add the address to.

Each address may be tagged with a label string. In order to preserve
compatibility with Linux-2.0 net aliases, this string must coincide with
the name of the device or must be prefixed with the device name followed
by colon.
The scope of the area where this address is valid.

Arbitrary unique number 0..255. Used to differentiate multiple instances
of vrrpd running on the same NIC (and hence same socket).

Name of the vmac interface to use. keepalived will come up with a name
if you don't specify one.
Send/Recv VRRP messages from base interface instead of VMAC interface.

services.lighttpd.cgit.configText.description:

http://git.zx2c4.com/cgit/tree/cgitrc.5.txt

services.lighttpd.inginious.backendType.description:
Select how INGINious accesses to grading containers.
The default "local" option ensures that Docker is started and provisioned.
Fore more information, see http://inginious.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install_doc/config_reference.html
Not all backends are supported. Use services.inginious.configFile for full flexibility.

and will be automatically downloaded before INGInious starts.

# Load the dummy auth plugin.
plugins:
  - plugin_module: inginious.frontend.webapp.plugins.auth.demo_auth
    users:
      # register the user "test" with the password "someverycomplexpassword"
      test: someverycomplexpassword

services.lighttpd.inginious.hostPattern.description:
The domain that serves INGInious.
INGInious uses absolute paths which makes it difficult to relocate in its own subdir.
The default configuration will serve INGInious when the server is accessed with a hostname starting with "inginious.".
If left blank, INGInious will take the precedence over all the other lighttpd sites, which is probably not what you want.

services.lighttpd.inginious.remoteAgents.description: A list of remote agents, used only when services.inginious.backendType is "remote_manual".

services.mailUsers.users.*.password.description:
You can generate passwords like this:
  doveadm pw -s sha256-crypt
  Enter new password:
  Retype new password:
  {SHA256-CRYPT}$5$/CHK3ckfRJloONnq$X/16jK2NPTiZpBZZ1XVpHhPXyxPy1p0QtUNeUFrYav5
services.mailUsers.users.*.password.example:
#{ name = "js"; domain = "lastlog.de"; aliases = [ "joachim@lastlog.de" ]; password = "{SHA256-CRYPT}$5$/CHK3ckfRJloONnq$X/16jK2NPTiZpBZZ1XVpHhPXyxPy1p0QtUNeUFrYav5"; }
{ name = "anton"; domain = "lastlog.de"; aliases = [ "joachim@mail.lastlog.de" ]; password = "{PLAIN}hallo"; }

The duration in milliseconds to delay processing events from
remote servers by if they go over the sleep limit.

The number of federation requests from a single server in a window
before the server will delay processing the request.

services.matrix-synapse.key_refresh_inte.description:
How long key response published by this server is valid for.
Used to set the valid_until_ts in /key/v2 APIs.
Determines how quickly servers will query to check which keys
are still valid.

services.matrix-synapse.listeners.description: List of ports that Synapse should listen on, their purpose and their configuration.

services.matrix-synapse.listeners.*.bind.description:
Local interface to listen on.
The empty string will cause synapse to listen on all interfaces.

services.matrix-synapse.listeners.*.port.description: The port to listen for HTTP(S) requests on.

services.matrix-synapse.listeners.*.reso.description: List of HTTP resources to serve on this listener.

Should synapse compress HTTP responses to clients that support it?
This should be disabled if running synapse behind a load balancer
that can do automatic compression.
List of resources to host on this listener.

services.matrix-synapse.listeners.*.tls.description: Whether to listen for HTTPS connections rather than HTTP.

services.matrix-synapse.listeners.*.x_fo.description:
Use the X-Forwarded-For (XFF) header as the client IP and not the
actual client IP.

services.matrix-synapse.logConfig.default:
version: 1

# In systemd's journal, loglevel is implicitly stored, so let's omit it
# from the message text.
formatters:
    journal_fmt:
        format: '%(name)s: [%(request)s] %(message)s'

filters:
    context:
        (): synapse.util.logcontext.LoggingContextFilter
        request: ""

handlers:
    journal:
        class: systemd.journal.JournalHandler
        formatter: journal_fmt
        filters: [context]
        SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER: synapse

root:
    level: INFO
    handlers: [journal]

disable_existing_loggers: False
services.matrix-synapse.logConfig.description: A yaml python logging config file

services.matrix-synapse.max_image_pixels.description: Maximum number of pixels that will be thumbnailed

services.matrix-synapse.max_upload_size.description: The largest allowed upload size in bytes

services.matterbridge.configFile.description: The matterbridge configuration file in the TOML file format.
services.matterbridge.configFile.example:
#WARNING: as this file contains credentials, be sure to set correct file permissions          [irc]
    [irc.freenode]
    Server="irc.freenode.net:6667"
    Nick="matterbot"

[mattermost]
    [mattermost.work]
     #do not prefix it wit http:// or https://
     Server="yourmattermostserver.domain"
     Team="yourteam"
     Login="yourlogin"
     Password="yourpass"
     PrefixMessagesWithNick=true

[[gateway]]
name="gateway1"
enable=true
    [[gateway.inout]]
    account="irc.freenode"
    channel="#testing"

    [[gateway.inout]]
    account="mattermost.work"
    channel="off-topic"

services.mattermost.mutableConfig.description:
Whether the Mattermost config.json is writeable by Mattermost.

Most of the settings can be edited in the system console of
Mattermost if this option is enabled. A template config using
the options specified in services.mattermost will be generated
but won't be overwritten on changes or rebuilds.

If this option is disabled, changes in the system console won't
be possible (default). If an config.json is present, it will be
overwritten!

registry. It is imperative to set this value to be a majority of

If 0 will fall back to --registry=in_memory.

List of containerizer implementations to compose in order to provide
containerization. Available options are mesos and docker.

The default url for pulling Docker images.

If enabled, start a Minecraft Server. The listening port for

data will be loaded from and saved to
<literal>/var/lib/minecraft</literal>.

services.minetest-server.configPath.description:
Path to the config to use.

If only one game exists, this option can be null.

services.mingetty.serialSpeed.description:
Bitrates to allow for agetty's listening on serial ports. Listing more

<literal>A,</literal>, <literal>V,</literal> and
<literal>P,</literal> restrict a directory to audio, video
or image files.  The directories must be accessible to the
<literal>minidlna</literal> user account.

To generate hashed password install <literal>mosquitto</literal>

Extra directives added to to the end of MPD's configuration file,

is added automatically to the beginning of the file. For available
options see <literal>man 5 mpd.conf</literal>'.

If set, <command>mpd</command> is socket-activated; that
is, instead of having it permanently running as a daemon,
systemd will start it on the first incoming connection.

services.munge.password.description: The path to a daemon's secret key.

services.munin-cron.enable.description:
Enable munin-cron. Takes care of all heavy lifting to collect data from
nodes and draws graphs to html. Runs munin-update, munin-limits,
munin-graphs and munin-html in that order.

HTML output is in <filename>/var/www/munin/</filename>, configure your
favourite webserver to serve static files.

services.munin-cron.extraGlobalConfig.description:
<filename>munin.conf</filename> extra global configuration.
See <link xlink:href='http://munin-monitoring.org/wiki/munin.conf' />.
Useful to setup notifications, see
<link xlink:href='http://munin-monitoring.org/wiki/HowToContact' />

services.munin-cron.hosts.description:
Definitions of hosts of nodes to collect data from. Needs at least one
hosts for cron to succeed. See
<link xlink:href='http://munin-monitoring.org/wiki/munin.conf' />

services.munin-node.enable.description:
Enable Munin Node agent. Munin node listens on 0.0.0.0 and
by default accepts connections only from 127.0.0.1 for security reasons.

See <link xlink:href='http://munin-monitoring.org/wiki/munin-node.conf' />.

services.murmur.allowHtml.description:
Allow HTML in client messages, comments, and channel

Number of attempts a client is allowed to make in
<literal>autobanTimeframe</literal> seconds, before being
banned for <literal>autobanTime</literal>.

services.murmur.autobanTime.description: The amount of time an IP ban lasts (in seconds).

services.murmur.autobanTimeframe.description:
Timeframe in which a client can connect without being banned
for repeated attempts (in seconds).

services.murmur.bandwidth.description:
Maximum bandwidth (in bits per second) that clients may send
speech at.

services.murmur.bonjour.description:
Enable Bonjour auto-discovery, which allows clients over
your LAN to automatically discover Murmur servers.

services.murmur.clientCertRequired.description: Require clients to authenticate via certificates.

services.murmur.enable.description: If enabled, start the Murmur Service.

services.murmur.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to put into mumur.ini.

services.murmur.hostName.description: Host to bind to. Defaults binding on all addresses.

services.murmur.imgMsgLength.description: Max length of image messages. Set 0 for no limit.

services.murmur.logDays.description:
How long to store RPC logs for in the database. Set 0 to
keep logs forever, or -1 to disable DB logging.

services.murmur.password.description: Required password to join server, if specified.

services.murmur.pidfile.description: Path to PID file for Murmur daemon.

services.murmur.port.description: Ports to bind to (UDP and TCP).

services.murmur.registerHostname.description:
DNS hostname where your server can be reached. This is only
needed if you want your server to be accessed by its
hostname and not IP - but the name *must* resolve on the
internet properly.

services.murmur.registerName.description:
Public server registration name, and also the name of the
Root channel. Even if you don't publicly register your
server, you probably still want to set this.

services.murmur.registerPassword.description:
Public server registry password, used authenticate your
server to the registry to prevent impersonation; required for
subsequent registry updates.

services.murmur.sendVersion.description: Send Murmur version in UDP response.

services.murmur.sslCa.description: Path to your SSL CA certificate.

services.murmur.textMsgLength.description: Max length of text messages. Set 0 for no limit.

services.murmur.users.description: Maximum number of concurrent clients allowed.

services.mwlib.nserve.address.description: Specify network interface to listen on.

services.mwlib.nserve.enable.description:
Whether to enable nserve. Nserve is a HTTP
server.  The Collection extension is talking to
that program directly.  Nserve uses at least
one qserve instance in order to distribute
and manage jobs.

services.mwlib.nslave.enable.description:
Pulls new jobs from exactly one qserve instance
and calls the zip and render programs
in order to download article collections and
convert them to different output formats. Nslave
uses a cache directory to store the generated
documents. Nslave also starts an internal http
server serving the content of the cache directory.

services.mwlib.nslave.http.description:
Internal http server serving the content of the cache directory.
You have to enable it, or use your own way for serving files
and set the http.url option accordingly.

services.mwlib.nslave.http.address.description: Specify network interface to listen on.

services.mwlib.nslave.http.port.description: Port to listen to when serving files from cache.

services.mwlib.nslave.http.url.description:
Specify URL for accessing generated files from cache.
The Collection extension of Mediawiki won't be able to
download files without it.

services.mwlib.nslave.numprocs.description: Number of parallel jobs to be executed.

services.mwlib.qserve.address.description: Specify network interface to listen on.

services.mwlib.qserve.allow.description: List of allowed client IPs. Empty means any.

services.mwlib.qserve.enable.description:
A job queue server used to distribute and manage
jobs. You should start one qserve instance
for each machine that is supposed to render pdf
files. Unless youre operating the Wikipedia
installation, one machine should suffice.

services.mysql.bind.description: Address to bind to. The default it to bind to all addresses

services.mysql.dataDir.description: Location where MySQL stores its table files

services.mysql.enable.description: Whether to enable the MySQL server.

services.mysql.ensureDatabases.description:
Ensures that the specified databases exist.
This option will never delete existing databases, especially not when the value of this
option is changed. This means that databases created once through this option or
otherwise have to be removed manually.

services.mysql.ensureUsers.description:
Ensures that the specified users exist and have at least the ensured permissions.
The MySQL users will be identified using Unix socket authentication. This authenticates the Unix user with the
same name only, and that without the need for a password.
This option will never delete existing users or remove permissions, especially not when the value of this
option is changed. This means that users created and permissions assigned once through this option or
otherwise have to be removed manually.

services.mysql.extraOptions.description:
Provide extra options to the MySQL configuration file.

Please note, that these options are added to the
<literal>[mysqld]</literal> section so you don't need to explicitly
state it again.

services.mysql.initialDatabases.description:
List of database names and their initial schemas that should be used to create databases on the first startup
of MySQL. The schema attribute is optional: If not specified, an empty database is created.

services.mysql.initialScript.description: A file containing SQL statements to be executed on the first startup. Can be used for granting certain permissions on the database

services.mysql.pidDir.description: Location of the file which stores the PID of the MySQL server

services.mysql.replication.masterHost.description: Hostname of the MySQL master server

services.mysql.replication.masterPasswor.description: Password of the MySQL replication user

services.mysql.replication.masterPort.description: Port number on which the MySQL master server runs

services.mysql.replication.masterUser.description: Username of the MySQL replication user

services.mysql.replication.role.description: Role of the MySQL server instance.

services.mysql.replication.serverId.description: Id of the MySQL server instance. This number must be unique for each instance

services.mysql.replication.slaveHost.description: Hostname of the MySQL slave server

services.mysql.rootPassword.description: Path to a file containing the root password, modified on the first startup. Not specifying a root password will leave the root password empty.

services.mysql.user.description: User account under which MySQL runs

services.mysqlBackup.calendar.description: Configured when to run the backup service systemd unit (DayOfWeek Year-Month-Day Hour:Minute:Second).

services.mysqlBackup.databases.description: List of database names to dump.

services.mysqlBackup.location.description: Location to put the gzipped MySQL database dumps.

services.mysqlBackup.singleTransaction.description: Whether to create database dump in a single transaction

services.mysqlBackup.user.description: User to be used to perform backup.

services.nagios.cgiConfigFile.description:
Derivation for the configuration file of Nagios CGI scripts
          that can be used in web servers for running the Nagios web interface.

services.nagios.enable.description:
Whether to use <link
          xlink:href='http://www.nagios.org/'>Nagios</link> to monitor
          your system or network.

services.nagios.enableWebInterface.description:
Whether to enable the Nagios web interface.  You should also
          enable Apache (<option>services.httpd.enable</option>).

services.nagios.mainConfigFile.description: Derivation for the main configuration file of Nagios.

services.nagios.objectDefs.description:
A list of Nagios object configuration files that must define
          the hosts, host groups, services and contacts for the
          network that you want Nagios to monitor.

services.nagios.plugins.description:
Packages to be added to the Nagios <envar>PATH</envar>.
          Typically used to add plugins, but can be anything.

services.nagios.urlPath.description:
The URL path under which the Nagios web interface appears.
          That is, you can access the Nagios web interface through
          <literal>http://<replaceable>server</replaceable>/<replaceable>urlPath</replaceable></literal>.

services.namecoind.enable.description: Whether to enable namecoind, Namecoin client..

services.namecoind.extraNodes.description: List of additional peer IP addresses to connect to.

services.namecoind.rpc.address.description: IP address the RPC server will bind to.

services.namecoind.rpc.allowFrom.description:
List of IP address ranges allowed to use the RPC API.
Wiledcards (*) can be user to specify a range.

services.namecoind.rpc.certificate.description: Certificate file for securing RPC connections.

services.namecoind.rpc.key.description: Key file for securing RPC connections.

services.namecoind.rpc.port.description: Port the RPC server will bind to.

services.namecoind.trustedNodes.description:
List of the only peer IP addresses to connect to. If specified
no other connection will be made.

services.namecoind.wallet.description:
Wallet file. The ownership of the file has to be
namecoin:namecoin, and the permissions must be 0640.

services.neo4j.boltPort.description: Neo4j port to listen for BOLT traffic.

services.neo4j.httpsPort.description: Neo4j port to listen for HTTPS traffic.

services.neo4j.port.description: Neo4j port to listen for HTTP traffic.

services.netatalk.enable.description: Whether to enable the Netatalk AFP fileserver.

services.netatalk.extmap.description:
File name extension mappings.
	  See <literal>man extmap.conf</literal> for more information.

services.netatalk.extraConfig.description:
Lines of configuration to add to the <literal>[Global]</literal> section.
See <literal>man apf.conf</literal> for more information.

services.netatalk.homes.basedirRegex.description: Regex which matches the parent directory of the user homes.

services.netatalk.homes.enable.description: Enable sharing of the UNIX server user home directories.

services.netatalk.homes.extraConfig.description:
Lines of configuration to add to the <literal>[Homes]</literal> section.
See <literal>man apf.conf</literal> for more information.

services.netatalk.homes.path.description: Share not the whole user home but this subdirectory path.

services.netatalk.port.description: TCP port to be used for AFP.

services.netatalk.volumes.description:
Set of AFP volumes to export.
See <literal>man apf.conf</literal> for more information.
services.netatalk.volumes.type: attribute set of attribute set of unspecifiedss

services.netdata.configText.example:
[global]
debug log = syslog
access log = syslog
error log = syslog

services.netdata.user.description: User account under which netdata runs.

services.networking.websockify.enable.description: Whether to enable websockify to forward websocket connections to TCP connections.

services.nexus.enable.description: Whether to enable SonarType Nexus3 OSS service.

services.nexus.home.description: Home directory of the Nexus3 instance.

services.nfs.server.createMountPoints.description: Whether to create the mount points in the exports file at startup time.

services.nfs.server.enable.description: Whether to enable the kernel's NFS server.

services.nfs.server.exports.description:
Contents of the /etc/exports file.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>exports</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry> for the format.

services.nfs.server.extraNfsdConfig.description: Extra configuration options for the [nfsd] section of /etc/nfs.conf.

services.nfs.server.hostName.description:
Hostname or address on which NFS requests will be accepted.
Default is all.  See the <option>-H</option> option in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>nfsd</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.nfs.server.lockdPort.description:
Use a fixed port for the NFS lock manager kernel module
(<literal>lockd/nlockmgr</literal>).  This is useful if the
NFS server is behind a firewall.

services.nfs.server.mountdPort.description: Use fixed port for rpc.mountd, useful if server is behind firewall.

services.nfs.server.nproc.description: Number of NFS server threads.  Defaults to the recommended value of 8.

services.nfs.server.statdPort.description:
Use a fixed port for <command>rpc.statd</command>. This is
useful if the NFS server is behind a firewall.

services.nginx.appendConfig.description:
Configuration lines appended to the generated Nginx
configuration file. Commonly used by different modules
providing http snippets. <option>appendConfig</option>
can be specified more than once and it's value will be
concatenated (contrary to <option>config</option> which
can be set only once).

services.nginx.appendHttpConfig.description:
Configuration lines to be appended to the generated http block.
          This is mutually exclusive with using config and httpConfig for
          specifying the whole http block verbatim.

services.nginx.commonHttpConfig.description:
With nginx you must provide common http context definitions before
they are used, e.g. log_format, resolver, etc. inside of server
or location contexts. Use this attribute to set these definitions
at the appropriate location.

services.nginx.config.description:
Verbatim nginx.conf configuration.
          This is mutually exclusive with the structured configuration
          via virtualHosts and the recommendedXyzSettings configuration
          options. See appendConfig for appending to the generated http block.

services.nginx.enable.description: Whether to enable Nginx Web Server.

services.nginx.eventsConfig.description: Configuration lines to be set inside the events block.

services.nginx.group.description: Group account under which nginx runs.

services.nginx.httpConfig.description:
Configuration lines to be set inside the http block.
          This is mutually exclusive with the structured configuration
          via virtualHosts and the recommendedXyzSettings configuration
          options. See appendHttpConfig for appending to the generated http block.

services.nginx.package.description:
Nginx package to use. This defaults to the stable version. Note
          that the nginx team recommends to use the mainline version which
          available in nixpkgs as <literal>nginxMainline</literal>.

services.nginx.proxyResolveWhileRunning.description:
Resolves domains of proxyPass targets at runtime
and not only at start, you have to set
services.nginx.resolver, too.

services.nginx.resolver.description: Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers into addresses

services.nginx.resolver.valid.description:
By default, nginx caches answers using the TTL value of a response.
An optional valid parameter allows overriding it

services.nginx.serverTokens.description: Show nginx version in headers and error pages.

services.nginx.sslCiphers.description: Ciphers to choose from when negotiating tls handshakes.

services.nginx.stateDir.description: Directory holding all state for nginx to run.

services.nginx.statusPage.description: Enable status page reachable from localhost on http://127.0.0.1/nginx_status.

services.nginx.upstreams.description: Defines a group of servers to use as proxy target.

services.nginx.upstreams.<name>.servers.description: Defines the address and other parameters of the upstream servers.

services.nginx.upstreams.<name>.servers..description:
Marks the server as a backup server. It will be passed
requests when the primary servers are unavailable.

services.nginx.user.description: User account under which nginx runs.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.acmeF.description:
Host which to proxy requests to if acme challenge is not found. Useful
if you want multiple hosts to be able to verify the same domain name.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.acmeR.description: Directory to store certificates and keys managed by the ACME service.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.addSS.description:
Whether to enable HTTPS in addition to plain HTTP. This will set defaults for
<literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on the respective default
ports (80, 443).

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.basic.description:
Basic Auth protection for a vhost.

WARNING: This is implemented to store the password in plain text in the
nix store.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.enabl.description: Whether to ask Let's Encrypt to sign a certificate for this vhost.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.extra.description: These lines go to the end of the vhost verbatim.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.force.description:
Whether to add a separate nginx server block that permanently redirects (301)
all plain HTTP traffic to HTTPS. This will set defaults for
<literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on the respective default
ports (80, 443), where the non-SSL listens are used for the redirect vhosts.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.globa.description:
If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to
the given hostname.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.liste.description:
Listen addresses and ports for this virtual host.
IPv6 addresses must be enclosed in square brackets.
Note: this option overrides <literal>addSSL</literal>
and <literal>onlySSL</literal>.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.locat.description: These lines go to the end of the location verbatim.

Adds proxy_pass directive and sets recommended proxy headers if
recommendedProxySettings is enabled.
Whether to supporty proxying websocket connections with HTTP/1.1.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.onlyS.description:
Whether to enable HTTPS and reject plain HTTP connections. This will set
defaults for <literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on port 443.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.root.description: The path of the web root directory.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.serve.description: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual host configuration.
Name of this virtual host. Defaults to attribute name in virtualHosts.

services.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.sslCe.description: Path to server SSL certificate key.

services.ngircd.enable.description: Whether to enable the ngircd IRC server.

services.nix-serve.bindAddress.description: IP address where nix-serve will bind its listening socket.

services.nix-serve.enable.description: Whether to enable nix-serve, the standalone Nix binary cache server.

services.nix-serve.extraParams.description: Extra command line parameters for nix-serve.

services.nix-serve.port.description: Port number where nix-serve will listen on.

services.nix-serve.secretKeyFile.description: The path to the file used for signing derivation data.

services.nixbot.botName.description: The bot's github user account name.

services.nixbot.githubToken.description: The bot's github user account token.

services.nixbot.hydraJobsetsRepo.description: The github repository to push the hydra jobset definitions to.

services.nixbot.prRepo.description: The github repository to push the testing branches to.

services.nixbot.publicUrl.description: The public URL the bot is reachable at (Github hook endpoint).

services.nixbot.repo.description: The github repository to check for PRs.

services.nixbot.repoDir.description: The directory the repositories are stored in.

services.nixosManual.browser.description: Browser used to show the manual.

services.nixosManual.enable.description: Whether to build the NixOS manual pages.

services.nixosManual.showManual.description:
Whether to show the NixOS manual on one of the virtual
consoles.

services.nixosManual.ttyNumber.description: Virtual console on which to show the manual.

services.nntp-proxy.listenAddress.description: Proxy listen address (IPv6 literal addresses need to be enclosed in "[" and "]" characters)

services.nntp-proxy.prohibitPosting.description: Whether to prohibit posting to the upstream server

services.nntp-proxy.upstreamMaxConnectio.description: Upstream server maximum allowed concurrent connections

services.nntp-proxy.users.<name>.maxConn.description: Maximum number of concurrent connections to the proxy for this user

services.nntp-proxy.users.<name>.passwor.description: SHA-512 password hash (can be generated by mkpasswd -m sha-512 <password>)

services.nscd.config.default:
server-user             nscd
threads                 1
paranoia                no
debug-level             0

enable-cache            passwd          yes
positive-time-to-live   passwd          600
negative-time-to-live   passwd          20
suggested-size          passwd          211
check-files             passwd          yes
persistent              passwd          no
shared                  passwd          yes

enable-cache            group           yes
positive-time-to-live   group           3600
negative-time-to-live   group           60
suggested-size          group           211
check-files             group           yes
persistent              group           no
shared                  group           yes

enable-cache            hosts           yes
positive-time-to-live   hosts           600
negative-time-to-live   hosts           5
suggested-size          hosts           211
check-files             hosts           yes
persistent              hosts           no
shared                  hosts           yes
services.nscd.config.description: Configuration to use for Name Service Cache Daemon.

services.nscd.enable.description: Whether to enable the Name Service Cache Daemon.

services.nsd.bind8Stats.description: Whether to enable BIND8 like statistics.

services.nsd.enable.description: Whether to enable NSD authoritative DNS server.

services.nsd.hideVersion.description: Whether NSD should answer VERSION.BIND and VERSION.SERVER CHAOS class queries.

services.nsd.identity.description: Identify the server (CH TXT ID.SERVER entry).

services.nsd.interfaces.description: What addresses the server should listen to.

services.nsd.ipFreebind.description:
Whether to bind to nonlocal addresses and interfaces that are down.
Similar to ip-transparent.

services.nsd.ipTransparent.description: Allow binding to non local addresses.

services.nsd.ipv4.description: Whether to listen on IPv4 connections.

services.nsd.ipv4EDNSSize.description: Preferred EDNS buffer size for IPv4.

services.nsd.ipv6.description: Whether to listen on IPv6 connections.

services.nsd.ipv6EDNSSize.description: Preferred EDNS buffer size for IPv6.

services.nsd.keys.<name>.keyFile.description:
Path to the file which contains the actual base64 encoded
key. The key will be copied into "/var/lib/nsd/private" before
NSD starts. The copied file is only accessibly by the NSD
user.

services.nsd.logTimeAscii.description: Log time in ascii, if false then in unix epoch seconds.

services.nsd.port.description: Port the service should bind do.

services.nsd.ratelimit.ipv4PrefixLength.description: IPv4 prefix length. Addresses are grouped by netblock.

services.nsd.ratelimit.ipv6PrefixLength.description: IPv6 prefix length. Addresses are grouped by netblock.

services.nsd.ratelimit.ratelimit.description:
Max qps allowed from any query source.
0 means unlimited. With an verbosity of 2 blocked and
unblocked subnets will be logged.

services.nsd.ratelimit.size.description:
Size of the hashtable. More buckets use more memory but lower
the chance of hash hash collisions.

services.nsd.ratelimit.slip.description:
Number of packets that get discarded before replying a SLIP response.
0 disables SLIP responses. 1 will make every response a SLIP response.

services.nsd.ratelimit.whitelistRatelimi.description:
Max qps allowed from whitelisted sources.
0 means unlimited. Set the rrl-whitelist option for specific
queries to apply this limit instead of the default to them.

services.nsd.remoteControl.controlCertFi.description:
Path to the client certificate signed with the server certificate.
This file is used by nsd-control and generated by nsd-control-setup.

services.nsd.remoteControl.controlKeyFil.description:
Path to the client private key, which is used by nsd-control
but not by the server. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.

services.nsd.remoteControl.enable.description: Whether to enable remote control via nsd-control.

services.nsd.remoteControl.interfaces.description: Which interfaces NSD should bind to for remote control.

services.nsd.remoteControl.port.description: Port number for remote control operations (uses TLS over TCP).

services.nsd.remoteControl.serverCertFil.description:
Path to the server self signed certificate, which is used by the server
but and by nsd-control. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.

services.nsd.remoteControl.serverKeyFile.description:
Path to the server private key, which is used by the server
but not by nsd-control. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.

services.nsd.reuseport.description:
Whether to enable SO_REUSEPORT on all used sockets. This lets multiple
processes bind to the same port. This speeds up operation especially
if the server count is greater than one and makes fast restarts less
prone to fail

services.nsd.rootServer.description:
Whether this server will be a root server (a DNS root server, you
usually don't want that).

services.nsd.roundRobin.description: Whether to enable round robin rotation of records.

services.nsd.serverCount.description: Number of NSD servers to fork. Put the number of CPUs to use here.

services.nsd.statistics.description:
Statistics are produced every number of seconds. Prints to log.
If null no statistics are logged.

services.nsd.tcpCount.description: Maximum number of concurrent TCP connections per server.

services.nsd.tcpQueryCount.description:
Maximum number of queries served on a single TCP connection.
0 means no maximum.

services.nsd.version.description:
The version string replied for CH TXT version.server and version.bind
queries. Will use the compiled package version on null.
See hideVersion for enabling/disabling this responses.

services.nsd.xfrdReloadTimeout.description: Number of seconds between reloads triggered by xfrd.

services.nsd.zonefilesCheck.description: Whether to check mtime of all zone files on start and sighup.

services.nsd.zones.description:
Define your zones here. Zones can cascade other zones and therefore
inherit settings from parent zones. Look at the definition of
children to learn about inheritance and child zones.
The given example will define 3 zones (example.(com|org|net).). Both
example.com. and example.org. inherit their configuration from
serverGroup1.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.allowAXFRFallb.description:
If NSD as secondary server should be allowed to AXFR if the primary
server does not allow IXFR.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.allowNotify.description:
Listed primary servers are allowed to notify this secondary server.
<screen><![CDATA[
Format: <ip> <key-name | NOKEY | BLOCKED>

<ip> either a plain IPv4/IPv6 address or range. Valid patters for ranges:
* 10.0.0.0/24            # via subnet size
* 10.0.0.0&255.255.255.0 # via subnet mask
* 10.0.0.1-10.0.0.254    # via range

A optional port number could be added with a '@':
* 2001:1234::1@1234

<key-name | NOKEY | BLOCKED>
* <key-name> will use the specified TSIG key
* NOKEY      no TSIG signature is required
* BLOCKED    notifies from non-listed or blocked IPs will be ignored
* ]]></screen>

services.nsd.zones.<name>.children.description:
Children zones inherit all options of their parents. Attributes
defined in a child will overwrite the ones of its parent. Only
leaf zones will be actually served. This way it's possible to
define maybe zones which share most attributes without
duplicating everything. This mechanism replaces nsd's patterns
in a save and functional way.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.data.description:
The actual zone data. This is the content of your zone file.
Use imports or pkgs.lib.readFile if you don't want this data in your config file.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.maxRefreshSecs.description:
Limit refresh time for secondary zones. This is the timer which
checks to see if the zone has to be refetched when it expires.
Normally the value from the SOA record is used, but this  option
restricts that value.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.maxRetrySecs.description:
Limit retry time for secondary zones. This is the timeout after
a failed fetch attempt for the zone. Normally the value from
the SOA record is used, but this option restricts that value.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.minRefreshSecs.description: Limit refresh time for secondary zones.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.minRetrySecs.description: Limit retry time for secondary zones.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.notify.description:
This primary server will notify all given secondary servers about
zone changes.
<screen><![CDATA[
Format: <ip> <key-name | NOKEY>

<ip> a plain IPv4/IPv6 address with on optional port number (ip@port)

<key-name | NOKEY>
* <key-name> sign notifies with the specified key
* NOKEY      don't sign notifies
]]></screen>

services.nsd.zones.<name>.notifyRetry.description: Specifies the number of retries for failed notifies. Set this along with notify.

services.nsd.zones.<name>.outgoingInterf.description:
This address will be used for zone-transfere requests if configured
as a secondary server or notifications in case of a primary server.
Supply either a plain IPv4 or IPv6 address with an optional port
number (ip@port).

services.nsd.zones.<name>.provideXFR.description:
Allow these IPs and TSIG to transfer zones, addr TSIG|NOKEY|BLOCKED
address range 192.0.2.0/24, 1.2.3.4&255.255.0.0, 3.0.2.20-3.0.2.40

services.nsd.zones.<name>.zoneStats.description:
When set to something distinct to null NSD is able to collect
statistics per zone. All statistics of this zone(s) will be added
to the group specified by this given name. Use "%s" to use the zones
name as the group. The groups are output from nsd-control stats
and stats_noreset.

services.ntopng.configText.description:
Overridable configuration file contents to use for ntopng. By
default, use the contents automatically generated by NixOS.

services.ntopng.enable.description:
Enable ntopng, a high-speed web-based traffic analysis and flow
collection tool.

With the default configuration, ntopng monitors all network
interfaces and displays its findings at http://localhost:3000. Default username and password is admin/admin.

See the ntopng(8) manual page and http://www.ntop.org/products/ntop/
for more info.

Note that enabling ntopng will also enable redis (key-value
database server) for persistent data storage.

services.ntopng.extraConfig.description:
Configuration lines that will be appended to the generated ntopng
configuration file. Note that this mechanism does not work when the
manual <option>configText</option> option is used.

services.ntopng.http-port.description: Sets the HTTP port of the embedded web server.

services.ntopng.interfaces.description: List of interfaces to monitor. Use "any" to monitor all interfaces.

services.ntp.enable.description:
Whether to synchronise your machine's time using the NTP
protocol.

services.ntp.extraFlags.description: Extra flags passed to the ntpd command.

services.ntp.servers.description: The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.

services.nullmailer.config.adminaddr.description:
If set, all recipients to users at either "localhost" (the literal string)
or the canonical host name (from the me control attribute) are remapped to this address.
This is provided to allow local daemons to be able to send email to
"somebody@localhost" and have it go somewhere sensible instead of being  bounced
by your relay host. To send to multiple addresses,
put them all on one line separated by a comma.

services.nullmailer.config.allmailfrom.description: If set, content will override the envelope sender on all messages.

services.nullmailer.config.defaultdomain.description:
The content of this attribute is appended to any host name that
does not contain a period (except localhost), including defaulthost
and idhost. Defaults to the value of the me attribute, if it exists,
otherwise the literal name defauldomain.

services.nullmailer.config.defaulthost.description:
The content of this attribute is appended to any address that
is missing a host name. Defaults to the value of the me control
attribute, if it exists, otherwise the literal name defaulthost.

services.nullmailer.config.doublebouncet.description:
If the original sender was empty (the original message was a
delivery status or disposition notification), the double bounce
is sent to the address in this attribute.

services.nullmailer.config.helohost.description:
Sets  the  environment variable $HELOHOST which is used by the
SMTP protocol module to set the parameter given to the HELO command.
Defaults to the value of the me configuration attribute.

services.nullmailer.config.idhost.description:
The content of this attribute is used when building the message-id
string for the message. Defaults to the canonicalized value of defaulthost.

services.nullmailer.config.maxpause.description:
The maximum time to pause between successive queue runs, in seconds.
Defaults to 24 hours (86400).

services.nullmailer.config.me.description:
The fully-qualifiled host name of the computer running nullmailer.
Defaults to the literal name me.

services.nullmailer.config.pausetime.description:
The minimum time to pause between successive queue runs when there
are messages in the queue, in seconds. Defaults to 1 minute (60).
Each time this timeout is reached, the timeout is doubled to a
maximum of maxpause. After new messages are injected, the timeout
is reset.  If this is set to 0, nullmailer-send will exit
immediately after going through the queue once (one-shot mode).

services.nullmailer.config.remotes.description: A list of remote servers to which to send each message. Each line contains a remote host name or address followed by an optional protocol string, separated by white space. See man 8 nullmailer-send for syntax and available options. WARNING: This is stored world-readable in the nix store. If you need to specify any secret credentials here, consider using the remotesFile option instead.

services.nullmailer.config.sendtimeout.description:
The  time to wait for a remote module listed above to complete sending
a message before killing it and trying again, in seconds.
Defaults to 1 hour (3600).  If this is set to 0, nullmailer-send
will wait forever for messages to complete sending.

services.nullmailer.group.description: Group to use to run nullmailer-send.

services.nullmailer.remotesFile.description: Path to the remotes control file. This file contains a list of remote servers to which to send each message. See man 8 nullmailer-send for syntax and available options.

services.nullmailer.setSendmail.description: Whether to set the system sendmail to nullmailer's.

services.nullmailer.user.description: User to use to run nullmailer-send.

services.nylon.<name?>.acceptInterface.description: Tell nylon which interface to listen for client requests on, default is "lo".

services.nylon.<name?>.allowedIPRanges.description:
Allowed client IP ranges are evaluated first, defaults to ARIN IPv4 private ranges:
  [ "192.168.0.0/16" "127.0.0.0/8" "172.16.0.0/12" "10.0.0.0/8" ]

services.nylon.<name?>.bindInterface.description: Tell nylon which interface to use as an uplink, default is "enp3s0f0".

services.nylon.<name?>.deniedIPRanges.description:
Denied client IP ranges, these gets evaluated after the allowed IP ranges, defaults to all IPv4 addresses:
  [ "0.0.0.0/0" ]
To block all other access than the allowed.

services.nylon.<name?>.enable.description: Enables nylon as a running service upon activation.

services.nylon.<name?>.logging.description: Enable logging, default is no logging.

services.nylon.<name?>.name.description: The name of this nylon instance.

services.nylon.<name?>.nrConnections.description: The number of allowed simultaneous connections to the daemon, default 10.

services.nylon.<name?>.port.description: What port to listen for client requests, default is 1080.

services.nylon.<name?>.verbosity.description: Enable verbose output, default is to not be verbose.

services.nzbget.user.description: User account under which NZBGet runs

services.oauth2_proxy.azure.tenant.description: Go to a tenant-specific or common (tenant-independent) endpoint.

services.oauth2_proxy.basicAuthPassword.description: The password to set when passing the HTTP Basic Auth header.

services.oauth2_proxy.cookie.domain.description: An optional cookie domain to force cookies to.

services.oauth2_proxy.cookie.name.description: The name of the cookie that the oauth_proxy creates.

services.oauth2_proxy.cookie.refresh.description: Refresh the cookie after this duration; 0 to disable.

services.oauth2_proxy.cookie.secret.description: The seed string for secure cookies.

services.oauth2_proxy.email.addresses.description: Line-separated email addresses that are allowed to authenticate.

services.oauth2_proxy.email.domains.description:
Authenticate emails with the specified domains. Use
<literal>*</literal> to authenticate any email.

services.oauth2_proxy.github.org.description: Restrict logins to members of this organisation.

services.oauth2_proxy.github.team.description: Restrict logins to members of this team.

services.oauth2_proxy.google.adminEmail.description:
The Google Admin to impersonate for API calls.

Only users with access to the Admin APIs can access the Admin SDK
Directory API, thus the service account needs to impersonate one of
those users to access the Admin SDK Directory API.

See <link xlink:href="https://developers.google.com/admin-sdk/directory/v1/guides/delegation#delegate_domain-wide_authority_to_your_service_account" />.

services.oauth2_proxy.google.groups.description: Restrict logins to members of these Google groups.

services.oauth2_proxy.google.serviceAcco.description: The path to the service account JSON credentials.

services.oauth2_proxy.htpasswd.displayFo.description: Display username / password login form if an htpasswd file is provided.

services.oauth2_proxy.htpasswd.file.description:
Additionally authenticate against a htpasswd file. Entries must be
created with <literal>htpasswd -s</literal> for SHA encryption.

services.oauth2_proxy.httpAddress.description:
HTTPS listening address.  This module does not expose the port by
default. If you want this URL to be accessible to other machines, please
add the port to <literal>networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts</literal>.

services.oauth2_proxy.loginURL.description:
Authentication endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.

services.oauth2_proxy.passAccessToken.description: Pass OAuth access_token to upstream via X-Forwarded-Access-Token header.

services.oauth2_proxy.passBasicAuth.description: Pass HTTP Basic Auth, X-Forwarded-User and X-Forwarded-Email information to upstream.

services.oauth2_proxy.passHostHeader.description: Pass the request Host Header to upstream.

services.oauth2_proxy.proxyPrefix.description: The url root path that this proxy should be nested under.

services.oauth2_proxy.redeemURL.description:
Token redemption endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.

services.oauth2_proxy.skipAuthRegexes.description:
Skip authentication for requests matching any of these regular
expressions.

services.oauth2_proxy.tls.httpsAddress.description:
<literal>addr:port</literal> to listen on for HTTPS clients.

Remember to add <literal>port</literal> to
<literal>allowedTCPPorts</literal> if you want other machines to be
able to connect to it.

services.oauth2_proxy.upstream.description:
The http url(s) of the upstream endpoint or <literal>file://</literal>
paths for static files. Routing is based on the path.

services.oauth2_proxy.validateURL.description:
Access token validation endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.

services.octoprint.enable.description: Whether to enable OctoPrint, web interface for 3D printers.

services.octoprint.extraConfig.description: Extra options which are added to OctoPrint's YAML configuration file.

services.offlineimap.enable.description: Whether to enable Offlineimap, a software to dispose your mailbox(es) as a local Maildir(s)..

services.offlineimap.install.description:
