Whether to install a user service for Offlineimap. Once
the service is started, emails will be fetched automatically.

The service must be manually started for each user with
"systemctl --user start offlineimap" or globally through
<varname>services.offlineimap.enable</varname>.

services.offlineimap.onCalendar.description: How often is offlineimap started. Default is '*:0/3' meaning every 3 minutes. See systemd.time(7) for more information about the format.

services.offlineimap.path.description: List of derivations to put in Offlineimap's path.

services.offlineimap.timeoutStartSec.description: How long waiting for offlineimap before killing it. Default is '120sec' meaning every 2 minutes. See systemd.time(7) for more information about the format.

services.oidentd.enable.description:
Whether to enable oidentd, an implementation of the Ident
protocol (RFC 1413).  It allows remote systems to identify the
name of the user associated with a TCP connection.

services.openafsClient.enable.description: Whether to enable the OpenAFS client.

services.opendkim.domains.description:
Local domains set (see <literal>opendkim(8)</literal> for more information on datasets).
Messages from them are signed, not verified.

services.opendkim.enable.description: Whether to enable the OpenDKIM sender authentication system.

services.opendkim.keyPath.description:
The path that opendkim should put its generated private keys into.
The DNS settings will be found in this directory with the name selector.txt.

services.opendkim.socket.description: Socket which is used for communication with OpenDKIM.

services.openfire.enable.description: Whether to enable OpenFire XMPP server.

services.openfire.usePostgreSQL.description: Whether you use PostgreSQL service for your storage back-end.

services.openldap.configDir.description: Use this optional config directory instead of using slapd.conf

services.openldap.enable.description: Whether to enable the ldap server.

example.text:
''
include ${pkgs.openldap.out}/etc/schema/core.schema
include ${pkgs.openldap.out}/etc/schema/cosine.schema
include ${pkgs.openldap.out}/etc/schema/inetorgperson.schema
include ${pkgs.openldap.out}/etc/schema/nis.schema

database bdb 
suffix dc=example,dc=org 
rootdn cn=admin,dc=example,dc=org 
# NOTE: change after first start
rootpw secret
directory /var/db/openldap
''

services.openldap.group.description: Group account under which slapd runs.

services.openldap.urlList.description: URL list slapd should listen on.

services.openldap.user.description: User account under which slapd runs.

services.openntpd.enable.description: Whether to enable OpenNTP time synchronization server.

services.openntpd.extraOptions.description: Extra options used when launching openntpd.

services.openntpd.servers.description: The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.

services.opensmtpd.addSendmailToSystemPa.description:
Whether to add OpenSMTPD's sendmail binary to the
system path or not.

services.opensmtpd.enable.description: Whether to enable the OpenSMTPD server.

services.opensmtpd.extraServerArgs.description:
Extra command line arguments provided when the smtpd process
is started.

services.opensmtpd.procPackages.description:
Packages to search for filters, tables, queues, and schedulers.

Add OpenSMTPD-extras here if you want to use the filters, etc. from
that package.

services.opensmtpd.serverConfiguration.description:
The contents of the smtpd.conf configuration file. See the
OpenSMTPD documentation for syntax information.
services.opensmtpd.serverConfiguration.example:
listen on lo
accept for any deliver to lmtp localhost:24

services.openssh.allowSFTP.description:
Whether to enable the SFTP subsystem in the SSH daemon.  This
enables the use of commands such as <command>sftp</command> and
<command>sshfs</command>.

services.openssh.authorizedKeysFiles.description: Files from which authorized keys are read.

services.openssh.challengeResponseAuthen.description: Specifies whether challenge/response authentication is allowed.

services.openssh.enable.description:
Whether to enable the OpenSSH secure shell daemon, which
allows secure remote logins.

services.openssh.forwardX11.description: Whether to allow X11 connections to be forwarded.

services.openssh.gatewayPorts.description:
Specifies whether remote hosts are allowed to connect to
ports forwarded for the client.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>sshd_config</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.openssh.hostKeys.description:
NixOS can automatically generate SSH host keys.  This option
specifies the path, type and size of each key.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>ssh-keygen</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry> for supported types
and sizes.

services.openssh.listenAddresses.description:
List of addresses and ports to listen on (ListenAddress directive
in config). If port is not specified for address sshd will listen
on all ports specified by <literal>ports</literal> option.
NOTE: this will override default listening on all local addresses and port 22.
NOTE: setting this option won't automatically enable given ports
in firewall configuration.

services.openssh.listenAddresses.*.addr.description: Host, IPv4 or IPv6 address to listen to.

services.openssh.moduliFile.description:
Path to <literal>moduli</literal> file to install in
<literal>/etc/ssh/moduli</literal>. If this option is unset, then
the <literal>moduli</literal> file shipped with OpenSSH will be used.

services.openssh.passwordAuthentication.description: Specifies whether password authentication is allowed.

services.openssh.permitRootLogin.description: Whether the root user can login using ssh.

services.openssh.ports.description: Specifies on which ports the SSH daemon listens.

services.openssh.sftpFlags.description: Commandline flags to add to sftp-server.

services.openssh.startWhenNeeded.description:
If set, <command>sshd</command> is socket-activated; that
is, instead of having it permanently running as a daemon,
systemd will start an instance for each incoming connection.

services.opentracker.extraOptions.description:
Configuration Arguments for opentracker
See https://erdgeist.org/arts/software/opentracker/ for all params

services.opentsdb.config.description: The contents of OpenTSDB's configuration file

services.opentsdb.group.description: Group account under which OpenTSDB runs.

services.opentsdb.user.description: User account under which OpenTSDB runs.

services.openvpn.servers.description:
Each attribute of this option defines a systemd service that
runs an OpenVPN instance.  These can be OpenVPN servers or
clients.  The name of each systemd service is
<literal>openvpn-<replaceable>name</replaceable>.service</literal>,
where <replaceable>name</replaceable> is the corresponding
attribute name.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.autoStar.description: Whether this OpenVPN instance should be started automatically.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.config.description:
Configuration of this OpenVPN instance.  See
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>openvpn</refentrytitle><manvolnum>8</manvolnum></citerefentry>
for details.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.down.description: Shell commands executed when the instance is shutting down.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.up.description: Shell commands executed when the instance is starting.

services.openvpn.servers.<name>.updateRe.description:
Use the script from the update-resolv-conf package to automatically
update resolv.conf with the DNS information provided by openvpn. The
script will be run after the "up" commands and before the "down" commands.

services.osquery.extraConfig.description: Extra config to be recursively merged into the JSON config file.

services.osquery.utc.description: Attempt to convert all UNIX calendar times to UTC.

services.ostinato.portList.exclude.description: A list of ports does not appear on the port list managed by drone.

services.ostinato.portList.include.description:
For a port to pass the filter and appear on the port list managed
by drone, it be allowed by this include list.

services.ostinato.rateAccuracy.description:
To ensure that the actual transmit rate is as close as possible to
the configured transmit rate, Drone runs a busy-wait loop.
While this provides the maximum accuracy possible, the CPU
utilization is 100% while the transmit is on. You can however,
sacrifice the accuracy to reduce the CPU load.

services.ostinato.rpcServer.address.description:
By default, the Drone RPC server will listen on all interfaces and
local IPv4 adresses for incoming connections from clients.  Specify
a single IPv4 or IPv6 address if you want to restrict that.
To listen on any IPv6 address, use ::

services.packagekit.enable.description:
Whether to enable PackageKit provides a cross-platform D-Bus abstraction layer for
installing software. Software utilizing PackageKit can install
software regardless of the package manager.
.

services.parsoid.enable.description:
Whether to enable Parsoid -- bidirectional
wikitext parser.

services.parsoid.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to parsoid configuration.

services.parsoid.wikis.type: list of string or attribute sets

services.pcscd.plugins.description: Plugin packages to be used for PCSC-Lite.

services.pcscd.readerConfig.description:
Configuration for devices that aren't hotpluggable.

See <citerefentry><refentrytitle>reader.conf</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>5</manvolnum></citerefentry> for valid options.
services.pcscd.readerConfig.example:
FRIENDLYNAME      "Some serial reader"
DEVICENAME        /dev/ttyS0
LIBPATH           /path/to/serial_reader.so
CHANNELID         1

services.pdns-recursor.api.address.description: IP address Recursor REST API server will bind to.

services.pdns-recursor.api.allowFrom.description: IP address ranges of clients allowed to make API requests.

services.pdns-recursor.api.port.description: Port number Recursor REST API server will bind to.

services.pdns-recursor.dns.address.description: IP address Recursor DNS server will bind to.

services.pdns-recursor.dns.allowFrom.description: IP address ranges of clients allowed to make DNS queries.

services.pdns-recursor.dns.port.description: Port number Recursor DNS server will bind to.

services.pdns-recursor.dnssecValidation.description:
Controls the level of DNSSEC processing done by the PowerDNS Recursor.
See https://doc.powerdns.com/md/recursor/dnssec/ for a detailed explanation.

services.pdns-recursor.enable.description: Whether to enable PowerDNS Recursor, a recursive DNS server.

services.pdns-recursor.exportHosts.description: Whether to export names and IP addresses defined in /etc/hosts.

services.pdns-recursor.extraConfig.description: Extra options to be appended to the configuration file.

services.pdns-recursor.forwardZones.description: DNS zones to be forwarded to other servers.

services.pdns-recursor.resolveDNSChainQu.description: Resolve <literal>.bit</literal> top-level domains using DNSChain and namecoin.

services.pdns-recursor.serveRFC1918.description:
Whether to directly resolve the RFC1918 reverse-mapping domains:
<literal>10.in-addr.arpa</literal>,
<literal>168.192.in-addr.arpa</literal>,
<literal>16-31.172.in-addr.arpa</literal>
This saves load on the AS112 servers.

services.pdnsd.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration directives that should be added to
<literal>pdnsd.conf</literal>.

services.pdnsd.globalConfig.description:
Global configuration that should be added to the global directory
of <literal>pdnsd.conf</literal>.

services.pdnsd.serverConfig.description:
Server configuration that should be added to the server directory
of <literal>pdnsd.conf</literal>.

services.pfix-srsd.domain.description: The domain for which to enable srs

services.pfix-srsd.enable.description: Whether to run the postfix sender rewriting scheme daemon.

services.pfix-srsd.secretsFile.description:
The secret data used to encode the SRS address.
to generate, use a command like:
<literal>for n in $(seq 5); do dd if=/dev/urandom count=1 bs=1024 status=none | sha256sum | sed 's/  -$//' | sed 's/^/          /'; done</literal>

services.pgmanage.allowCustomConnections.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to allow anyone to use a custom
connection from the login screen.

services.pgmanage.connections.description:
pgmanage requires at least one PostgreSQL server be defined.
</para><para>
Detailed information about PostgreSQL connection strings is available at:
<link xlink:href="http://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/libpq-connect.html"/>
</para><para>
Note that you should not specify your user name or password. That
information will be entered on the login screen. If you specify a
username or password, it will be removed by pgmanage before attempting to
connect to a database.

services.pgmanage.dataRoot.description:
This tells pgmanage where to put the SQL file history. All tabs are saved
to this location so that if you get disconnected from pgmanage you
don't lose your work.

services.pgmanage.enable.description: Whether to enable PostgreSQL Administration for the web.

services.pgmanage.localOnly.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to set the listening socket to local
addresses only.

services.pgmanage.loginGroup.description:
This tells pgmanage to only allow users in a certain PostgreSQL group to
login to pgmanage. Note that a connection will be made to PostgreSQL in
order to test if the user is a member of the login group.

services.pgmanage.loginTimeout.description:
Number of seconds of inactivity before user is automatically logged
out.

services.pgmanage.port.description: This tells pgmanage what port to listen on for browser requests.

services.pgmanage.superOnly.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to only allow super users to
login. The recommended value is true and will restrict users who are not
super users from logging in to any PostgreSQL instance through
pgmanage. Note that a connection will be made to PostgreSQL in order to
test if the user is a superuser.

services.pgmanage.tls.description:
These options tell pgmanage where the TLS Certificate and Key files
reside. If you use these options then you'll only be able to access
pgmanage through a secure TLS connection. These options are only
necessary if you wish to connect directly to pgmanage using a secure TLS
connection. As an alternative, you can set up pgmanage in a reverse proxy
configuration. This allows your web server to terminate the secure
connection and pass on the request to pgmanage. You can find help to set
up this configuration in:
<link xlink:href="https://github.com/pgManage/pgManage/blob/master/INSTALL_NGINX.md"/>

services.pgpkeyserver-lite.enable.description: Whether to enable pgpkeyserver-lite on a nginx vHost proxying to a gpg keyserver.

services.pgpkeyserver-lite.hkpAddress.description: Wich ip address the sks-keyserver is listening on.

services.pgpkeyserver-lite.hkpPort.description: Which port the sks-keyserver is listening on.

services.pgpkeyserver-lite.hostname.description: Which hostname to set the vHost to that is proxying to sks.

services.phpfpm.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration that should be put in the global section of
the PHP-FPM configuration file. Do not specify the options
<literal>error_log</literal> or
<literal>daemonize</literal> here, since they are generated by
NixOS.

services.phpfpm.phpOptions.description: Options appended to the PHP configuration file <filename>php.ini</filename>.

services.phpfpm.phpPackage.description: The PHP package to use for running the PHP-FPM service.

services.phpfpm.poolConfigs.description:
A mapping between PHP-FPM pool names and their configurations.
See the documentation on <literal>php-fpm.conf</literal> for
details on configuration directives. If no pools are defined,
the phpfpm service is disabled.

example.text:
{ mypool = ''
    listen = /run/phpfpm/mypool
    user = nobody
    pm = dynamic
    pm.max_children = 75
    pm.start_servers = 10
    pm.min_spare_servers = 5
    pm.max_spare_servers = 20
    pm.max_requests = 500
  '';
}

services.phpfpm.pools.description:
PHP-FPM pools. If no pools or poolConfigs are defined, the PHP-FPM
service is disabled.

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.extraConfig.description:
Extra lines that go into the pool configuration.
See the documentation on <literal>php-fpm.conf</literal> for
details on configuration directives.
services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.extraConfig.example:
user = nobody
pm = dynamic
pm.max_children = 75
pm.start_servers = 10
pm.min_spare_servers = 5
pm.max_spare_servers = 20
pm.max_requests = 500

services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.listen.description: The address on which to accept FastCGI requests.

services.physlock.disableSysRq.description: Whether to disable SysRq when locked with physlock.

services.physlock.enable.description:
Whether to enable the <command>physlock</command> screen locking mechanism.

Enable this and then run <command>systemctl start physlock</command>
to securely lock the screen.

This will switch to a new virtual terminal, turn off console
switching and disable SysRq mechanism (when
<option>services.physlock.disableSysRq</option> is set)
until the root or user password is given.

services.physlock.lockOn.extraTargets.description:
Other targets to lock the screen just before.

Useful if you want to e.g. both autologin to X11 so that
your <filename>~/.xsession</filename> gets executed and
still to have the screen locked so that the system can be
booted relatively unattended.

services.physlock.lockOn.hibernate.description: Whether to lock screen with physlock just before hibernate.

services.physlock.lockOn.suspend.description: Whether to lock screen with physlock just before suspend.

services.piwik.enable.description:
Enable piwik web analytics with php-fpm backend.
Either the nginx option or the webServerUser option is mandatory.

services.piwik.nginx.description:
With this option, you can customize an nginx virtualHost which already has sensible defaults for piwik.
Either this option or the webServerUser option is mandatory.
Set this to {} to just enable the virtualHost if you don't need any customization.
If enabled, then by default, the serverName is piwik.$\{config.networking.hostName\}, SSL is active,
and certificates are acquired via ACME.
If this is set to null (the default), no nginx virtualHost will be configured.

services.piwik.nginx.acmeFallbackHost.description:
Host which to proxy requests to if acme challenge is not found. Useful
if you want multiple hosts to be able to verify the same domain name.

services.piwik.nginx.acmeRoot.description: Directory to store certificates and keys managed by the ACME service.

services.piwik.nginx.addSSL.description:
Whether to enable HTTPS in addition to plain HTTP. This will set defaults for
<literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on the respective default
ports (80, 443).

services.piwik.nginx.basicAuth.description:
Basic Auth protection for a vhost.

WARNING: This is implemented to store the password in plain text in the
nix store.

services.piwik.nginx.enableACME.description: Whether to ask Let's Encrypt to sign a certificate for this vhost.

services.piwik.nginx.extraConfig.description: These lines go to the end of the vhost verbatim.

services.piwik.nginx.forceSSL.description:
Whether to add a separate nginx server block that permanently redirects (301)
all plain HTTP traffic to HTTPS. This will set defaults for
<literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on the respective default
ports (80, 443), where the non-SSL listens are used for the redirect vhosts.

services.piwik.nginx.globalRedirect.description:
If set, all requests for this host are redirected permanently to
the given hostname.

services.piwik.nginx.listen.description:
Listen addresses and ports for this virtual host.
IPv6 addresses must be enclosed in square brackets.
Note: this option overrides <literal>addSSL</literal>
and <literal>onlySSL</literal>.

services.piwik.nginx.locations.<name>.ex.description: These lines go to the end of the location verbatim.

services.piwik.nginx.locations.<name>.pr.description:
Adds proxy_pass directive and sets recommended proxy headers if
recommendedProxySettings is enabled.
Whether to supporty proxying websocket connections with HTTP/1.1.

services.piwik.nginx.onlySSL.description:
Whether to enable HTTPS and reject plain HTTP connections. This will set
defaults for <literal>listen</literal> to listen on all interfaces on port 443.

services.piwik.nginx.root.description: The path of the web root directory.

services.piwik.nginx.serverAliases.description: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual host configuration.

services.piwik.nginx.serverName.description: Name of this virtual host. Defaults to attribute name in virtualHosts.

services.piwik.nginx.sslCertificateKey.description: Path to server SSL certificate key.

services.piwik.phpfpmProcessManagerConfi.default:
; default phpfpm process manager settings
pm = dynamic
pm.max_children = 75
pm.start_servers = 10
pm.min_spare_servers = 5
pm.max_spare_servers = 20
pm.max_requests = 500

; log worker's stdout, but this has a performance hit
catch_workers_output = yes
services.piwik.phpfpmProcessManagerConfi.description: Settings for phpfpm's process manager. You might need to change this depending on the load for piwik.

services.piwik.webServerUser.description:
Name of the web server user that forwards requests to the /run/phpfpm-piwik.sock fastcgi socket for piwik if the nginx
option is not used. Either this option or the nginx option is mandatory.
If you want to use another webserver than nginx, you need to set this to that server's user
and pass fastcgi requests to `index.php` and `piwik.php` to this socket.

services.plex.dataDir.description: The directory where Plex stores its data files.

services.plex.enable.description: Whether to enable Plex Media Server.

services.plex.extraPlugins.description:
A list of paths to extra plugin bundles to install in Plex's plugin
directory. Every time the systemd unit for Plex starts up, all of the
symlinks in Plex's plugin directory will be cleared and this module
will symlink all of the paths specified here to that directory. If
this behavior is undesired, set <option>managePlugins</option> to
false.

services.plex.managePlugins.description:
If set to true, this option will cause all of the symlinks in Plex's
plugin directory to be removed and symlinks for paths specified in
<option>extraPlugins</option> to be added.

services.plex.openFirewall.description: Open ports in the firewall for the media server

services.plex.package.description:
The Plex package to use. Plex subscribers may wish to use their own
package here, pointing to subscriber-only server versions.

services.plex.user.description: User account under which Plex runs.

services.plexpy.configFile.description: The location of PlexPy's config file.

services.plexpy.dataDir.description: The directory where PlexPy stores its data files.

services.plexpy.enable.description: Whether to enable PlexPy Plex Monitor.

services.plexpy.user.description: User account under which PlexPy runs.

services.polipo.allowedClients.description: List of IP addresses or network addresses that may connect to Polipo.

services.polipo.enable.description: Whether to run the polipo caching web proxy.

services.polipo.extraConfig.description:
Polio configuration. Contents will be added 
verbatim to the configuration file.

services.polipo.parentProxy.description:
Hostname and port number of an HTTP parent proxy;
it should have the form host:port.

services.polipo.proxyAddress.description: IP address on which Polipo will listen.

services.polipo.proxyPort.description: TCP port on which Polipo will listen.

services.polipo.socksParentProxy.description:
Hostname and port number of an SOCKS parent proxy;
it should have the form host:port.

services.postage.allowCustomConnections.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to allow anyone to use a custom
connection from the login screen.

services.postage.connections.description:
pgmanage requires at least one PostgreSQL server be defined.
</para><para>
Detailed information about PostgreSQL connection strings is available at:
<link xlink:href="http://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/libpq-connect.html"/>
</para><para>
Note that you should not specify your user name or password. That
information will be entered on the login screen. If you specify a
username or password, it will be removed by pgmanage before attempting to
connect to a database.

services.postage.dataRoot.description:
This tells pgmanage where to put the SQL file history. All tabs are saved
to this location so that if you get disconnected from pgmanage you
don't lose your work.

services.postage.enable.description: Whether to enable PostgreSQL Administration for the web.

services.postage.localOnly.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to set the listening socket to local
addresses only.

services.postage.loginGroup.description:
This tells pgmanage to only allow users in a certain PostgreSQL group to
login to pgmanage. Note that a connection will be made to PostgreSQL in
order to test if the user is a member of the login group.

services.postage.loginTimeout.description:
Number of seconds of inactivity before user is automatically logged
out.

services.postage.port.description: This tells pgmanage what port to listen on for browser requests.

services.postage.superOnly.description:
This tells pgmanage whether or not to only allow super users to
login. The recommended value is true and will restrict users who are not
super users from logging in to any PostgreSQL instance through
pgmanage. Note that a connection will be made to PostgreSQL in order to
test if the user is a superuser.

services.postage.tls.description:
These options tell pgmanage where the TLS Certificate and Key files
reside. If you use these options then you'll only be able to access
pgmanage through a secure TLS connection. These options are only
necessary if you wish to connect directly to pgmanage using a secure TLS
connection. As an alternative, you can set up pgmanage in a reverse proxy
configuration. This allows your web server to terminate the secure
connection and pass on the request to pgmanage. You can find help to set
up this configuration in:
<link xlink:href="https://github.com/pgManage/pgManage/blob/master/INSTALL_NGINX.md"/>

services.postfix.aliasFiles.description: Aliases' tables to be compiled and placed into /var/lib/postfix/conf.

services.postfix.aliasMapType.description: The format the alias map should have. Use regexp if you want to use regular expressions.

services.postfix.config.description: The main.cf configuration file as key value set.
services.postfix.config.type: attribute set of boolean or string or list of stringss

services.postfix.destination.description:
Full (!) list of domains we deliver locally. Leave blank for
          acceptable Postfix default.

services.postfix.dnsBlacklistOverrides.description: contents of check_client_access for overriding dnsBlacklists

services.postfix.dnsBlacklists.description: dns blacklist servers to use with smtpd_client_restrictions

services.postfix.domain.description: Domain to use. Leave blank to use hostname minus first component.

services.postfix.enable.description: Whether to run the Postfix mail server.

services.postfix.enableHeaderChecks.description: Whether to enable postfix header checks

services.postfix.enableSmtp.description: Whether to enable smtp in master.cf.

services.postfix.extraAliases.description: Additional entries to put verbatim into aliases file, cf. man-page aliases(8).

services.postfix.extraConfig.description: Extra lines to be added verbatim to the main.cf configuration file.

services.postfix.extraMasterConf.description: Extra lines to append to the generated master.cf file.

services.postfix.group.description: What to call the Postfix group (must be used only for postfix).

services.postfix.headerChecks.*.action.description: The action to be executed when the pattern is matched

services.postfix.headerChecks.*.pattern.description: A regexp pattern matching the header

services.postfix.hostname.description:
Hostname to use. Leave blank to use just the hostname of machine.
          It should be FQDN.

services.postfix.lookupMX.description: Whether relay specified is just domain whose MX must be used.

services.postfix.mapFiles.description: Maps to be compiled and placed into /var/lib/postfix/conf.

services.postfix.masterConfig.description:
An attribute set of service options, which correspond to the service
definitions usually done within the Postfix
<filename>master.cf</filename> file.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.arg.description:
Arguments to pass to the <option>command</option>. There is no shell
processing involved and shell syntax is passed verbatim to the
process.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.chr.description:
Whether the service is chrooted to have only access to the
<option>services.postfix.queueDir</option> and the closure of
store paths specified by the <option>program</option> option.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.com.description:
A program name specifying a Postfix service/daemon process.
By default it's the attribute <option>name</option>.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.max.description:
The maximum number of processes to spawn for this service. If the
value is <literal>0</literal> it doesn't have any limit. If
<literal>null</literal> is given it uses the postfix default of
<literal>100</literal>.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.nam.description: The name of the service to run. Defaults to the attribute set key.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.pri.description:
Whether the service's sockets and storage directory is restricted to
be only available via the mail system. If <literal>null</literal> is
given it uses the postfix default <literal>true</literal>.

services.postfix.masterConfig.<name>.wak.description:
Automatically wake up the service after the specified number of
seconds. If <literal>0</literal> is given, never wake the service
up.

If set to <literal>false</literal> the component will only be woken
up if it is used. This is equivalent to postfix' notion of adding a
question mark behind the wakeup time in
<filename>master.cf</filename>

services.postfix.networks.description:
Net masks for trusted - allowed to relay mail to third parties -
          hosts. Leave empty to use mynetworks_style configuration or use
          default (localhost-only).

services.postfix.networksStyle.description:
Name of standard way of trusted network specification to use,
          leave blank if you specify it explicitly or if you want to use
          default (localhost-only).

services.postfix.origin.description: Origin to use in outgoing e-mail. Leave blank to use hostname.

services.postfix.recipientDelimiter.description: Delimiter for address extension: so mail to user+test can be handled by ~user/.forward+test

services.postfix.relayDomains.description: List of domains we agree to relay to. Default is empty.

services.postfix.relayPort.description: SMTP port for relay mail relay.

services.postfix.rootAlias.description: Who should receive root e-mail. Blank for no redirection.

services.postfix.setSendmail.description: Whether to set the system sendmail to postfix's.

services.postfix.setgidGroup.description:
How to call postfix setgid group (for postdrop). Should
          be uniquely used group.

services.postfix.submissionOptions.description: Options for the submission config in master.cf

services.postfix.transport.description: Entries for the transport map, cf. man-page transport(8).

services.postfix.useSrs.description: Whether to enable sender rewriting scheme

services.postfix.user.description: What to call the Postfix user (must be used only for postfix).

services.postfix.virtual.description: Entries for the virtual alias map, cf. man-page virtual(8).

services.postfix.virtualMapType.description: What type of virtual alias map file to use. Use <literal>"regexp"</literal> for regular expressions.

services.postgresql.authentication.description:
Defines how users authenticate themselves to the server. By
default, "trust" access to local users will always be granted
along with any other custom options. If you do not want this,
set this option using "lib.mkForce" to override this
behaviour.

services.postgresql.enableTCPIP.description:
Whether PostgreSQL should listen on all network interfaces.
If disabled, the database can only be accessed via its Unix
domain socket or via TCP connections to localhost.

services.postgresql.extraConfig.description: Additional text to be appended to <filename>postgresql.conf</filename>.

services.postgresql.extraPlugins.description:
When this list contains elements a new store path is created.
PostgreSQL and the elements are symlinked into it. Then pg_config,
postgres and pg_ctl are copied to make them use the new
$out/lib directory as pkglibdir. This makes it possible to use postgis
without patching the .sql files which reference $libdir/postgis-1.5.

services.postgresql.identMap.description: Defines the mapping from system users to database users.

services.postgresql.initialScript.description: A file containing SQL statements to execute on first startup.

services.postgresql.port.description: The port on which PostgreSQL listens.

services.postgresqlBackup.databases.description: List of database names to dump.

services.postgresqlBackup.location.description: Location to put the gzipped PostgreSQL database dumps.

services.postgresqlBackup.period.description:
This option defines (in the format used by cron) when the
databases should be dumped.
The default is to update at 01:15 (at night) every day.

services.postgrey.IPv4CIDR.description: Strip N bits from IPv4 addresses if lookupBySubnet is true

services.postgrey.IPv6CIDR.description: Strip N bits from IPv6 addresses if lookupBySubnet is true

services.postgrey.autoWhitelist.description: Whitelist clients after successful delivery of N messages

services.postgrey.enable.description: Whether to run the Postgrey daemon

services.postgrey.greylistAction.description: Response status for greylisted messages (see access(5))

services.postgrey.greylistHeader.default: X-Greylist: delayed %%t seconds by postgrey-%%v at %%h; %%d
services.postgrey.greylistHeader.description: Prepend header to greylisted mails; use %%t for seconds delayed due to greylisting, %%v for the version of postgrey, %%d for the date, and %%h for the host

services.postgrey.greylistText.description: Response status text for greylisted messages; use %%s for seconds left until greylisting is over and %%r for mail domain of recipient

services.postgrey.lookupBySubnet.description: Strip the last N bits from IP addresses, determined by IPv4CIDR and IPv6CIDR

services.postgrey.maxAge.description: Delete entries from whitelist if they haven't been seen for N days

services.postgrey.privacy.description: Store data using one-way hash functions (SHA1)

services.postgrey.retryWindow.description: Allow N days for the first retry. Use string with appended 'h' to specify time in hours

services.postsrsd.enable.description: Whether to enable the postsrsd SRS server for Postfix.

services.postsrsd.excludeDomains.description: Origin domains to exclude from rewriting in addition to primary domain

services.postsrsd.forwardPort.description: Port for the forward SRS lookup

services.postsrsd.reversePort.description: Port for the reverse SRS lookup

services.postsrsd.secretsFile.description: Secret keys used for signing and verification

services.postsrsd.separator.description: First separator character in generated addresses

services.postsrsd.timeout.description: Timeout for idle client connections in seconds

services.powerdns.enable.description: Whether to enable Powerdns domain name server.

services.powerdns.extraConfig.description:
Extra lines to be added verbatim to pdns.conf.
Powerdns will chroot to /var/lib/powerdns.
So any file, powerdns is supposed to be read,
should be in /var/lib/powerdns and needs to specified
relative to the chroot.

services.pptpd.clientIpRange.description: The range from which client IPs are drawn.

services.pptpd.enable.description: Whether to enable Whether pptpd should be run on startup..

services.pptpd.extraPppdOptions.description: Adds extra lines to the pppd options file.

services.pptpd.extraPptpdOptions.description: Adds extra lines to the pptpd configuration file.

services.pptpd.maxClients.description: The maximum number of simultaneous connections.

services.prayer.enable.description: Whether to run the prayer webmail http server.

services.prayer.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the configuration file.

services.prayer.port.description: Port the prayer http server is listening to.

services.prey.deviceKey.description:
<literal>Device key</literal> obtained by visiting
<link xlink:href="https://panel.preyproject.com/devices" />
and clicking on your device.

services.prey.enable.description:
Enables the <link xlink:href="http://preyproject.com/" />
shell client. Be sure to specify both API and device keys.
Once enabled, a <command>cron</command> job will run every 15
minutes to report status information.

services.printing.browsedConf.description:
The contents of the configuration. file of the CUPS Browsed daemon
(<filename>cups-browsed.conf</filename>)

services.printing.browsing.description: Specifies whether shared printers are advertised.

services.printing.clientConf.description:
The contents of the client configuration.
(<filename>client.conf</filename>)

services.printing.defaultShared.description: Specifies whether local printers are shared by default.

services.printing.drivers.description:
CUPS drivers to use. Drivers provided by CUPS, cups-filters,
Ghostscript and Samba are added unconditionally. If this list contains
Gutenprint (i.e. a derivation with
<literal>meta.isGutenprint = true</literal>) the PPD files in
<filename>/var/lib/cups/ppd</filename> will be updated automatically
to avoid errors due to incompatible versions.

services.printing.enable.description: Whether to enable printing support through the CUPS daemon.

services.printing.extraConf.description:
Extra contents of the configuration file of the CUPS daemon
(<filename>cupsd.conf</filename>).

services.printing.extraFilesConf.description:
Extra contents of the configuration file of the CUPS daemon
(<filename>cups-files.conf</filename>).

services.printing.listenAddresses.description: A list of addresses and ports on which to listen.

services.printing.snmpConf.description:
The contents of <filename>/etc/cups/snmp.conf</filename>. See "man
cups-snmp.conf" for a complete description.

services.printing.webInterface.description: Specifies whether the web interface is enabled.

services.privoxy.actionsFiles.description:
List of paths to Privoxy action files.
These paths may either be absolute or relative to the privoxy configuration directory.

services.privoxy.enable.description: Whether to enable the Privoxy non-caching filtering proxy.

services.privoxy.enableEditActions.description: Whether or not the web-based actions file editor may be used.

services.privoxy.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the configuration file.

services.privoxy.filterFiles.description:
List of paths to Privoxy filter files.
These paths may either be absolute or relative to the privoxy configuration directory.

services.privoxy.listenAddress.description: Address the proxy server is listening to.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.configT.description:
Alertmanager configuration as YAML text. If non-null, this option
defines the text that is written to alertmanager.yml. If null, the
contents of alertmanager.yml is generated from the structured config
options.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.configu.description: Alertmanager configuration as nix attribute set.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.group.description: Group under which Alertmanager shall be run.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.listenA.description: Address to listen on for the web interface and API.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.logForm.description: If set use a syslog logger or JSON logging.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.logLeve.description: Only log messages with the given severity or above.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.openFir.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.port.description: Port to listen on for the web interface and API.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.user.description: User name under which Alertmanager shall be run.

services.prometheus.alertmanager.webExte.description:
The URL under which Alertmanager is externally reachable (for example, if Alertmanager is served via a reverse proxy).
Used for generating relative and absolute links back to Alertmanager itself.
If the URL has a path portion, it will be used to prefix all HTTP endoints served by Alertmanager.
If omitted, relevant URL components will be derived automatically.

services.prometheus.alertmanagerNotifica.description: The capacity of the queue for pending alert manager notifications.

services.prometheus.alertmanagerTimeout.description: Alert manager HTTP API timeout (in seconds).

services.prometheus.alertmanagerURL.description: List of Alertmanager URLs to send notifications to.

services.prometheus.blackboxExporter.ena.description: Whether to enable prometheus blackbox exporter.

services.prometheus.blackboxExporter.ext.description: Extra commandline options when launching the blackbox exporter.

services.prometheus.blackboxExporter.ope.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.collectdExporter.col.description: File mapping user names to pre-shared keys (passwords).
Whether to enable collectd binary protocol receiver.
Address to listen on for binary network packets.
Network address on which to accept collectd binary network packets.
Minimum required security level for accepted packets.

services.prometheus.collectdExporter.ena.description: Whether to enable prometheus collectd exporter.

services.prometheus.collectdExporter.ext.description: Extra commandline options when launching the collectd exporter.

services.prometheus.collectdExporter.lis.description: Address to listen on for web interface, telemetry and collectd JSON data.

services.prometheus.collectdExporter.log.description: Set the log target and format.
Only log messages with the given severity or above.

services.prometheus.collectdExporter.ope.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.collectdExporter.por.description:
Port to listen on.
This is used for scraping as well as the to receive collectd data via the write_http plugin.

services.prometheus.configText.description:
If non-null, this option defines the text that is written to
prometheus.yml. If null, the contents of prometheus.yml is generated
from the structured config options.

services.prometheus.dataDir.description: Directory to store Prometheus metrics data.

services.prometheus.extraFlags.description: Extra commandline options when launching Prometheus.

services.prometheus.fritzboxExporter.ena.description: Whether to enable prometheus fritzbox exporter.

services.prometheus.fritzboxExporter.ext.description: Extra commandline options when launching the fritzbox exporter.

services.prometheus.fritzboxExporter.gat.description: The hostname or IP of the FRITZ!Box.
The port of the FRITZ!Box UPnP service.

services.prometheus.fritzboxExporter.ope.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.globalConfig.description:
Parameters that are valid in all  configuration contexts. They
also serve as defaults for other configuration sections

services.prometheus.globalConfig.evaluat.description: How frequently to evaluate rules by default.

services.prometheus.globalConfig.scrape_.description: How frequently to scrape targets by default.
How long until a scrape request times out.

services.prometheus.jsonExporter.enable.description: Whether to enable prometheus JSON exporter.

services.prometheus.jsonExporter.extraFl.description: Extra commandline options when launching the JSON exporter.

services.prometheus.jsonExporter.openFir.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.listenAddress.description: Address to listen on for the web interface, API, and telemetry.

services.prometheus.minioExporter.enable.description: Whether to enable prometheus minio exporter.

services.prometheus.minioExporter.extraF.description: Extra commandline options when launching the minio exporter.

services.prometheus.minioExporter.listen.description: Address to listen on for web interface and telemetry.

services.prometheus.minioExporter.minioA.description:
The value of the Minio access key.
It is required in order to connect to the server.
By default this uses the one from the local minio server if enabled
and <literal>config.services.minio.accessKey</literal>.

The calue of the Minio access secret.
It is required in order to connect to the server.
By default this uses the one from the local minio server if enabled
and <literal>config.services.minio.secretKey</literal>.

The URL of the minio server.
Use HTTPS if Minio accepts secure connections only.
By default this connects to the local minio server if enabled.

services.prometheus.minioExporter.minioB.description:
Collect statistics about the buckets and files in buckets.
It requires more computation, use it carefully in case of large buckets..

services.prometheus.minioExporter.openFi.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.nginxExporter.enable.description: Whether to enable prometheus nginx exporter.

services.prometheus.nginxExporter.extraF.description: Extra commandline options when launching the nginx exporter.

services.prometheus.nginxExporter.openFi.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.nginxExporter.scrape.description:
Address to access the nginx status page.
Can be enabled with services.nginx.statusPage = true.

services.prometheus.nodeExporter.disable.description: Collectors to disable which are enabled by default.

services.prometheus.nodeExporter.enable.description: Whether to enable prometheus node exporter.

services.prometheus.nodeExporter.enabled.description: Collectors to enable. The collectors listed here are enabled in addition to the default ones.

services.prometheus.nodeExporter.extraFl.description: Extra commandline options when launching the node exporter.

services.prometheus.nodeExporter.openFir.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.ruleFiles.description: Any additional rules files to include in this configuration.

services.prometheus.rules.description: Alerting and/or Recording rules to evaluate at runtime.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.basi.description: Optional http login credentials for metrics scraping.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.cons.description: List of Consul service discovery configurations.
A list of services for which targets are retrieved.
The string by which Consul tags are joined into the tag label.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.dns_.description: List of DNS service discovery configurations.
A list of DNS SRV record names to be queried.
The time after which the provided names are refreshed.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.file.description: List of file service discovery configurations.

Patterns for files from which target groups are extracted. Refer
to the Prometheus documentation for permitted filename patterns
and formats.
Refresh interval to re-read the files.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.job_.description: The job name assigned to scraped metrics by default.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.metr.description: The HTTP resource path on which to fetch metrics from targets.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.para.type: attribute set of list of stringss

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.rela.description: Action to perform based on regex matching.
Regular expression against which the extracted value is matched.

Replacement value against which a regex replace is performed if the
regular expression matches.
Separator placed between concatenated source label values.

The source labels select values from existing labels. Their content
is concatenated using the configured separator and matched against
the configured regular expression.

Label to which the resulting value is written in a replace action.
It is mandatory for replace actions.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.sche.description: The URL scheme with which to fetch metrics from targets.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.scra.description:
How frequently to scrape targets from this job. Defaults to the
globally configured default.

Per-target timeout when scraping this job. Defaults to the
globally configured default.

services.prometheus.scrapeConfigs.*.stat.description: List of labeled target groups for this job.
Labels assigned to all metrics scraped from the targets.
The targets specified by the target group.

services.prometheus.snmpExporter.configu.description: Snmp exporter configuration as nix attribute set. Mutually exclusive with 'configurationPath' option.
Path to a snmp exporter configuration file. Mutually exclusive with 'configuration' option.

services.prometheus.snmpExporter.enable.description: Whether to enable Prometheus snmp exporter.

services.prometheus.snmpExporter.group.description: Group under which snmp exporter shall be run.

services.prometheus.snmpExporter.listenA.description: Address to listen on for web interface and telemetry.

services.prometheus.snmpExporter.logForm.description: Set the log target and format.

services.prometheus.snmpExporter.logLeve.description: Only log messages with the given severity or above.

services.prometheus.snmpExporter.openFir.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.snmpExporter.user.description: User name under which snmp exporter shall be run.

services.prometheus.unifiExporter.enable.description: Whether to enable prometheus unifi exporter.

services.prometheus.unifiExporter.extraF.description: Extra commandline options when launching the unifi exporter.

services.prometheus.unifiExporter.openFi.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prometheus.unifiExporter.unifiA.description: URL of the UniFi Controller API.

services.prometheus.unifiExporter.unifiI.description:
If enabled skip the verification of the TLS certificate of the UniFi Controller API.
Use with caution.

services.prometheus.unifiExporter.unifiP.description: Password for authentication against UniFi Controller API.

services.prometheus.unifiExporter.unifiT.description: Timeout including unit for UniFi Controller API requests.

services.prometheus.unifiExporter.unifiU.description: username for authentication against UniFi Controller API.

services.prometheus.varnishExporter.enab.description: Whether to enable prometheus Varnish exporter.

services.prometheus.varnishExporter.extr.description: Extra commandline options when launching the Varnish exporter.

services.prometheus.varnishExporter.open.description: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

services.prosody.admins.description: List of administrators of the current host

services.prosody.enable.description: Whether to enable the prosody server

services.prosody.modules.bosh.description: Enable BOSH clients, aka 'Jabber over HTTP'

services.prosody.modules.httpserver.description: Serve static files from a directory over HTTP

services.prosody.modules.legacyauth.description: Legacy authentication. Only used by some old clients and bots

services.prosody.modules.ping.description: Replies to XMPP pings with pongs

services.prosody.modules.roster.description: Allow users to have a roster

services.prosody.modules.saslauth.description: Authentication for clients and servers. Recommended if you want to log in.

services.prosody.modules.time.description: Let others know the time here on this server

services.prosody.modules.tls.description: Add support for secure TLS on c2s/s2s connections

services.prosody.modules.uptime.description: Report how long server has been running

services.prosody.virtualHosts.type: list or attribute set of submodules

services.prosody.virtualHosts.<name?>.en.description: Whether to enable the virtual host

services.psd.browsers.description:
A list of browsers to sync. Available choices are:

chromium chromium-dev conkeror.mozdev.org epiphany firefox
firefox-trunk google-chrome google-chrome-beta google-chrome-unstable
heftig-aurora icecat luakit midori opera opera-developer opera-beta
qupzilla palemoon rekonq seamonkey

An empty list will enable all browsers.

services.psd.daemonFile.description: Where the pid and backup configuration files will be stored.

services.psd.enable.description: Whether to enable the Profile Sync daemon.

services.psd.resyncTimer.description:
The amount of time to wait before syncing browser profiles back to the
disk.

Takes a systemd.unit time span. The time unit defaults to seconds if
omitted.

services.psd.users.description: A list of users whose browser profiles should be sync'd to tmpfs.

services.psd.volatile.description:
The directory where browser profiles should reside(this should be
mounted as a tmpfs). Do not include a trailing backslash.

services.pumpio.dbHost.description: The database host to connect to.

services.pumpio.dbName.description: The name of the database to use.

services.pumpio.dbPassword.description:
The password corresponding to dbUser.  Warning: this is
stored in cleartext in the Nix store!

services.pumpio.dbPasswordFile.description: A file containing the password corresponding to dbUser.

services.pumpio.dbPort.description: The port that the database is listening on.

services.pumpio.dbUser.description: The username. Defaults to null, meaning no authentication.

services.pumpio.disableRegistration.description:
Disables registering new users on the site through the Web
or the API.

services.pumpio.driver.description: Type of database. Corresponds to a nodejs databank driver.

services.pumpio.enable.description: Whether to enable Pump.io social streams server.

services.pumpio.enableUploads.description:
If you want to disable file uploads, set this to false. Uploaded files will be stored
in /var/lib/pump.io/uploads.

services.pumpio.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration options which are serialized to json and added
to the pump.io.json config file.

services.pumpio.favicon.description:
Local filesystem path to the favicon.ico file to use. This
will be served as "/favicon.ico" by the server.

services.pumpio.firehose.description:
Firehose host running the ofirehose software. Defaults to
"ofirehose.com". Public notices will be ping this firehose
server and from there go out to search engines and the
world. If you want to disconnect from the public web, set
this to something falsy.

services.pumpio.hostname.description:
The hostname of the server, used for generating
URLs. Defaults to "localhost" which doesn't do much for you.

services.pumpio.owner.description: Name of owning entity, if you want to link to it.

services.pumpio.ownerURL.description: URL of owning entity, if you want to link to it.

services.pumpio.port.description:
Port to listen on. Defaults to 31337, which is suitable for
running behind a reverse proxy. For a standalone server,
use 443.

services.pumpio.requireEmail.description: Require an e-mail address to register.

services.pumpio.secret.description:
A session-generating secret, server-wide password.  Warning:
this is stored in cleartext in the Nix store!

services.pumpio.secretFile.description:
A file containing the session-generating secret,
server-wide password.

services.pumpio.smtpFrom.description:
Email address to use in the "From:" header of outgoing
notifications. Defaults to 'no-reply@' plus the site
hostname.

services.pumpio.smtpHost.description:
Server to use for sending transactional email. If it's not
set up, no email is sent and features like password recovery
and email notification won't work.

services.pumpio.smtpPassword.description:
Password to use to connect to SMTP server. Might not be
necessary for some servers.  Warning: this is stored in
cleartext in the Nix store!

services.pumpio.smtpPasswordFile.description:
A file containing the password used to connect to SMTP
server. Might not be necessary for some servers.

services.pumpio.smtpPort.description: Port to connect to on SMTP server.

services.pumpio.smtpUseSSL.description:
Only use SSL with the SMTP server. By default, a SSL
connection is negotiated using TLS. You may need to change
the smtpPort value if you set this.

services.pumpio.smtpUser.description:
Username to use to connect to SMTP server. Might not be
necessary for some servers.

services.pumpio.spamClientSecret.description:
OAuth pair for spam server.  Warning: this is
stored in cleartext in the Nix store!

services.pumpio.spamClientSecretFile.description: A file containing the OAuth key for the spam server.

services.pumpio.spamHost.description:

for spam.

services.pumpio.sslCert.description:
The path to the server certificate. The certificate is
required, but it can be self-signed.

services.pumpio.sslKey.description:
The path to the server certificate private key. The
certificate is required, but it can be self-signed.

services.pumpio.urlPort.description:
Port to use for generating URLs. This basically has to be
either 80 or 443 because the host-meta and Webfinger
protocols don't make any provision for HTTP/HTTPS servers
running on other ports.

services.redis.appendFsync.description: How often to fsync the append-only log, options: no, always, everysec.

If the master is password protected (using the requirePass configuration)

services.redshift.brightness.day.description:
Screen brightness to apply during the day,
between <literal>0.1</literal> and <literal>1.0</literal>.

services.redshift.brightness.night.description:
Screen brightness to apply during the night,
between <literal>0.1</literal> and <literal>1.0</literal>.

services.redshift.enable.description:
Enable Redshift to change your screen's colour temperature depending on

services.redshift.extraOptions.description:
Additional command-line arguments to pass to
<command>redshift</command>.

services.redshift.latitude.description:
Your current latitude, between
<literal>-90.0</literal> and <literal>90.0</literal>. Must be provided
along with longitude.

services.redshift.longitude.description:
Your current longitude, between
between <literal>-180.0</literal> and <literal>180.0</literal>. Must be

The location provider to use for determining your location. If set to

services.redsocks.chroot.description:
Chroot under which to run redsocks. Log file is opened before
chroot, but if logging to syslog /etc/localtime may be required.

services.redsocks.log.description:
Where to send logs.

Possible values are:
  - stderr
  - file:/path/to/file
  - syslog:FACILITY where FACILITY is any of "daemon", "local0",
  etc.

services.redsocks.log_info.description: Log start and end of client sessions.

services.redsocks.redsocks.description:
Local port to proxy associations to be performed.

The example shows how to configure a proxy to handle port 80 as HTTP
relay, and all other ports as HTTP connect.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.disclose_sr.description:
Way to disclose client IP to the proxy.
  - "false": do not disclose
http-connect supports the following ways:
  - "X-Forwarded-For": add header "X-Forwarded-For: IP"
  - "Forwarded_ip": add header "Forwarded: for=IP" (see RFC7239)
  - "Forwarded_ipport": add header 'Forwarded: for="IP:port"'

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.doNotRedire.description:
Iptables filters that if matched will get the packet off of
redsocks.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.ip.description:
IP on which redsocks should listen. Defaults to 127.0.0.1 for
security reasons.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.password.description:
Password to send to proxy. WARNING, this will end up
world-readable in the store! Awaiting
https://github.com/NixOS/nix/issues/8 to be able to fix.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.port.description: Port on which redsocks should listen.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.proxy.description:
Proxy through which redsocks should forward incoming traffic.
Example: "example.org:8080"

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.redirectCon.description:
Conditions to make outbound packets go through this redsocks
instance.

If set to false, no packet will be forwarded. If set to true,
all packets will be forwarded (except packets excluded by
redirectInternetOnly).

If set to a string, this is an iptables filter that will be
matched against packets before getting them into redsocks. For
example, setting it to "--dport 80" will only send
packets to port 80 to redsocks. Note "-p tcp" is always
implicitly added, as udp can only be proxied through redudp or
the like.

services.redsocks.redsocks.*.redirectInt.description: Exclude all non-globally-routable IPs from redsocks

services.resilio.apiKey.description: API key, which enables the developer API.

services.resilio.checkForUpdates.description:
Determines whether to check for updates and alert the user
about them in the UI.

services.resilio.deviceName.description: Name of the Resilio Sync device.

services.resilio.directoryRoot.description: Default directory to add folders in the web UI.

services.resilio.enable.description:
If enabled, start the Resilio Sync daemon. Once enabled, you can
interact with the service through the Web UI, or configure it in your
NixOS configuration. Enabling the <literal>resilio</literal> service
also installs a systemd user unit which can be used to start
user-specific copies of the daemon. Once installed, you can use
<literal>systemctl --user start resilio</literal> as your user to start
the daemon using the configuration file located at
<literal>$HOME/.config/resilio-sync/config.json</literal>.

services.resilio.enableWebUI.description:
Enable Web UI for administration. Bound to the specified
<literal>httpListenAddress</literal> and
<literal>httpListenPort</literal>.

services.resilio.listeningPort.description: Listening port. Defaults to 0 which randomizes the port.

services.resilio.sharedFolders.description:
Shared folder list. If enabled, web UI must be
disabled. Secrets can be generated using <literal>rslsync
--generate-secret</literal>. Note that this secret will be
put inside the Nix store, so it is realistically not very
secret.

If you would like to be able to modify the contents of this
directories, it is recommended that you make your user a
member of the <literal>resilio</literal> group.

Directories in this list should be in the
<literal>resilio</literal> group, and that group must have
write access to the directory. It is also recommended that
<literal>chmod g+s</literal> is applied to the directory
so that any sub directories created will also belong to
the <literal>resilio</literal> group. Also,
<literal>setfacl -d -m group:resilio:rwx</literal> and
<literal>setfacl -m group:resilio:rwx</literal> should also
be applied so that the sub directories are writable by
the group.

services.resilio.storagePath.description:
Where BitTorrent Sync will store it's database files (containing
things like username info and licenses). Generally, you should not
need to ever change this.

services.resolved.dnssec.description:
If set to
<variablelist>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"true"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    all DNS lookups are DNSSEC-validated locally (excluding
    LLMNR and Multicast DNS). Note that this mode requires a
    DNS server that supports DNSSEC. If the DNS server does
    not properly support DNSSEC all validations will fail.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"allow-downgrade"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    DNSSEC validation is attempted, but if the server does not
    support DNSSEC properly, DNSSEC mode is automatically
    disabled. Note that this mode makes DNSSEC validation
    vulnerable to "downgrade" attacks, where an attacker might
    be able to trigger a downgrade to non-DNSSEC mode by
    synthesizing a DNS response that suggests DNSSEC was not
    supported.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"false"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    DNS lookups are not DNSSEC validated.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
</variablelist>

services.resolved.domains.description:
A list of domains. These domains are used as search suffixes
when resolving single-label host names (domain names which
contain no dot), in order to qualify them into fully-qualified
domain names (FQDNs).
</para><para>
For compatibility reasons, if this setting is not specified,
the search domains listed in
<filename>/etc/resolv.conf</filename> are used instead, if
that file exists and any domains are configured in it.

services.resolved.enable.description: Whether to enable the systemd DNS resolver daemon.

services.resolved.extraConfig.description: Extra config to append to resolved.conf.

services.resolved.fallbackDns.description:
A list of IPv4 and IPv6 addresses to use as the fallback DNS servers.
If this option is empty, a compiled-in list of DNS servers is used instead.

services.resolved.llmnr.description:
Controls Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution support
(RFC 4795) on the local host.
</para><para>
If set to
<variablelist>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"true"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    Enables full LLMNR responder and resolver support.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"false"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    Disables both.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>"resolve"</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    Only resolution support is enabled, but responding is disabled.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
</variablelist>

	  A port may optionally be specified after adding a space to the address
