services.rsyslogd.defaultConfig.default:
# "local1" is used for dhcpd messages.
local1.*                     -/var/log/dhcpd

mail.*                       -/var/log/mail

*.=warning;*.=err            -/var/log/warn
*.crit                        /var/log/warn

*.*;mail.none;local1.none    -/var/log/messages
services.rsyslogd.defaultConfig.description:
The default <filename>syslog.conf</filename> file configures a
fairly standard setup of log files, which can be extended by
means of <varname>extraConfig</varname>.

services.rsyslogd.enable.description:
Whether to enable syslogd.  Note that systemd also logs
syslog messages, so you normally don't need to run syslogd.

services.rsyslogd.extraConfig.description:
Additional text appended to <filename>syslog.conf</filename>,
i.e. the contents of <varname>defaultConfig</varname>.

services.sabnzbd.enable.description: Whether to enable the sabnzbd server.

services.sabnzbd.group.description: Group to run the service as

services.sabnzbd.user.description: User to run the service as

services.salt.master.configuration.description: Salt master configuration as Nix attribute set.

services.salt.master.enable.description: Whether to enable Salt master service.

services.salt.minion.configuration.description:
Salt minion configuration as Nix attribute set.
See <link xlink:href="https://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/configuration/minion.html"/>                                                                                                 
for details.

services.salt.minion.enable.description: Whether to enable Salt minion service.

services.samba.configText.description:
Verbatim contents of smb.conf. If null (default), use the
autogenerated file from NixOS instead.

services.samba.enable.description:
Whether to enable Samba, which provides file and print
services to Windows clients through the SMB/CIFS protocol.

<note>
  <para>If you use the firewall consider adding the following:</para>
  <programlisting>
    networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts = [ 139 445 ];
    networking.firewall.allowedUDPPorts = [ 137 138 ];
  </programlisting>
</note>

services.samba.enableNmbd.description:
Whether to enable Samba's nmbd, which replies to NetBIOS over IP name
service requests. It also participates in the browsing protocols
which make up the Windows "Network Neighborhood" view.

services.samba.enableWinbindd.description:
Whether to enable Samba's winbindd, which provides a number of services
to the Name Service Switch capability found in most modern C libraries,
to arbitrary applications via PAM and ntlm_auth and to Samba itself.

services.samba.extraConfig.description: Additional global section and extra section lines go in here.
services.samba.extraConfig.example:
guest account = nobody
map to guest = bad user

services.samba.invalidUsers.description: List of users who are denied to login via Samba.

services.samba.nsswins.description:
Whether to enable the WINS NSS (Name Service Switch) plug-in.
Enabling it allows applications to resolve WINS/NetBIOS names (a.k.a.
Windows machine names) by transparently querying the winbindd daemon.

services.samba.package.description: Defines which package should be used for the samba server.

services.samba.shares.description:
A set describing shared resources.
See <command>man smb.conf</command> for options.
services.samba.shares.type: attribute set of attribute set of unspecifiedss

services.samba.syncPasswordsByPam.description:
Enabling this will add a line directly after pam_unix.so.
Whenever a password is changed the samba password will be updated as well.
However, you still have to add the samba password once, using smbpasswd -a user.
If you don't want to maintain an extra password database, you still can send plain text
passwords which is not secure.

services.saned.enable.description:
Enable saned network daemon for remote connection to scanners.

saned would be runned from <literal>scanner</literal> user; to allow
access to hardware that doesn't have <literal>scanner</literal> group
you should add needed groups to this user.

services.saslauthd.config.description: Configuration to use for Cyrus SASL authentication daemon.

services.saslauthd.enable.description: Whether to enable Whether to enable the Cyrus SASL authentication daemon..

services.scollector.bosunHost.description:
Host and port of the bosun server that will store the collected
data.

services.scollector.collectors.description:
An attribute set mapping the frequency of collection to a list of
binaries that should be executed at that frequency. You can use "0"
to run a binary forever.
services.scollector.collectors.type: attribute set of list of pathss

services.scollector.extraConfig.description: Extra scollector configuration added to the end of scollector.toml

services.scollector.group.description: Group account under which scollector runs.

services.scollector.user.description: User account under which scollector runs.

services.searx.configFile.description:
The path of the Searx server configuration file. If no file
          is specified, a default file is used (default config file has
          debug mode enabled).

services.searx.enable.description: Whether to enable the searx server. See https://github.com/asciimoo/searx.

services.seeks.confDir.description:
The Seeks server configuration. If it is not specified,
          a default configuration is used.

services.seeks.enable.description: Whether to enable the Seeks server.

services.selfoss.database.host.description: Host of the database (has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.database.name.description: Name of the existing database (has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.database.password.description: The database user's password (has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.database.port.description:
The database's port. If not set, the default ports will be
provided (5432 and 3306 for pgsql and mysql respectively)
(has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.database.type.description: Database to store feeds. Supported are sqlite, pgsql and mysql.

services.selfoss.database.user.description:
The database user. The user must exist and has access to
the specified database (has no effect if type is "sqlite").

services.selfoss.pool.description:
Name of existing phpfpm pool that is used to run web-application.
If not specified a pool will be created automatically with
default values.

services.selfoss.user.description: User account under which both the service and the web-application run.

services.shairport-sync.arguments.description:
Arguments to pass to the daemon. Defaults to a local pulseaudio
server.

services.shairport-sync.enable.description:
Enable the shairport-sync daemon.

Running with a local system-wide or remote pulseaudio server
is recommended.

services.shairport-sync.user.description:
User account name under which to run shairport-sync. The account
will be created.

services.shellinabox.certDirectory.description:
The daemon will look in this directory far any certificates.
If the browser negotiated a Server Name Identification the daemon
will look for a matching certificate-SERVERNAME.pem file. If no SNI
handshake takes place, it will fall back on using the certificate in the
certificate.pem file.

If no suitable certificate is installed, shellinaboxd will attempt to
create a new self-signed certificate. This will only succeed if, after
dropping privileges, shellinaboxd has write permissions for this
directory.

services.shellinabox.enableSSL.description: Whether or not to enable SSL (https) support.

services.shellinabox.extraOptions.description:
A list of strings to be appended to the command line arguments
for shellinaboxd. Please see the manual page
<link xlink:href="https://code.google.com/p/shellinabox/wiki/shellinaboxd_man"/>
for a full list of available arguments.

services.shellinabox.user.description:
User to run shellinaboxd as. If started as root, the server drops
privileges by changing to nobody, unless overridden by the
<literal>--user</literal> option.

services.shibboleth-sp.enable.description: Whether to enable the shibboleth service

services.shibboleth-sp.fastcgi.enable.description: Whether to include the shibauthorizer and shibresponder FastCGI processes

services.shibboleth-sp.fastcgi.shibAutho.description: Port for shibauthorizer FastCGI proccess to bind to

services.shibboleth-sp.fastcgi.shibRespo.description: Port for shibauthorizer FastCGI proccess to bind to

services.shout.config.description:
Shout <filename>config.js</filename> contents as attribute set (will be
converted to JSON to generate the configuration file).

The options defined here will be merged to the default configuration file.

Documentation: http://shout-irc.com/docs/server/configuration.html

services.shout.configFile.description:
Contents of Shout's <filename>config.js</filename> file.

Used for backward compatibility, recommended way is now to use
the <literal>config</literal> option.

Documentation: http://shout-irc.com/docs/server/configuration.html

services.shout.enable.description: Whether to enable Shout web IRC client.

services.shout.listenAddress.description: IP interface to listen on for http connections.

services.shout.port.description: TCP port to listen on for http connections.

services.shout.private.description:
Make your shout instance private. You will need to configure user
accounts by adding entries in <filename>/var/lib/shout/users</filename>.

services.siproxd.enable.description:
Whether to enable the Siproxd SIP 
	  proxy/masquerading daemon.

services.siproxd.extraConfig.description: Extra configuration to add to siproxd configuration.

services.siproxd.hostsAllowReg.description: Acess control list for incoming SIP registrations.

services.siproxd.hostsAllowSip.description: Acess control list for incoming SIP traffic.

services.siproxd.hostsDenySip.description:
Acess control list for denying incoming
	   SIP registrations and traffic.

services.siproxd.rtpDscp.description:
DSCP (differentiated services) value to be assigned
to RTP packets. Allows QOS aware routers to handle 
different types traffic with different priorities.

services.siproxd.rtpPortHigh.description: Top of UDP port range for incoming and outgoing RTP traffic

services.siproxd.rtpPortLow.description: Bottom of UDP port range for incoming and outgoing RTP traffic

services.siproxd.rtpTimeout.description:
Timeout for an RTP stream. If for the specified 
number of seconds no data is relayed on an active
stream, it is considered dead and will be killed.

services.siproxd.sipDscp.description:
DSCP (differentiated services) value to be assigned
to SIP packets. Allows QOS aware routers to handle 
different types traffic with different priorities.

services.siproxd.sipListenPort.description: Port to listen for incoming SIP messages.

services.sks.hkpAddress.description: Wich ip addresses the sks-keyserver is listening on.

services.sks.hkpPort.description: Which port the sks-keyserver is listening on.

services.skydns.domain.description: Skydns default domain if not specified by etcd config.

services.skydns.etcd.caCert.description: Skydns path of TLS certificate authority public key.

services.skydns.etcd.machines.description: Skydns list of etcd endpoints to connect to.

services.skydns.etcd.tlsKey.description: Skydns path of TLS client certificate - private key.

services.skydns.etcd.tlsPem.description: Skydns path of TLS client certificate - public key.

services.skydns.extraConfig.description: Skydns attribute set of extra config options passed as environemnt variables.

services.skydns.nameservers.description: Skydns list of nameservers to forward DNS requests to when not authoritative for a domain.

services.slimserver.dataDir.description:
The directory where slimserver stores its state, tag cache,
playlists etc.

services.slurm.client.enable.description: Whether to enable slurm rlient daemon.

services.slurm.controlAddr.description:
Name that ControlMachine should be referred to in establishing a
communications path.

services.slurm.controlMachine.description:
The short hostname of the machine where SLURM control functions are
executed (i.e. the name returned by the command "hostname -s", use "tux001"
rather than "tux001.my.com").

services.slurm.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration options that will be added verbatim at
the end of the slurm configuration file.

services.slurm.nodeName.description:
Name that SLURM uses to refer to a node (or base partition for BlueGene
systems). Typically this would be the string that "/bin/hostname -s"
returns. Note that now you have to write node's parameters after the name.

services.slurm.package.description: The package to use for slurm binaries.

services.slurm.partitionName.description:
Name by which the partition may be referenced. Note that now you have
to write patrition's parameters after the name.

services.slurm.server.enable.description: Whether to enable slurm control daemon.

services.smartd.autodetect.description:
Whenever smartd should monitor all devices connected to the
machine at the time it's being started (the default).

Set to false to monitor the devices listed in
<option>services.smartd.devices</option> only.

services.smartd.defaults.autodetected.description:
Like <option>services.smartd.defaults.monitored</option>, but for the
autodetected devices.

services.smartd.defaults.monitored.description:
Common default options for explicitly monitored (listed in
<option>services.smartd.devices</option>) devices.

The default value turns on monitoring of all the things (see
<literal>man 5 smartd.conf</literal>).

The example also turns on SMART Automatic Offline Testing on
startup, and schedules short self-tests daily, and long
self-tests weekly.

services.smartd.devices.*.options.description: Options that determine how smartd monitors the device.

services.smartd.enable.description: Whether to enable smartd daemon from <literal>smartmontools</literal> package.

services.smartd.notifications.mail.maile.description:
Sendmail-compatible binary to be used to send the messages.

You should probably enable
<option>services.postfix</option> or some other MTA for
this to work.

services.smartd.notifications.test.description: Whenever to send a test notification on startup.

services.smartd.notifications.wall.enabl.description: Whenever to send wall notifications to all users.

services.smartd.notifications.x11.displa.description: DISPLAY to send X11 notifications to.

services.smartd.notifications.x11.enable.description: Whenever to send X11 xmessage notifications.

							MAX  0.5 144   7200
							MIN  0.5 144   7200

services.smokeping.smokeMailTemplate.description: Specify the smokemail template for alerts.

services.snapper.cleanupInterval.description:
Cleanup interval.

The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.snapper.configs.<name>.extraCon.description:
Additional configuration next to SUBVOLUME and FSTYPE.
See man:snapper-configs(5).

services.snapper.configs.<name>.fstype.description: Filesystem type. Only btrfs is stable and tested.

services.snapper.configs.<name>.subvolum.description:
Path of the subvolume or mount point.
This path is a subvolume and has to contain a subvolume named
.snapshots.
See also man:snapper(8) section PERMISSIONS.

services.snapper.filters.description: Global display difference filter. See man:snapper(8) for more details.

services.snapper.snapshotInterval.description:
Snapshot interval.

The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.sniproxy.config.description: sniproxy.conf configuration excluding the daemon username and pid file.

services.sniproxy.logDir.description: Location of the log directory for sniproxy.

services.sniproxy.user.description: User account under which sniproxy runs.

services.softether.vpnbridge.enable.description: Whether to enable SoftEther VPN Bridge.

services.softether.vpnclient.down.description: Shell commands executed when the Virtual Network Adapter(s) is/are shutting down.

services.softether.vpnclient.up.description: Shell commands executed when the Virtual Network Adapter(s) is/are starting.

services.softether.vpnserver.enable.description: Whether to enable SoftEther VPN Server.

services.solr.extraJars.description: List of paths pointing to jars. Jars are copied to commonLibFolder to be available to java/solr.

services.solr.extraJavaOptions.description:
Extra command line options given to the java process running
solr.

services.solr.extraWinstoneOptions.description:
Extra command line options given to the Winstone, which is
the servlet container hosting solr.

services.solr.group.description: The group that will own the working directory.

services.solr.javaPackage.description: Which Java derivation to use for running solr.

Contents of the <literal>log4j.properties</literal> used. By default,
everything is logged to stdout (picked up by systemd) with level INFO.

services.solr.solrHome.description:
The solr home directory. It is your own responsibility to
make sure this directory contains a working solr configuration,
and is writeable by the the user running the solr service.
Failing to do so, the solr will not start properly.

services.solr.solrPackage.description: Which solr derivation to use for running solr.

services.solr.user.description:
The user that should run the solr process and.
the working directories.

services.spice-vdagentd.enable.description: Whether to enable Spice guest vdagent daemon.

services.spiped.config.description:
Configuration for a secure pipe daemon. The daemon can be
started, stopped, or examined using
<literal>systemctl</literal>, under the name
<literal>spiped@foo</literal>.

services.spiped.config.<name>.decrypt.description:
Take encrypted connections from the
<literal>source</literal> socket and send unencrypted
connections to the <literal>target</literal> socket.

services.spiped.config.<name>.encrypt.description:
Take unencrypted connections from the
<literal>source</literal> socket and send encrypted
connections to the <literal>target</literal> socket.

services.spiped.config.<name>.keyfile.description:
Name of a file containing the spiped key. As the
daemon runs as the <literal>spiped</literal> user, the
key file must be somewhere owned by that user. By
default, we recommend putting the keys for any spipe
services in <literal>/var/lib/spiped</literal>.

services.spiped.config.<name>.maxConns.description: Limit on the number of simultaneous connections allowed.

services.spiped.config.<name>.resolveRef.description: Resolution refresh time for the target socket, in seconds.

services.spiped.config.<name>.source.description:
Address on which spiped should listen for incoming
connections.  Must be in one of the following formats:
<literal>/absolute/path/to/unix/socket</literal>,
<literal>host.name:port</literal>,
<literal>[ip.v4.ad.dr]:port</literal> or
<literal>[ipv6::addr]:port</literal> - note that
hostnames are resolved when spiped is launched and are
not re-resolved later; thus if DNS entries change
spiped will continue to connect to the expired
address.

services.spiped.config.<name>.target.description: Address to which spiped should connect.

services.spiped.config.<name>.timeout.description:
Timeout, in seconds, after which an attempt to connect to
the target or a protocol handshake will be aborted (and the
connection dropped) if not completed

services.spiped.config.<name>.waitForDNS.description:
Wait for DNS. Normally when <literal>spiped</literal> is
launched it resolves addresses and binds to its source
socket before the parent process returns; with this option
it will daemonize first and retry failed DNS lookups until
they succeed. This allows <literal>spiped</literal> to
launch even if DNS isn't set up yet, but at the expense of
losing the guarantee that once <literal>spiped</literal> has
finished launching it will be ready to create pipes.

services.spiped.config.<name>.weakHandsh.description:
Use fast/weak handshaking: This reduces the CPU time spent
in the initial connection setup, at the expense of losing
perfect forward secrecy.

services.squeezelite.dataDir.description: The directory where Squeezelite stores its name file.

services.squeezelite.enable.description: Whether to enable Squeezelite, a software Squeezebox emulator.

services.squeezelite.extraArguments.description: Additional command line arguments to pass to Squeezelite.

services.squid.configText.description:
Verbatim contents of squid.conf. If null (default), use the
autogenerated file from NixOS instead.

services.squid.enable.description: Whether to run squid web proxy.

services.squid.extraConfig.description:
Squid configuration. Contents will be added
verbatim to the configuration file.

services.squid.proxyPort.description: TCP port on which squid will listen.

services.sshguard.attack_threshold.description: Block attackers when their cumulative attack score exceeds threshold. Most attacks have a score of 10.

services.sshguard.blacklist_file.description: Blacklist an attacker when its score exceeds threshold. Blacklisted addresses are loaded from and added to blacklist-file.

services.sshguard.blacklist_threshold.description: Blacklist an attacker when its score exceeds threshold. Blacklisted addresses are loaded from and added to blacklist-file.

services.sshguard.blocktime.description:
Block attackers for initially blocktime seconds after exceeding threshold. Subsequent blocks increase by a factor of 1.5.

sshguard unblocks attacks at random intervals, so actual block times will be longer.

services.sshguard.detection_time.description: Remember potential attackers for up to detection_time seconds before resetting their score.

services.sshguard.enable.description: Whether to enable the sshguard service.

services.sshguard.services.description: Systemd services sshguard should receive logs of.

services.sshguard.whitelist.description: Whitelist a list of addresses, hostnames, or address blocks.

services.sslh.pidfile.description: PID file path for sslh daemon.

services.ssm-agent.enable.description: Whether to enable AWS SSM agent.

services.ssm-agent.package.description: The SSM agent package to use

services.sssd.enable.description: Whether to enable the System Security Services Daemon..

services.sssd.sshAuthorizedKeysIntegrati.description:
Whether to make sshd look up authorized keys from SSS.
For this to work, the <literal>ssh</literal> SSS service must be enabled in the sssd configuration.

services.stanchion.distributedCookie.description:
Cookie for distributed node communication.  All nodes in the
same cluster should use the same cookie or they will not be able to
communicate.

services.stanchion.extraConfig.description: Additional text to be appended to <filename>stanchion.conf</filename>.

services.stanchion.listener.description: Name of Riak CS listening service.

services.statsd.backends.description: List of backends statsd will use for data persistence

services.statsd.enable.description: Whether to enable statsd stats aggregation service

services.statsd.graphiteHost.description: Hostname or IP of Graphite server

services.statsd.listenAddress.description: Address that statsd listens on over UDP

services.statsd.mgmt_address.description: Address to run management TCP interface on

services.statsd.mgmt_port.description: Port to run the management TCP interface on

services.statsd.port.description: Port that stats listens for messages on over UDP

services.strongswan.ca.description:
A set of CAs (certification authorities) and their options for
the ca xxx sections of the <filename>ipsec.conf</filename>
file.
services.strongswan.ca.type: attribute set of attribute set of stringss

services.strongswan.connections.description:
A set of connections and their options for the conn xxx
sections of the <filename>ipsec.conf</filename> file.
services.strongswan.connections.type: attribute set of attribute set of stringss

services.strongswan.enabledPlugins.description:
A list of additional plugins to enable if
<option>managePlugins</option> is true.

services.strongswan.managePlugins.description:
If set to true, this option will disable automatic plugin loading and
then tell strongSwan to enable the plugins specified in the
<option>enabledPlugins</option> option.

services.strongswan.secrets.description:
A list of paths to IPSec secret files. These
files will be included into the main ipsec.secrets file with
the <literal>include</literal> directive. It is safer if these
paths are absolute.

services.strongswan.setup.description:
A set of options for the config setup section of the
<filename>ipsec.conf</filename> file. Defines general
configuration parameters.

services.subsonic.contextPath.description:
The context path, i.e., the last part of the Subsonic
URL. Typically '/' or '/subsonic'. Default '/'

services.subsonic.defaultMusicFolder.description:
Configure Subsonic to use this folder for music.  This option
only has effect the first time Subsonic is started.

services.subsonic.defaultPlaylistFolder.description:
Configure Subsonic to use this folder for playlists.  This option
only has effect the first time Subsonic is started.

services.subsonic.defaultPodcastFolder.description:
Configure Subsonic to use this folder for Podcasts.  This option
only has effect the first time Subsonic is started.

services.subsonic.home.description:
The directory where Subsonic will create files.
Make sure it is writable.

services.subsonic.httpsPort.description:
The port on which Subsonic will listen for
incoming HTTPS traffic. Set to 0 to disable.

services.subsonic.listenAddress.description:
The host name or IP address on which to bind Subsonic.
Only relevant if you have multiple network interfaces and want
to make Subsonic available on only one of them. The default value
will bind Subsonic to all available network interfaces.

services.subsonic.maxMemory.description:
The memory limit (max Java heap size) in megabytes.
Default: 100

services.subsonic.port.description:
The port on which Subsonic will listen for
incoming HTTP traffic. Set to 0 to disable.

services.subsonic.transcoders.description:
List of paths to transcoder executables that should be accessible
from Subsonic. Symlinks will be created to each executable inside
/var/lib/subsonic/transcoders.

services.supybot.configFile.description:
Path to a supybot config file. This can be generated by
running supybot-wizard.

Note: all paths should include the full path to the stateDir
directory (backup conf data logs logs/plugins plugins tmp web).

services.supybot.stateDir.description: The root directory, logs and plugins are stored here

services.svnserve.enable.description: Whether to enable svnserve to serve Subversion repositories through the SVN protocol.

services.svnserve.svnBaseDir.description: Base directory from which Subversion repositories are accessed.

services.syncthing.all_proxy.description:
Overwrites all_proxy environment variable for the syncthing process to
the given value. This is normaly used to let relay client connect
through SOCKS5 proxy server.

services.syncthing.dataDir.description: Path where the settings and keys will exist.

services.syncthing.enable.description:
Whether to enable Syncthing - the self-hosted open-source alternative
to Dropbox and Bittorrent Sync. Initial interface will be
available on http://127.0.0.1:8384/.
.

services.syncthing.group.description:
Syncthing will be run under this group (group will not be created if it doesn't exist.
This can be your user name).

services.syncthing.openDefaultPorts.description:
Open the default ports in the firewall:
  - TCP 22000 for transfers
  - UDP 21027 for discovery
If multiple users are running syncthing on this machine, you will need to manually open a set of ports for each instance and leave this disabled.
Alternatively, if are running only a single instance on this machine using the default ports, enable this.

services.syncthing.systemService.description: Auto launch Syncthing as a system service.

services.syncthing.user.description:
Syncthing will be run under this user (user will be created if it doesn't exist.
This can be your user name).

services.synergy.client.autoStart.description: Whether the Synergy client should be started automatically.

services.synergy.client.enable.description: Whether to enable the Synergy client (receive keyboard and mouse events from a Synergy server).

services.synergy.client.screenName.description:
Use the given name instead of the hostname to identify
ourselves to the server.

services.synergy.client.serverAddress.description:
The server address is of the form: [hostname][:port].  The
hostname must be the address or hostname of the server.  The
port overrides the default port, 24800.

services.synergy.server.address.description: Address on which to listen for clients.

services.synergy.server.autoStart.description: Whether the Synergy server should be started automatically.

services.synergy.server.enable.description: Whether to enable the Synergy server (send keyboard and mouse events).

services.synergy.server.screenName.description:
Use the given name instead of the hostname to identify
this screen in the configuration.

services.syslog-ng.configHeader.description:
The very first lines of the configuration file. Should usually contain
the syslog-ng version header.

services.syslog-ng.enable.description: Whether to enable the syslog-ng daemon.

services.syslog-ng.extraConfig.description: Configuration added to the end of <literal>syslog-ng.conf</literal>.

services.syslog-ng.extraModulePaths.description:
A list of paths that should be included in syslog-ng's
<literal>--module-path</literal> option. They should usually
end in <literal>/lib/syslog-ng</literal>

services.syslogd.defaultConfig.default:
# Send emergency messages to all users.
*.emerg                       *

# "local1" is used for dhcpd messages.
local1.*                     -/var/log/dhcpd

mail.*                       -/var/log/mail

*.=warning;*.=err            -/var/log/warn
*.crit                        /var/log/warn

*.*;mail.none;local1.none    -/var/log/messages
services.syslogd.defaultConfig.description:
The default <filename>syslog.conf</filename> file configures a
fairly standard setup of log files, which can be extended by
means of <varname>extraConfig</varname>.

services.syslogd.enable.description:
Whether to enable syslogd.  Note that systemd also logs
syslog messages, so you normally don't need to run syslogd.

services.syslogd.enableNetworkInput.description: Accept logging through UDP. Option -r of syslogd(8).

services.syslogd.extraConfig.description:
Additional text appended to <filename>syslog.conf</filename>,
i.e. the contents of <varname>defaultConfig</varname>.

services.syslogd.tty.description:
The tty device on which syslogd will print important log
messages. Leave this option blank to disable tty logging.

services.sysstat.collect-args.description: Arguments to pass sa1 when collecting statistics

services.sysstat.enable.description: Whether to enable sar system activity collection.

services.systemhealth.enable.description: Enable the system health monitor and its generation of graphs.

services.systemhealth.urlPrefix.description: The URL prefix under which the System Health web pages appear in httpd.

services.tahoe.introducers.<name>.nickna.description: The nickname of this Tahoe introducer.

services.tahoe.introducers.<name>.packag.description: The package to use for the Tahoe LAFS daemon.

services.tahoe.introducers.<name>.tub.lo.description:
The external location that the introducer should listen on.

If specified, the port should be included.

services.tahoe.introducers.<name>.tub.po.description: The port on which the introducer will listen.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.client.helpe.description:
The furl for a Tahoe helper node.

Like all furls, keep this safe and don't share it.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.client.intro.description:
The furl for a Tahoe introducer node.

Like all furls, keep this safe and don't share it.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.client.share.description:
The number of distinct storage nodes required to store
a file.
The number of shares required to reconstitute a file.
The number of shares required to store a file.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.nickname.description: The nickname of this Tahoe node.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.package.description: The package to use for the Tahoe LAFS daemon.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.sftpd.hostPr.description: Path to the SSH host private key.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.sftpd.hostPu.description: Path to the SSH host public key.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.sftpd.port.description:
The port on which the SFTP server will listen.

This is the correct setting to tweak if you want Tahoe's SFTP
daemon to listen on a different port.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.storage.rese.description: The amount of filesystem space to not use for storage.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.tub.location.description:
The external location that the node should listen on.

This is the setting to tweak if there are multiple interfaces
and you want to alter which interface Tahoe is advertising.

If specified, the port should be included.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.tub.port.description:
The port on which the tub will listen.

This is the correct setting to tweak if you want Tahoe's storage
system to listen on a different port.

services.tahoe.nodes.<name>.web.port.description:
The port on which the Web server will listen.

This is the correct setting to tweak if you want Tahoe's WUI to
listen on a different port.

services.tarsnap.archives.description:
Tarsnap archive configurations. Each attribute names an archive
to be created at a given time interval, according to the options
associated with it. When uploading to the tarsnap server,
archive names are suffixed by a 1 second resolution timestamp.

For each member of the set is created a timer which triggers the
instanced <literal>tarsnap-archive-name</literal> service unit. You may use
<command>systemctl start tarsnap-archive-name</command> to
manually trigger creation of <literal>archive-name</literal> at
any time.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.aggress.description:
Upload data over multiple TCP connections, potentially
increasing tarsnap's bandwidth utilisation at the cost
of slowing down all other network traffic. Not
recommended unless TCP congestion is the dominant
limiting factor.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.cachedi.description:
The cache allows tarsnap to identify previously stored data
blocks, reducing archival time and bandwidth usage.

Should the cache become desynchronized or corrupted, tarsnap
will refuse to run until you manually rebuild the cache with
<command>tarsnap --fsck</command>.

Set to <literal>null</literal> to disable caching.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.checkpo.description:
Create a checkpoint every <literal>checkpointBytes</literal>
of uploaded data (optionally specified using an SI prefix).

1GB is the minimum value. A higher value is recommended,
as checkpointing is expensive.

Set to <literal>null</literal> to disable checkpointing.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.directo.description: List of filesystem paths to archive.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.exclude.description: Exclude files and directories matching these patterns.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.include.description:
Include only files and directories matching these
patterns (the empty list includes everything).

Exclusions have precedence over inclusions.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.keyfile.description:
Set a specific keyfile for this archive. This defaults to
<literal>"/root/tarsnap.key"</literal> if left unspecified.

Use this option if you want to run multiple backups
concurrently - each archive must have a unique key. You can
generate a write-only key derived from your master key (which
is recommended) using <literal>tarsnap-keymgmt(1)</literal>.

Note: every archive must have an individual master key. You
must generate multiple keys with
<literal>tarsnap-keygen(1)</literal>, and then generate write
only keys from those.

The keyfile name should be given as a string and not a path, to
avoid the key being copied into the Nix store.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.lowmem.description:
Reduce memory consumption by not caching small files.
Possibly beneficial if the average file size is smaller
than 1 MB and the number of files is lower than the
total amount of RAM in KB.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.maxbw.description:
Abort archival if upstream bandwidth usage in bytes
exceeds this threshold.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.maxbwRa.description: Download bandwidth rate limit in bytes.
Upload bandwidth rate limit in bytes.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.period.description:
Create archive at this interval.

The format is described in
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>7</manvolnum></citerefentry>.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.printSt.description:
Print global archive statistics upon completion.
The output is available via
<command>systemctl status tarsnap@archive-name</command>.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.verbose.description: Whether to produce verbose logging output.

services.tarsnap.archives.<name>.verylow.description:
Reduce memory consumption by a factor of 2 beyond what
<literal>lowmem</literal> does, at the cost of significantly
slowing down the archiving process.

services.tarsnap.keyfile.description:
The keyfile which associates this machine with your tarsnap
account.
Create the keyfile with <command>tarsnap-keygen</command>.

Note that each individual archive (specified below) may also have its
own individual keyfile specified. Tarsnap does not allow multiple
concurrent backups with the same cache directory and key (starting a
new backup will cause another one to fail). If you have multiple
archives specified, you should either spread out your backups to be
far apart, or specify a separate key for each archive. By default
every archive defaults to using
<literal>"/root/tarsnap.key"</literal>.

It's recommended for backups that you generate a key for every archive
using <literal>tarsnap-keygen(1)</literal>, and then generate a
write-only tarsnap key using <literal>tarsnap-keymgmt(1)</literal>,
and keep your master key(s) for a particular machine off-site.

The keyfile name should be given as a string and not a path, to
avoid the key being copied into the Nix store.

services.taskserver.allowedClientIDs.description:
A list of regular expressions that are matched against the reported
client id (such as <literal>task 2.3.0</literal>).

The values <literal>all</literal> or <literal>none</literal> have
special meaning. Overidden by any entry in the option
<option>services.taskserver.disallowedClientIDs</option>.

services.taskserver.ciphers.description:
List of GnuTLS ciphers to use. See the GnuTLS documentation about
priority strings at <link xlink:href="https://gnutls.org/manual/html_node/Priority-Strings.html"/> for full details.

services.taskserver.config.description:
Configuration options to pass to Taskserver.

The options here are the same as described in <citerefentry>
  <refentrytitle>taskdrc</refentrytitle>
  <manvolnum>5</manvolnum>
</citerefentry>, but with one difference:

The <literal>server</literal> option is
<literal>server.listen</literal> here, because the
<literal>server</literal> option would collide with other options
like <literal>server.cert</literal> and we would run in a type error
(attribute set versus string).

Nix types like integers or booleans are automatically converted to
the right values Taskserver would expect.

services.taskserver.confirmation.description: Determines whether certain commands are confirmed.

services.taskserver.disallowedClientIDs.description:
A list of regular expressions that are matched against the reported
client id (such as <literal>task 2.3.0</literal>).

The values <literal>all</literal> or <literal>none</literal> have
special meaning. Any entry here overrides those in
<option>services.taskserver.allowedClientIDs</option>.

services.taskserver.enable.description:
Whether to enable the Taskwarrior server.

More instructions about NixOS in conjuction with Taskserver can be
found in the NixOS manual at
<olink targetdoc="manual" targetptr="module-taskserver"/>.

services.taskserver.extensions.description:
Fully qualified path of the Taskserver extension scripts.
Currently there are none.

services.taskserver.fqdn.description:
The fully qualified domain name of this server, which is also used
as the common name in the certificates.

services.taskserver.ipLog.description: Logs the IP addresses of incoming requests.

services.taskserver.listenHost.description:
The address (IPv4, IPv6 or DNS) to listen on.

If the value is something else than <literal>localhost</literal> the
port defined by <option>listenPort</option> is automatically added to
<option>networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts</option>.

services.taskserver.organisations.description:
An attribute set where the keys name the organisation and the values
are a set of lists of <option>users</option> and
<option>groups</option>.

services.taskserver.organisations.<name>.description: A list of group names that belong to the organization.
A list of user names that belong to the organization.

services.taskserver.pki.auto.bits.description:
The bit size for generated keys.

<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.auto.expiration..description:
The expiration time of the CA certificate in days or <literal>null</literal> for no
expiration time.


<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

The expiration time of client certificates in days or <literal>null</literal> for no
expiration time.


<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

The expiration time of the certificate revocation list (CRL) in days or <literal>null</literal> for no
expiration time.


<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

The expiration time of the server certificate in days or <literal>null</literal> for no
expiration time.


<note><para>
This option is for the automatically handled CA and will be ignored if any
of the <option>services.taskserver.pki.manual.*</option> options are set.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.manual.ca.cert.description:
Fully qualified path to the CA certificate.
<note><para>
Setting this option will prevent automatic CA creation and handling.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.manual.server.ce.description:
Fully qualified path to the server certificate.
<note><para>
Setting this option will prevent automatic CA creation and handling.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.manual.server.cr.description:
Fully qualified path to the server certificate revocation list.
<note><para>
Setting this option will prevent automatic CA creation and handling.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.pki.manual.server.ke.description:
Fully qualified path to the server key.
<note><para>
Setting this option will prevent automatic CA creation and handling.
</para></note>

services.taskserver.queueSize.description:
Size of the connection backlog, see <citerefentry>
  <refentrytitle>listen</refentrytitle>
  <manvolnum>2</manvolnum>
</citerefentry>.

services.taskserver.requestLimit.description: Size limit of incoming requests, in bytes.

services.taskserver.trust.description:
Determines how client certificates are validated.

The value <literal>allow all</literal> performs no client
certificate validation. This is not recommended. The value
<literal>strict</literal> causes the client certificate to be
validated against a CA.

services.tcsd.conformanceCred.description:
Path to the conformance credential for your TPM.
See also the platformCred option

services.tcsd.enable.description:
Whether to enable tcsd, a Trusted Computing management service
that provides TCG Software Stack (TSS).  The tcsd daemon is
the only portal to the Trusted Platform Module (TPM), a hardware
chip on the motherboard.

services.tcsd.endorsementCred.description:
Path to the endorsement credential for your TPM.
See also the platformCred option

services.tcsd.firmwarePCRs.description: PCR indices used in the TPM for firmware measurements.

services.tcsd.group.description: Group account under which tcsd runs.

services.tcsd.kernelPCRs.description: PCR indices used in the TPM for kernel measurements.

services.tcsd.platformCred.description:
Path to the platform credential for your TPM. Your TPM
manufacturer may have provided you with a set of credentials
(certificates) that should be used when creating identities
using your TPM. When a user of your TPM makes an identity,
this credential will be encrypted as part of that process.
See the 1.1b TPM Main specification section 9.3 for information
on this process.

services.tcsd.stateDir.description:
The location of the system persistent storage file.
The system persistent storage file holds keys and data across
restarts of the TCSD and system reboots.

services.tcsd.user.description: User account under which tcsd runs.

services.teamspeak3.dataDir.description: Directory to store TS3 database and other state/data files.

services.teamspeak3.defaultVoicePort.description: Default UDP port for clients to connect to virtual servers - used for first virtual server, subsequent ones will open on incrementing port numbers by default.

services.teamspeak3.enable.description: Whether to run the Teamspeak3 voice communication server daemon.

services.teamspeak3.fileTransferIP.description: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming file transfer connections. Defaults to any IP.

services.teamspeak3.fileTransferPort.description: TCP port opened for file transfers.

services.teamspeak3.logPath.description: Directory to store log files in.

services.teamspeak3.queryIP.description: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming ServerQuery connections. Defaults to any IP.

services.teamspeak3.queryPort.description: TCP port opened for ServerQuery connections.

services.teamspeak3.voiceIP.description: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming voice connections. Defaults to any IP.

services.telepathy.enable.description:
Whether to enable Telepathy service, a communications framework
that enables real-time communication via pluggable protocol backends.

services.terraria.autoCreatedWorldSize.description:
Specifies the size of the auto-created world if <literal>worldPath</literal> does not
point to an existing world.

services.terraria.banListPath.description: The path to the ban list.

services.terraria.enable.description:
If enabled, starts a Terraria server. The server can be connected to via <literal>tmux -S /var/lib/terraria/terraria.sock attach</literal>
for administration by users who are a part of the <literal>terraria</literal> group (use <literal>C-b d</literal> shortcut to detach again).

services.terraria.maxPlayers.description: Sets the max number of players (between 1 and 255).

services.terraria.messageOfTheDay.description: Set the server message of the day text.

services.terraria.noUPnP.description: Disables automatic Universal Plug and Play.

services.terraria.password.description: Sets the server password. Leave <literal>null</literal> for no password.

services.terraria.port.description: Specifies the port to listen on.

services.terraria.secure.description: Adds additional cheat protection to the server.

services.terraria.worldPath.description:
The path to the world file (<literal>.wld</literal>) which should be loaded.
If no world exists at this path, one will be created with the size
specified by <literal>autoCreatedWorldSize</literal>.

services.tftpd.enable.description:
Whether to enable tftpd, a Trivial File Transfer Protocol server.
The server will be run as an xinetd service.

services.tftpd.path.description: Where the tftp server files are stored.

services.thermald.enable.description: Whether to enable thermald, the temperature management daemon.

services.thinkfan.enable.description: Whether to enable thinkfan, fan controller for ibm/lenovo thinkpads.

services.timesyncd.enable.description: Enables the systemd NTP client daemon.

services.timesyncd.servers.description: The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.

services.tinc.networks.description:
Defines the tinc networks which will be started.
Each network invokes a different daemon.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.bindToAddr.description: The ip address to bind to (both listen on and send packets from).

services.tinc.networks.<name>.chroot.description:
Change process root directory to the directory where the config file is located (/etc/tinc/netname/), for added security.
The chroot is performed after all the initialization is done, after writing pid files and opening network sockets.

Note that tinc can't run scripts anymore (such as tinc-down or host-up), unless it is setup to be runnable inside chroot environment.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.debugLevel.description:
The amount of debugging information to add to the log. 0 means little
logging while 5 is the most logging. <command>man tincd</command> for
more details.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.ed25519Pri.description: Path of the private ed25519 keyfile.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.extraConfi.description: Extra lines to add to the tinc service configuration file.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.hosts.description:
The name of the host in the network as well as the configuration for that host.
This name should only contain alphanumerics and underscores.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.interfaceT.description: The type of virtual interface used for the network connection

services.tinc.networks.<name>.listenAddr.description: The ip address to listen on for incoming connections.

services.tinc.networks.<name>.name.description:
The name of the node which is used as an identifier when communicating
with the remote nodes in the mesh. If null then the hostname of the system
is used to derive a name (note that tinc may replace non-alphanumeric characters in
hostnames by underscores).

services.tinc.networks.<name>.package.description: The package to use for the tinc daemon's binary.

services.tinydns.data.description: The DNS data to serve, in the format described by tinydns-data(8)

services.tinydns.enable.description: Whether to run the tinydns dns server

services.tinydns.ip.description: IP address on which to listen for connections

services.tlp.enable.description: Whether to enable the TLP daemon.

services.tomcat.axis2.enable.description: Whether to enable an Apache Axis2 container

services.tomcat.axis2.services.description: List containing AAR files or directories with AAR files which are web services to be deployed on Axis2

services.tomcat.baseDir.description: Location where Tomcat stores configuration files, webapplications and logfiles

services.tomcat.catalinaOpts.description: Parameters to pass to the Java Virtual Machine which spawns the Catalina servlet container

services.tomcat.commonLibs.description: List containing JAR files or directories with JAR files which are libraries shared by the web applications and the servlet container

services.tomcat.extraGroups.description: Defines extra groups to which the tomcat user belongs.

services.tomcat.group.description: Group account under which Apache Tomcat runs.

services.tomcat.javaOpts.description: Parameters to pass to the Java Virtual Machine which spawns Apache Tomcat

services.tomcat.logPerVirtualHost.description: Whether to enable logging per virtual host.

services.tomcat.sharedLibs.description: List containing JAR files or directories with JAR files which are libraries shared by the web applications

services.tomcat.user.description: User account under which Apache Tomcat runs.

services.tomcat.virtualHosts.description: List consisting of a virtual host name and a list of web applications to deploy on each virtual host

services.tomcat.webapps.description: List containing WAR files or directories with WAR files which are web applications to be deployed on Tomcat

services.tor.client.enable.description:
Whether to enable Tor daemon to route application
connections.  You might want to disable this if you plan
running a dedicated Tor relay.

services.tor.client.privoxy.enable.description:
Whether to enable and configure the system Privoxy to use Tor's
faster port, suitable for HTTP.

To have anonymity, protocols need to be scrubbed of identifying
information, and this can be accomplished for HTTP by Privoxy.

Privoxy can also be useful for KDE torification. A good setup would be:
setting SOCKS proxy to the default Tor port, providing maximum
circuit isolation where possible; and setting HTTP proxy to Privoxy
to route HTTP traffic over faster, but less isolated port.

services.tor.client.socksListenAddress.description:
Bind to this address to listen for connections from
Socks-speaking applications. Provides strong circuit
isolation, separate circuit per IP address.

services.tor.client.socksListenAddressFa.description:
Bind to this address to listen for connections from
Socks-speaking applications. Same as
<option>socksListenAddress</option> but uses weaker
circuit isolation to provide performance suitable for a
web browser.

services.tor.client.socksPolicy.description:
Entry policies to allow/deny SOCKS requests based on IP
address. First entry that matches wins. If no SocksPolicy
is set, we accept all (and only) requests from
<option>socksListenAddress</option>.

services.tor.controlPort.description:
If set, Tor will accept connections on the specified port
and allow them to control the tor process.
services.tor.controlPort.type: null or signed integer or string

services.tor.enable.description:
Enable the Tor daemon. By default, the daemon is run without
relay, exit, bridge or client connectivity.

services.tor.enableGeoIP.description:
Whenever to configure Tor daemon to use GeoIP databases.

Disabling this will disable by-country statistics for
bridges and relays and some client and third-party software
functionality.

services.tor.extraConfig.description:
Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to the
configuration file at the end.

services.tor.hiddenServices.description:
A set of static hidden services that terminate their Tor
circuits at this node.

Every element in this set declares a virtual onion host.

You can specify your onion address by putting corresponding
private key to an appropriate place in /var/lib/tor.

For services without private keys in /var/lib/tor Tor
daemon will generate random key pairs (which implies random
onion addresses) on restart. The latter could take a while,
please be patient.

<note><para>
  Hidden services can be useful even if you don't intend to
  actually <emphasis>hide</emphasis> them, since they can
  also be seen as a kind of NAT traversal mechanism.

  E.g. the example will make your sshd, whatever runs on
  "8080" and your mail server available from anywhere where
  the Tor network is available (which, with the help from
  bridges, is pretty much everywhere), even if both client
  and server machines are behind NAT you have no control
  over.
</para></note>
services.tor.hiddenServices.type: list or attribute set of submodules

services.tor.hiddenServices.<name?>.map.description: Port mapping for this hidden service.

services.tor.hiddenServices.<name?>.name.description:
Name of this tor hidden service.

This is purely descriptive.

After restarting Tor daemon you should be able to
find your .onion address in
<literal>/var/lib/tor/onion/$name/hostname</literal>.

services.tor.relay.accountingMax.description:
Specify maximum bandwidth allowed during an accounting period. This
allows you to limit overall tor bandwidth over some time period.
See the <literal>AccountingMax</literal> option by looking at the
tor manual <citerefentry><refentrytitle>tor</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry> for more.

Note this limit applies individually to upload and
download; if you specify <literal>"500 GBytes"</literal>
here, then you may transfer up to 1 TBytes of overall
bandwidth (500 GB upload, 500 GB download).

services.tor.relay.accountingStart.description:
Specify length of an accounting period. This allows you to limit
overall tor bandwidth over some time period. See the
<literal>AccountingStart</literal> option by looking at the tor
manual <citerefentry><refentrytitle>tor</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry> for more.

services.tor.relay.address.description:
The IP address or full DNS name for advertised address of your relay.
Leave unset and Tor will guess.

services.tor.relay.bandwidthBurst.description:
Specify this to allow bursts of the bandwidth usage of relayed (server)
traffic. The average usage will still be as specified in relayBandwidthRate.
Your own traffic is still unthrottled. Units: bytes/second.

services.tor.relay.bandwidthRate.description:
Specify this to limit the bandwidth usage of relayed (server)
traffic. Your own traffic is still unthrottled. Units: bytes/second.

services.tor.relay.contactInfo.description:
Contact information for the relay owner (e.g. a mail
address and GPG key ID).

services.tor.relay.enable.description:
Whether to enable relaying TOR traffic for others.

See <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/tor-doc-relay" />
for details.

Setting this to true requires setting
<option>services.tor.relay.role</option>
and
<option>services.tor.relay.port</option>
options.

services.tor.relay.exitPolicy.description:
A comma-separated list of exit policies. They're
considered first to last, and the first match wins. If you
want to _replace_ the default exit policy, end this with
either a reject *:* or an accept *:*. Otherwise, you're
_augmenting_ (prepending to) the default exit policy.
Leave commented to just use the default, which is
available in the man page or at
<link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/documentation.html" />.

Look at
<link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/faq-abuse.html#TypicalAbuses" />
for issues you might encounter if you use the default
exit policy.

If certain IPs and ports are blocked externally, e.g. by
your firewall, you should update your exit policy to
reflect this -- otherwise Tor users will be told that
those destinations are down.

services.tor.relay.nickname.description: A unique handle for your TOR relay.

services.tor.relay.port.description:
What port to advertise for Tor connections. This corresponds to the
<literal>ORPort</literal> section in the Tor manual; see
<citerefentry><refentrytitle>tor</refentrytitle>
<manvolnum>1</manvolnum></citerefentry> for more details.

At a minimum, you should just specify the port for the
relay to listen on; a common one like 143, 22, 80, or 443
to help Tor users who may have very restrictive port-based
firewalls.

services.tor.relay.role.description:
Your role in Tor network. There're several options:

<variablelist>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>exit</literal></term>
  <listitem>
    <para>
      An exit relay. This allows Tor users to access regular
      Internet services through your public IP.
    </para>

    <important><para>
      Running an exit relay may expose you to abuse
      complaints. See
      <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/faq.html.en#ExitPolicies" />
      for more info.
    </para></important>

    <para>
      You can specify which services Tor users may access via
      your exit relay using <option>exitPolicy</option> option.
    </para>
  </listitem>
</varlistentry>

<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>relay</literal></term>
  <listitem>
    <para>
      Regular relay. This allows Tor users to relay onion
      traffic to other Tor nodes, but not to public
      Internet.
    </para>

    <important><para>
      Note that some misconfigured and/or disrespectful
      towards privacy sites will block you even if your
      relay is not an exit relay. That is, just being listed
      in a public relay directory can have unwanted
      consequences.

      Which means you might not want to use
      this role if you browse public Internet from the same
      network as your relay, unless you want to write
      e-mails to those sites (you should!).
    </para></important>

    <para>
      See
      <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/tor-doc-relay.html.en" />
      for more info.
    </para>
  </listitem>
</varlistentry>

<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>bridge</literal></term>
  <listitem>
    <para>
      Regular bridge. Works like a regular relay, but
      doesn't list you in the public relay directory and
      hides your Tor node behind obfsproxy.
    </para>

    <para>
      Using this option will make Tor advertise your bridge
      to users through various mechanisms like
      <link xlink:href="https://bridges.torproject.org/" />, though.
    </para>

    <important>
      <para>
        WARNING: THE FOLLOWING PARAGRAPH IS NOT LEGAL ADVISE.
        Consult with your lawer when in doubt.
      </para>

      <para>
        This role should be safe to use in most situations
        (unless the act of forwarding traffic for others is
        a punishable offence under your local laws, which
        would be pretty insane as it would make ISP
        illegal).
      </para>
    </important>

    <para>
      See <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/bridges.html.en" />
      for more info.
    </para>
  </listitem>
</varlistentry>

<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>private-bridge</literal></term>
  <listitem>
    <para>
      Private bridge. Works like regular bridge, but does
      not advertise your node in any way.
    </para>

    <para>
      Using this role means that you won't contribute to Tor
      network in any way unless you advertise your node
      yourself in some way.
    </para>

    <para>
      Use this if you want to run a private bridge, for
      example because you'll give out your bridge address
      manually to your friends.
    </para>

    <para>
      Switching to this role after measurable time in
      "bridge" role is pretty useless as some Tor users
      would have learned about your node already. In the
      latter case you can still change
      <option>port</option> option.
    </para>

    <para>
      See <link xlink:href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/bridges.html.en" />
      for more info.
    </para>
  </listitem>
</varlistentry>
</variablelist>

services.tor.torsocks.allowInbound.description:
Set Torsocks to accept inbound connections. If set to
<literal>true</literal>, listen() and accept() will be
allowed to be used with non localhost address.

services.tor.torsocks.enable.description:
Whether to build <literal>/etc/tor/torsocks.conf</literal>
containing the specified global torsocks configuration.

services.tor.torsocks.fasterServer.description:
IP/Port of the Tor SOCKS server for torsocks-faster wrapper suitable for HTTP.
Currently, hostnames are NOT supported by torsocks.

services.tor.torsocks.onionAddrRange.description:
Tor hidden sites do not have real IP addresses. This
specifies what range of IP addresses will be handed to the
application as "cookies" for .onion names.  Of course, you
should pick a block of addresses which you aren't going to
ever need to actually connect to. This is similar to the
MapAddress feature of the main tor daemon.

services.tor.torsocks.server.description:
IP/Port of the Tor SOCKS server. Currently, hostnames are
NOT supported by torsocks.

services.tor.torsocks.socks5Password.description:
SOCKS5 password. The <literal>TORSOCKS_PASSWORD</literal>
environment variable overrides this option if it is set.

services.tor.torsocks.socks5Username.description:
SOCKS5 username. The <literal>TORSOCKS_USERNAME</literal>
environment variable overrides this option if it is set.

services.tor.tsocks.config.description:
Extra configuration. Contents will be added verbatim to TSocks
configuration file.

services.tor.tsocks.enable.description:
Whether to build tsocks wrapper script to relay application traffic via Tor.

<important>
  <para>You shouldn't use this unless you know what you're
  doing because your installation of Tor already comes with
  its own superior (doesn't leak DNS queries)
  <literal>torsocks</literal> wrapper which does pretty much
  exactly the same thing as this.</para>
</important>

services.tor.tsocks.server.description: IP address of TOR client to use.

services.torque.mom.enable.description: Whether to enable torque computing node.

services.toxBootstrapd.enable.description: Whether to enable the Tox DHT bootstrap daemon.

services.toxBootstrapd.extraConfig.description:
Configuration for bootstrap daemon.
See <link xlink:href="https://github.com/irungentoo/toxcore/blob/master/other/bootstrap_daemon/tox-bootstrapd.conf"/>
and <link xlink:href="http://wiki.tox.im/Nodes"/>.

services.toxvpn.auto_add_peers.description: peers to automacally connect to on startup

services.toxvpn.enable.description: Whether to enable enable toxvpn running on startup.

services.toxvpn.port.description: udp port for toxcore, port-forward to help with connectivity if you run many nodes behind one NAT

services.traefik.configFile.description:
Path to verbatim traefik.toml to use.
(Using that option has precedence over <literal>configOptions</literal>)

services.traefik.dataDir.description: Location for any persistent data traefik creates, ie. acme

services.traefik.enable.description: Whether to enable Traefik web server.

services.transmission.enable.description:
Whether or not to enable the headless Transmission BitTorrent daemon.

Transmission daemon can be controlled via the RPC interface using
transmission-remote or the WebUI (http://localhost:9091/ by default).

Torrents are downloaded to /var/lib/transmission/Downloads by default and are
accessible to users in the "transmission" group.

services.transmission.home.description: The directory where transmission will create files.

services.transmission.port.description: TCP port number to run the RPC/web interface.

services.transmission.settings.description:
Attribute set whos fields overwrites fields in settings.json (each
time the service starts). String values must be quoted, integer and
boolean values must not.

See https://trac.transmissionbt.com/wiki/EditConfigFiles for
documentation.

services.trezord.enable.description: Enable Trezor bridge daemon, for use with Trezor hardware bitcoin wallets.

services.tt-rss.auth.autoCreate.description:
Allow authentication modules to auto-create users in tt-rss internal
database when authenticated successfully.

services.tt-rss.auth.autoLogin.description:
Automatically login user on remote or other kind of externally supplied
authentication, otherwise redirect to login form as normal.
If set to true, users won't be able to set application language
and settings profile.

services.tt-rss.checkForUpdates.description: Check for updates automatically if running Git version

services.tt-rss.database.host.description: Host of the database. Leave null to use Unix domain socket.

services.tt-rss.database.port.description:
The database's port. If not set, the default ports will be provided (5432
and 3306 for pgsql and mysql respectively).

services.tt-rss.database.type.description: Database to store feeds. Supported are pgsql and mysql.

services.tt-rss.database.user.description:
The database user. The user must exist and has access to
the specified database.

services.tt-rss.email.fromAddress.description:
Address for sending outgoing mail. This applies to password reset
notifications, digest emails and any other mail.

services.tt-rss.email.fromName.description:
Name for sending outgoing mail. This applies to password reset
notifications, digest emails and any other mail.

services.tt-rss.email.login.description: SMTP authentication login used when sending outgoing mail.

services.tt-rss.email.password.description: SMTP authentication password used when sending outgoing mail.

services.tt-rss.email.security.description:
Used to select a secure SMTP connection. Allowed values: ssl, tls,
or empty.

services.tt-rss.email.server.description:
Hostname:port combination to send outgoing mail. Blank - use system
MTA.

services.tt-rss.enableGZipOutput.description:
Selectively gzip output to improve wire performance. This requires
PHP Zlib extension on the server.
Enabling this can break tt-rss in several httpd/php configurations,
if you experience weird errors and tt-rss failing to start, blank pages
after login, or content encoding errors, disable it.

services.tt-rss.feedCryptKey.description:
Key used for encryption of passwords for password-protected feeds
in the database. A string of 24 random characters. If left blank, encryption
is not used. Requires mcrypt functions.
Warning: changing this key will make your stored feed passwords impossible
to decrypt.

services.tt-rss.forceArticlePurge.description:
When this option is not 0, users ability to control feed purging
intervals is disabled and all articles (which are not starred)
older than this amount of days are purged.

services.tt-rss.logDestination.description:
Log destination to use. Possible values: sql (uses internal logging
you can read in Preferences -> System), syslog - logs to system log.
Setting this to blank uses PHP logging (usually to http server
error.log).

services.tt-rss.plugins.description:
List of plugins to load automatically for all users.
System plugins have to be specified here. Please enable at least one
authentication plugin here (auth_*).
Users may enable other user plugins from Preferences/Plugins but may not
disable plugins specified in this list.
Disabling auth_internal in this list would automatically disable
reset password link on the login form.

services.tt-rss.pool.description:
Name of existing phpfpm pool that is used to run web-application.
If not specified a pool will be created automatically with
default values.

services.tt-rss.pubSubHubbub.enable.description:
Enable client PubSubHubbub support in tt-rss. When disabled, tt-rss
won't try to subscribe to PUSH feed updates.

services.tt-rss.pubSubHubbub.hub.description:
URL to a PubSubHubbub-compatible hub server. If defined, "Published
articles" generated feed would automatically become PUSH-enabled.

services.tt-rss.registration.enable.description:
Allow users to register themselves. Please be aware that allowing
random people to access your tt-rss installation is a security risk
and potentially might lead to data loss or server exploit. Disabled
by default.

services.tt-rss.registration.maxUsers.description:
Maximum amount of users which will be allowed to register on this
system. 0 - no limit.

services.tt-rss.registration.notifyAddre.description: Email address to send new user notifications to.

services.tt-rss.selfUrlPath.description:
Full URL of your tt-rss installation. This should be set to the
location of tt-rss directory, e.g. http://example.org/tt-rss/
You need to set this option correctly otherwise several features
including PUSH, bookmarklets and browser integration will not work properly.

services.tt-rss.sessionCookieLifetime.description:
Default lifetime of a session (e.g. login) cookie. In seconds,
0 means cookie will be deleted when browser closes.

services.tt-rss.simpleUpdateMode.description:
Enables fallback update mode where tt-rss tries to update feeds in
background while tt-rss is open in your browser.
If you don't have a lot of feeds and don't want to or can't run
background processes while not running tt-rss, this method is generally
viable to keep your feeds up to date.
Still, there are more robust (and recommended) updating methods
available, you can read about them here: http://tt-rss.org/wiki/UpdatingFeeds

services.tt-rss.singleUserMode.description:
Operate in single user mode, disables all functionality related to
multiple users and authentication. Enabling this assumes you have
your tt-rss directory protected by other means (e.g. http auth).

services.tt-rss.sphinx.index.description:
Index names in Sphinx configuration. Example configuration
files are available on tt-rss wiki.

services.tt-rss.sphinx.server.description: Hostname:port combination for the Sphinx server.

services.tt-rss.user.description: User account under which both the update daemon and the web-application run.

services.tt-rss.virtualHost.description: Name of the nginx virtualhost to use and setup. If null, do not setup any virtualhost.

services.tzupdate.enable.description:
Enable the tzupdate timezone updating service. This provides
a one-shot service which can be activated with systemctl to 
update the timezone.

services.u9fs.enable.description: Whether to run the u9fs 9P server for Unix.

services.u9fs.extraArgs.description:
Extra arguments to pass on invocation,
see <command>man 4 u9fs</command>

services.u9fs.listenStreams.description:
Sockets to listen for clients on.
See <command>man 5 systemd.socket</command> for socket syntax.

services.udev.extraHwdb.description:
Additional <command>hwdb</command> files. They'll be written
into file <filename>10-local.hwdb</filename>. Thus they are
read before all other files.

services.udev.extraRules.description:
Additional <command>udev</command> rules. They'll be written
into file <filename>99-local.rules</filename>. Thus they are
read and applied after all other rules.

services.udev.packages.description:
List of packages containing <command>udev</command> rules.
All files found in
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/etc/udev/rules.d</filename> and
<filename><replaceable>pkg</replaceable>/lib/udev/rules.d</filename>
will be included.

services.udev.path.description:
Packages added to the <envar>PATH</envar> environment variable when
executing programs from Udev rules.

services.udisks2.enable.description:
Whether to enable Udisks, a DBus service that allows
applications to query and manipulate storage devices.

services.uhub.aclConfig.description: Contents of user ACL configuration file.

services.uhub.address.description: Address to bind the hub to.

services.uhub.enable.description: Whether to enable the uhub ADC hub.

services.uhub.plugins.authSqlite.enable.description: Whether to enable the Sqlite authentication database plugin

services.uhub.plugins.authSqlite.file.description: Path to user database. Use the uhub-passwd utility to create the database and add/remove users.

services.uhub.plugins.history.connect.description: The number of chat history messages to send when users connect (0 = do not send any history).

services.uhub.plugins.history.default.description: When !history is provided without arguments, then this default number of messages are returned.

services.uhub.plugins.history.enable.description: Whether to enable the history plugin.

services.uhub.plugins.history.max.description: The maximum number of messages to keep in history

services.uhub.plugins.logging.enable.description: Whether to enable the logging plugin.

services.uhub.plugins.logging.syslog.description: If true then the system log is used instead of writing to file.

services.uhub.plugins.welcome.enable.description: Whether to enable the welcome plugin.

services.uhub.plugins.welcome.motd.description:
Welcome message displayed to clients after connecting 
and with the <literal>!motd</literal> command.

services.uhub.plugins.welcome.rules.description: Rules message, displayed to clients with the <literal>!rules</literal> command.

services.uhub.port.description: TCP port to bind the hub to.

services.unbound.allowedAccess.description: What networks are allowed to use unbound as a resolver.

services.unbound.enable.description: Whether to enable Unbound domain name server.

services.unbound.enableRootTrustAnchor.description: Use and update root trust anchor for DNSSEC validation.

services.unbound.forwardAddresses.description: What servers to forward queries to.

services.unbound.interfaces.description: What addresses the server should listen on.

services.unclutter-xfixes.enable.description: Enable unclutter-xfixes to hide your mouse cursor when inactive.

services.unclutter-xfixes.extraOptions.description: More arguments to pass to the unclutter-xfixes command.

services.unclutter-xfixes.threshold.description: Minimum number of pixels considered cursor movement.

services.unclutter-xfixes.timeout.description: Number of seconds before the cursor is marked inactive.

services.unclutter.enable.description: Enable unclutter to hide your mouse cursor when inactive

services.unclutter.excluded.description: Names of windows where unclutter should not apply

services.unclutter.extraOptions.description: More arguments to pass to the unclutter command

services.unclutter.keystroke.description: Wait for a keystroke before hiding the cursor

services.unclutter.threeshold.description: Minimum number of pixels considered cursor movement

services.unclutter.timeout.description: Number of seconds before the cursor is marked inactive

services.unifi.dataDir.description:
Where to store the database and other data.

This directory will be bind-mounted to /var/lib/unifi/data as part of the service startup.

services.unifi.enable.description: Whether or not to enable the unifi controller service.

services.unifi.initialJavaHeapSize.description:
Set the initial heap size for the JVM in MB. If this option isn't set, the
JVM will decide this value at runtime.

services.unifi.maximumJavaHeapSize.description:
Set the maximimum heap size for the JVM in MB. If this option isn't set, the
JVM will decide this value at runtime.

services.unifi.openPorts.description:
Whether or not to open the minimum required ports on the firewall.

This is necessary to allow firmware upgrades and device discovery to
work. For remote login, you should additionally open (or forward) port
8443.

services.upower.enable.description:
Whether to enable Upower, a DBus service that provides power
management support to applications.

services.uptime.configFile.description:
The uptime configuration file

If mongodb: server != localhost, please set usesRemoteMongo = true

If you only want to run the monitor, please set enableWebService = false
and enableSeparateMonitoringService = true

If autoStartMonitor: false (recommended) and you want to run both
services, please set enableSeparateMonitoringService = true

services.uptime.enableSeparateMonitoring.description: Whether to enable the uptime monitoring service.

services.uptime.enableWebService.description: Whether to enable the uptime monitoring program web service.

services.uptime.nodeEnv.description: The node environment to run in (development, production, etc.)

services.uptime.usesRemoteMongo.description: Whether the configuration file specifies a remote mongo instance

services.uptimed.enable.description:
Enable <literal>uptimed</literal>, allowing you to track
your highest uptimes.

services.urxvtd.enable.description:
Enable urxvtd, the urxvt terminal daemon. To use urxvtd, run
"urxvtc".

services.usbguard.IPCAccessControlFiles.description:
The files at this location will be interpreted by the daemon as IPC
